EASY: The tasks involve straightforward calculations of surface integrals, primarily requiring basic knowledge of integration techniques and the ability to set up the integrals properly based on parametric representations of the surfaces.

original.solution:
Solution.

a) The problem is easiest to solve by transitioning to spherical coordinates. In these coordinates, $U=r$ and using formulas $(2.80)$ we get

$$
\operatorname{grad} U=\frac{\partial U}{\partial r} \ddot{e}_{r}+\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial U}{\partial \theta} \ddot{e}_{0}+\frac{1}{r \sin \theta} \frac{\partial U}{\partial \varphi} \vec{e}_{\phi}=\dot{e}_{r}
$$

(Since the scalar field $U$ does not depend on $\theta$ and $\varphi$.) In Cartesian coordinates, $\operatorname{grad} U$ has the form

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{grad} U=\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} \dot{i}+\frac{\partial U}{\partial y} j+\frac{\partial U}{\partial z} \dot{k}= \\
=\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}} \ddot{i}+\frac{y}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}} \ddot{j}+\frac{z}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}}
\end{gathered}
$$

b) In spherical coordinates:

$$
\operatorname{grad} U=\frac{\partial U}{\partial r} \dot{e}_{r}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(\frac{1}{r^{2}}\right) \dot{e}_{r}=-\frac{2}{r^{3}} \dot{e}_{r}
$$

In Cartesian coordinates:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{grad} U=\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{x}}\left(\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right) \dot{i}+ \\
+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right) \vec{j}+\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right) \dot{k}= \\
=(-2)\left(\frac{x \vec{i}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{y \vec{j}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{z \vec{k}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

Solution.

$$
\operatorname{div} \vec{A}=\nabla \vec{A}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x y^{2}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(x^{2} y\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial z} z^{3}=y^{2}+x^{2}+3 z^{2}
$$

From this, at $x=1, y=-1, z=3$ we get

$$
\left.\operatorname{div} \vec{A}\right|_{M(1,-1,3)}=29
$$

b) First, we calculate the gradient of the function $\varphi$:

$\nabla \varphi=\operatorname{grad} \varphi=\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial x} \dot{i}+\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial y} \dot{j}+\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial z} \dot{k}=y^{2} z^{2} \dot{i}+2 x y z^{2} \dot{j}+2 x z y^{2} \dot{k}$.

Now we find the divergence of this vector field:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla(\nabla \varphi)= & \nabla^{2} \varphi=\Delta \varphi=\operatorname{grad} \varphi=\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial y^{2}}+\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial z^{2}}= \\
& =2 x z^{2}+2 x y^{2}=2 x\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

c) $\operatorname{div} \dot{A}=\nabla \dot{A}=\frac{\partial(4 x y z)}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial\left(-y^{2} z\right)}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial\left(-z^{2} y\right)}{\partial z}=4 y z-2 y z-2 z y=0$.

The divergence of the field $\dot{A}$ turned out to be zero at every point in space. The vector field $\dot{A}$ is solenoidal.

Solution.

a) We proceed according to formula (2.21):

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{rot} \dot{A}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\vec{i} & \ddot{j} & \dot{k} \\
\frac{\hat{z}}{\partial x} & \frac{\hat{c}}{\partial y} & \frac{\hat{c}}{\partial z} \\
\frac{y}{z} & \frac{z}{x} & \frac{x}{y}
\end{array}\right|=i\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)-\frac{\hat{c}}{\partial z}\left(\frac{z}{x}\right)\right)+\dot{j}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(\frac{y}{z}\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\right)+ \\
+\dot{k}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{z}{x}\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{y}{z}\right)\right)=\dot{i}\left(-\frac{x}{y^{2}}-\frac{1}{x}\right)+\vec{j}\left(-\frac{y}{z^{2}}-\frac{1}{y}\right)+\vec{k}\left(-\frac{z}{x^{2}}-\frac{1}{z}\right)= \\
=-\left(\frac{1+x^{2}}{x y^{2}}, \frac{1+y^{2}}{y z^{2}}, \frac{1+z^{2}}{z x^{2}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

b) Write the field $\vec{A}$ in Cartesian coordinates:

$$
\vec{A}=f\left(\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right)(x, y, z)
$$

Using formula (2.21), we calculate the desired curl:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{rot} \vec{A}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\vec{i} & \vec{j} & \vec{k} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
x f(r) & y f(r) & z f(r)
\end{array}\right|=\vec{i}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(z f(r))-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(y f(r))\right)+ \\
& +\dot{j}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(x f(r))-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(z f(r))\right)+\vec{k}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(y f(r))-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(x f(r))\right)= \\
& =\ddot{i}\left(x f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{y}{r}-y f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{z}{r}\right)+\vec{j}\left(x f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{z}{r}-z f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{x}{r}\right)+ \\
& +\dot{k}\left(y f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{x}{r}-x f^{\prime}(r) \cdot \frac{y}{r}\right)=\ddot{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The field $\dot{A}$, defined in $R_{3}$, turned out to be irrotational ( $\operatorname{rot} \dot{A}=0$ ). As is known, an irrotational field defined throughout space has a potential $\varphi$, i.e., the field $\dot{A}$ can be represented as

$$
\ddot{A}=\operatorname{grad} \varphi
$$

In this case, we can set $\varphi=F(r)$, where the function $F(r)$ is such that $F_{r}^{\prime}(r)=r f(r)$, i.e., $F(r)=\int r f(r) d r$.

original.problem:
4.80. Integrate the Clairaut's equation

$$
y=x \frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{1}{2(d y / d x)}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let $p=\frac{d y}{d x}$, then from the equation we get $y=x p+\frac{1}{2 p}$. Differentiate both sides of the last equation and replace $d y$ with $p d x: p d x=p d x+x d p-\frac{d p}{2 p^{2}}$. Transform the obtained equation: $d p\left(x-\frac{1}{2 p^{2}}\right)=0$. From this it follows: a) $d p=0, p=C=$ const and the general solution of the Clairaut equation has the form $y=C x+\frac{1}{2 C}$; b) from the equality of the second factor to zero we get $x=\frac{1}{2 p^{2}}$; eliminate the parameter $p$ from this equation and the equation $y=x p+\frac{1}{2 p}$, we have $y^{2}=2 x$.

original.problem: Example 1.3. Compute $\int x e^{x} d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $u=x, e^{x} d x=d v$. Then $d u=d x$, and $v=\int d v=\int e^{x} d x=e^{x}$ (it is not necessary to write the constant of integration here). By formula (1.10) we have

$$
\int x e^{x} d x=x e^{x}-\int e^{x} d x=x e^{x}-e^{x}+C=e^{x}(x-1)+C
$$

original.problem: Example 1.2. Find $\int \frac{x d x}{1+x^{2}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. This integral could be found using the same technique as in Example 1.1. However, we will show how the integrand is formally transformed after introducing a new variable of integration. Introduce a new variable of integration $t$, related to the old variable by the equation $t=1+x^{2}$. Next, we transform the integrand to the form of the right-hand side of (1.9) in accordance with the remarks noted after Problem 1.1. We have

$$
d t=d\left(1+x^{2}\right)=\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{\prime} d x=2 x d x \Rightarrow x d x=\frac{1}{2} d t
$$

Thus, in accordance with (1.9)

$$
\int \frac{x d x}{1+x^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d t}{t}=\frac{1}{2} \ln |t|+C=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1+x^{2}\right)+C
$$

llm_response:
The problem involves finding the integral \( \int \frac{x d x}{1+x^{2}} \), and the solution provided explains the transformation of the integrand and the steps leading to the final answer.

Thus, this problem can be classified as follows:

EASY: The solution is primarily a straightforward computation involving the evaluation of an integral through substitution.

original.problem: Example 1.4. Calculate $\int e^{x} \cos x d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $u=\cos x, d v=e^{x} d x$. Then $d u=-\sin x d x, v=e^{x}$, and by formula (1.10) we have:

$$
\int e^{x} \cos x d x=e^{x} \cos x+\int e^{x} \sin x d x
$$

The second integral on the right side of the obtained equality is integrated by parts again, and the necessary actions for integration by parts are conveniently written as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int e^{x} \sin x d x & =\left|\begin{array}{l}
d v=e^{x} d x, v=e^{x} \\
u=\sin x, d u=\cos x d x
\end{array}\right|= \\
& =e^{x} \sin x-\int e^{x} \cos x d x
\end{aligned}
$$

We now get:

$$
\int e^{x} \cos x d x=e^{x} \cos x+e^{x} \sin x-\int e^{x} \cos x d x
$$

The required indefinite integral $\int e^{x} \cos x d x$ appears in the right side of this equality. Transferring it to the left side of the equality, we get

$$
2 \int e^{x} \cos x d x=e^{x}(\cos x+\sin x)
$$

From which it follows that $\int e^{x} \cos x d x=\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos x+\sin x)+C$ (we added the constant of integration $C$, since it is clear that the function $\frac{e^{x}}{2}(\cos x+\sin x)$ is one of the antiderivatives of the function $e^{x} \cos x$).

Integration by parts is typically used for calculating indefinite integrals of the form

$$
\int x^{m} \sin \alpha x d x, \int x^{m} \cos \beta x d x, \int x^{m} e^{\gamma x} d x
$$

( $m$ - a positive integer, $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ - constants);

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int e^{\alpha x} \cos \beta x d x, \int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x, \int \arcsin x d x \\
\int \operatorname{arcctg} x d x, \int x^{n} \ln x d x
\end{gathered}
$$

and others.

Remark. The process of integration generally involves the judicious application of the methods described above (algebraic transformations of the integrand, integration by parts, integration by substitution) to reduce the given integral to an integral (or integrals) that are already known or whose evaluation presents no difficulty.

To implement this integration program in practice, it is necessary to be able to integrate those classes of elementary functions for which integration methods are well developed. It is important to remember that for any function continuous on an interval $(a ; b)$, there exists an antiderivative on this interval and, consequently, an indefinite integral.

original.problem:
Example 1.1. Find the integrals:
a) $\int \sin (7 x+3) d x$,
b) $\int \frac{d x}{x+5}$.
c) $\int(3 x+5)^{99} d x$,
d) $\int e^{x^{3}} x^{2} d x$
e) $\int \sin ^{3} x \cos x d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. a) Here the substitution $t=7 x+3$ is made, as in this case the indefinite integral is reduced to a tabular integral of sine

$$
\begin{aligned}
t=7 x+3 \Rightarrow d t & =d(7 x+3)=(7 x+3)^{\prime} d x=7 d x, \text { i.e. } \\
d t & =7 d x \Rightarrow d x=\frac{1}{7} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking into account the chosen substitution, we get

$$
\int \sin (7 x+3) d x=\frac{1}{7} \int \sin t d t=-\frac{1}{7} \cos t+C=-\frac{1}{7} \cos (7 x+3)+C
$$

b) In this example, the substitution $t=x+5$ is natural, then

$$
d t=d(x+5)=(x+5)^{\prime} d x=d x \Rightarrow d t=d x
$$

As a result

$$
\int \frac{d x}{(x+5)}=\int \frac{d t}{t}=\ln |t|+C=\ln |x+5|+C
$$

c) This indefinite integral is easily found by the substitution $t=3 x+5$. Obviously, $d t=3 d x$ and

$$
\int(3 x+5)^{99} d x=\frac{1}{3} \int t^{99} d t=\frac{1}{3} \frac{t^{100}}{100}+C=\frac{(3 x+5)^{100}}{300}+C
$$

d) In this case, the substitution $x=t^{3}$ leads to the goal. Then

$$
d t=d x^{3}=\left(x^{3}\right)^{\prime} d x=3 x^{2} d x \Rightarrow x^{2} d x=\frac{1}{3} d t
$$

Taking into account these results

$$
\int e^{x^{3}} x^{2} d x=\frac{1}{3} \int e^{t} d t=\frac{1}{3} e^{t}+C=\frac{1}{3} e^{x^{3}}+C
$$

This integral can also be found directly by bringing $x^{2}$ under the differential sign, considering that by property (1.3) $d \int f(x) d x=f(x) d x$. The expression $x^{2} d x$ can be rewritten as

$$
x^{2} d x=d \int x^{2} d x=d \frac{x^{3}}{3}=\frac{1}{3} d x^{3}
$$

Then the integral in question can be rewritten as follows: $\int e^{x^{3}} x^{2} d x=\frac{1}{3} \int e^{x^{3}} d x^{3}$. If we now denote $u=x^{3}$, we get in the end

$$
\int e^{x^{3}} x^{2} d x=\frac{1}{3} \int e^{x^{3}} d x^{3}=\frac{1}{3} \int e^{u} d u=\frac{1}{3} e^{u}+C=\frac{1}{3} e^{x^{3}}+C
$$

Remark. Formula (1.9) reflects the property of invariance of the integration formula: integration formulas retain their form when substituting any differentiable function of the independent variable for the independent variable.

e) It is easy to notice that $\cos x d x=d \sin x$. Then

$$
\int \sin ^{3} x \cos x d x=\int \sin ^{3} x d \sin x
$$

If we now denote $\sin x=t$, we get

$$
\int \sin ^{3} x \cos x d x=\int t^{3} d t=\frac{t^{4}}{4}+C=\frac{\sin ^{4} x}{4}+C
$$

In the general case, the transformation of the integrand expression to a new variable involves two aspects:

1) transforming the integrand function in terms of the new variable
2) expressing the differential of the old variable in terms of the differential of the new variable.

This last step is carried out by formally finding the differential of the right and left sides of the equations
$x=\varphi(t)$ or $t=\varphi^{-1}(x)$, connecting the old and new variables:

$$
d x=d \varphi(t)=\varphi^{\prime}(t) d t \text { or } d t=d \varphi^{-1}(x)=\left(\varphi^{-1}(x)\right)^{\prime} d x
$$

=-\frac{1}{20} \cos 10 x-\frac{1}{8} \cos 4 x+C

$$

original.problem: Example 1.12. Find $\int \sin ^{4} x \cos ^{4} x d x$.
original.solution:
Solution.

$$
\begin{gathered}

original.problem: Example 2.28. Compute $I_{n}=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{n} e^{-x} d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. Using the formula for integration by parts, we find

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{n} e^{-x} d x=-\left.\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} x^{n} e^{-x}\right|_{0} ^{b}+n \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{n-1} e^{-x} d x
$$

from here

$$
I_{n}=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{b} x^{n} e^{-x} d x=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty}\left(-b^{n} e^{-b}+n \int_{0}^{b} x^{n-1} e^{-x} d x\right)=n I_{n-1}
$$

We find \( I_{0}=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} d x \):

$$
I_{0}=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{b} e^{-x} d x=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty}\left(e^{0}-e^{-b}\right)=1
$$

Thus

$$
I_{1}=1 \cdot I_{0}=1, I_{2}=2 \cdot I_{1}=2, \ldots, I_{n}=1 \cdot 2 \cdot \ldots \cdot n=n!
$$

## 2.4. GEOMETRIC APPLICATIONS OF DEFINITE INTEGRALS

## Area of a Plane Curve

The area of a plane figure bounded by curves given by their equations in Cartesian coordinates: above - $y=y_{1}(x)$, below - $y=y_{2}(x)$, and on the left and right by segments of the lines $x=a$ and $x=b$, is calculated by the formula

$$
S=\left|\int_{a}^{b}\left(y_{1}(x)-y_{2}(x)\right) d x\right|
$$

The area of a plane figure bounded by curves given by their equations in Cartesian coordinates: to the right - $x=x_{1}(y)$, to the left - $x=x_{2}(y)$, and below and above by segments of the lines $y=c$ and $y=d$, is calculated by the formula

$$
S=\left|\int_{c}^{d}\left(x_{1}(y)-x_{2}(y)\right) d y\right|
$$

The area of a closed plane figure bounded by a curve given by parametric equations: $x=x(t)$, $y=y(t), 0 \leqslant t \leqslant T$ can be calculated using one of three formulas (assuming that as $t$ increases from 0 to $T$, the curve is traversed counterclockwise).

$$
S=\int_{0}^{T} y(t) x^{\prime}(t) d t=\int_{0}^{T} x(t) y^{\prime}(t) d t=0.5 \int_{0}^{T}\left(x(t) y^{\prime}(t)+y(t) x^{\prime}(t)\right) d t
$$

The area of a figure bounded by a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates $\rho=\rho(\varphi)$ and segments of two rays $\varphi=\alpha$ and $\varphi=\beta$, is calculated by the formula

$$
S=0.5\left|\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}(\rho(\varphi))^{2} d \varphi\right|
$$

## Arc Length

The length of an arc of a smooth curve given by the equation in Cartesian coordinates $y=y(x)(a \leqslant x \leqslant b)$, is calculated by the formula

$$
L=\left|\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+\left(y^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}} d x\right|
$$

The length of an arc of a smooth curve given by the equation in Cartesian coordinates $x=x(y)(c \leqslant y \leqslant d)$, is calculated by the formula

$$
L=\left|\int_{c}^{d} \sqrt{1+\left(x^{\prime}(y)\right)^{2}} d y\right|
$$

The length of an arc of a smooth curve given by parametric equations $x=x(t)$ and $y=y(t)\left(t_{1} \leqslant t \leqslant t_{2}\right)$ is calculated by the formula

$$
L=\left|\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t\right|
$$

The length of an arc of a smooth curve given by parametric equations in three-dimensional space $x=x(t), y=y(t)$, $z=z(t)\left(t_{1} \leqslant t \leqslant t_{2}\right)$ is calculated by the formula

$$
L=\left|\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(z^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t\right|
$$

The length of an arc of a smooth curve given by a polar equation, $\rho=\rho(\varphi), \alpha \leqslant \varphi \leqslant \beta$ is calculated by the formula

$$
L=\left|\int_{a}^{\beta} \sqrt{\left.\left.(\rho(\varphi))^{2}\right)+\left(\rho^{\prime}(\varphi)\right)^{2}\right)} d \varphi\right|
$$

If a segment of a smooth curve is rotated around an arbitrary axis, the area of the surface formed is calculated by the formula

$$
S=2 \pi\left|\int_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}} G(l(r)) d l(r)\right|

$$

If a segment of a smooth curve given by parametric equations $x=x(t)$ and $y=y(t)\left(t_{1} \leqslant t \leqslant t_{2}\right)$ is rotated around the $O Y$ axis, the area of the surface formed is calculated by the formula

original.problem: Example 3.16. Find $u_{x x}^{\prime \prime}, u_{y y}^{\prime \prime}, u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}, u_{y x}^{\prime \prime}, u_{x y z}^{\prime \prime \prime}, u_{x y^{2} z}^{I V}$, if $u=e^{x y z}$.
original.solution:
Solution. According to the definition of higher-order partial derivatives (3.2), it is necessary to first find the corresponding partial derivatives of a lower order. In this case, it is necessary to find the first-order partial derivatives

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}, u_{y}^{\prime}, u_{z}^{\prime} \Rightarrow u_{x}^{\prime}=e^{x y z} y z ; u_{y}^{\prime}=e^{x y z} z x ; u_{z}^{\prime}=e^{x y z} x y
$$

Next, in accordance with (3.2)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u_{x x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(e^{x y z} y z\right)= \\
& \quad=y z\left(e^{x y z}\right)_{x}^{\prime}=y z e^{x y z}(x y z)_{x}^{\prime}=(y z)^{2} e^{x y z} \\
& u_{y y}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial y^{2}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(e^{x y z} x z\right)= \\
& \quad=x z\left(e^{x y z}\right)_{y}^{\prime}=x z e^{x y z}(x y z)_{y}^{\prime}=(x z)^{2} e^{x y z}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial y \partial x}=\left(u_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\epsilon^{x y z} y z\right)= \\
=y z e^{x y z}(x y z)_{y}^{\prime}+e^{x y z}(y z)_{y}^{\prime}= \\
=e^{x y z} x y z^{2}+e^{x y z} z=e^{x y z}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right) \\
u_{y x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x \partial y}=\left(u_{y}^{\prime}\right)_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(e^{x y z} x z\right)= \\
=x z e^{x y z}(x y z)_{x}^{\prime}+e^{x y z}(z z)_{x}^{\prime}= \\
=e^{x y z} x y z^{2}+e^{x y z} z=e^{x y z}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Now let's find the third-order partial derivative $u_{x y z}^{\prime \prime \prime}$. According to (3.2), we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{x y z}^{\prime \prime \prime}=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial y \partial x}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(e^{x y z}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)\right)= \\
=e^{x y z}(x y z)_{z}^{\prime}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)+e^{x y z}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)_{z}^{\prime}= \\
=e^{x y z} x y\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)+e^{x y z}(2 x y z+1)= \\
=e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}+x y z+2 x y z+1\right)=e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}+3 x y z+1\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

The fourth-order partial derivative $u_{x y^{2} z}^{I V}$ will be found as the partial derivative with respect to the variable $z$ of the third-order partial derivative $u_{x y^{2}}^{\prime \prime \prime}$. In turn, the specified third-order derivative is found using the formula $u_{x y^{2}}^{\prime \prime \prime}=$ $=\left(u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}\right)_{y}^{\prime}$, that is, as the partial derivative with respect to the variable $y$ of the second-order partial derivative $u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}$. Thus, in accordance with the above, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{x y^{2} z}^{I V}=\left(\left(u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}\right)_{y}^{\prime}\right)_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{\partial}{\partial z} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial y \partial x}\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(e^{x y z}\left(x y z^{2}+z\right)\right)= \\
=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(z\left(\left(e^{x y z}\right)_{y}^{\prime}(x y z+1)+e^{x y z}(x y z+1)_{y}^{\prime}\right)\right)= \\
=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(z\left(e^{x y z} x z,(x y z+1)+e^{x y z} x z\right)\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(z e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)\right)= \\
=e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)+ \\
\quad+z\left(\left(e^{x y z}\right)_{z}^{\prime}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)+e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)_{z}^{\prime}\right)= \\
=e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)+ \\
\quad+z\left(e^{x y z} x y\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)+e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z+2 x\right)\right)= \\
=e^{x y z}\left(x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z+x^{3} y^{2} z^{3}+2 x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x^{2} y z^{2}+2 x z\right)= \\
\quad=e^{x y z}\left(x^{3} y^{2} z^{3}+5 x^{2} y z^{2}+4 x z\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

original.problem:
Example 3.14. Find the partial derivatives of the function

$$
u=\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{\sin (x y z)}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. In this case, both the base and the exponent depend on independent variables. One way to find partial derivatives in this case is to logarithmize both sides of the equation defining the function (i.e., the same technique used when finding the derivative of a single-variable function in a similar situation). We have

$$
\ln u=\ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{\sin (x y z)}=\sin (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)
$$

Thus, $\ln u=\sin (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)$. Differentiating both sides of the obtained equation sequentially with respect to $x, y, z$, we will find the partial derivatives. It is necessary to keep in mind that the function $\ln u$, written on the left side of the obtained equation, represents a composite function. Therefore, its partial derivative with respect to any of the variables has the form $(\ln u)^{\prime}=\frac{u^{\prime}}{u}$. Taking this into account, we get

$$
\frac{u_{x}^{\prime}}{u}=y z \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\sin (x y z) \frac{2 x}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}
$$

From which

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=u\left(y z \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 x \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right)
$$

Or

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{x}^{\prime}=\left(x^{2}\right. & \left.+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{\sin (x y z)} \times \\
& \times\left(y z \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 x \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, the partial derivatives with respect to the variables $y$ and $z$ are found:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u_{y}^{\prime}}{u}= & x z \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 y \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}} \Rightarrow \\
\Rightarrow u_{y}^{\prime}= & \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{\sin (x y z)} \times \\
& \times\left(x z \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 y \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right) \\
\frac{u_{z}^{\prime}}{u}= & x y \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 z \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}} \Rightarrow \\
\Rightarrow u_{z}^{\prime}= & \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{\sin (x y z)} \times \\
& \times\left(x y \cos (x y z) \ln \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\frac{2 z \sin (x y z)}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
Example 3.15. Find the partial derivatives of the function

$$
f(x, y, z)=\left\{\begin{array}{lr}
x^{4}+\frac{2 x y z}{y^{2}+z^{2}}, & y^{2}+z^{2} \neq 0 \\
x^{4}, & y^{2}+z^{2} = 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

at the point $A(1,0,0)$.
original.solution:
Solution. Consider the function $f(x, 0,0)=x^{4}$. Let's find the derivative of this function: $f_{x}^{\prime}(x, 0,0)=4 x^{3}$ and $f_{x}^{\prime}(1,0,0)=4$. Next, consider the functions $f(1, y, 0)=1$ and $f(1,0, z)=1$. We have: $f_{x}^{\prime}(1, y, 0)=0, f_{z}^{\prime}(1,0, z)=0$ and, in particular, $f_{y}^{\prime}(1,0,0)=0$ and $f_{z}^{\prime}(1,0,0)=0$. Thus, the partial derivatives of the function at point $A(1,0,0)$ exist, but as shown in Example 3.11, the function is discontinuous at point $A(1,0,0)$. Therefore, the existence of partial derivatives at a point does not guarantee the continuity of the function at that point in general.

Remark. The above definition of partial derivatives usually applies to interior points of the domain of a function of several variables and, in general, is not suitable for boundary points of this domain, as it is not always possible to compute the partial increments of the function. Therefore, in the boundary points of the domain of functions of several variables, partial derivatives are defined as the limit values of these derivatives.

From the definition of partial derivatives as ordinary derivatives under the condition of fixing the values of all variables except one, for which the derivative is taken, it follows, in particular, that the geometric meaning of partial derivatives of a function of two variables $z=f(x, y)$ at a point $P_{0}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is analogous to the geometric meaning of the derivative of a function of one variable: $f_{x}^{\prime}(x, y)$ is the tangent of the angle of inclination to the $O X$ axis (relative to this axis) of the tangent at the point $M_{0}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}, f\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)\right)$ to the section of the surface $z=f(x, y)$ by the plane $y=y_{0}$.

Partial derivatives of higher orders at point $P_{0}$ are defined by transitioning from partial derivatives of order $r-1$ to partial derivatives of order $r$ according to the following relationship:

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i_{r}}}\left(\frac{\partial^{r-1} f}{\partial x_{i_{r-1}} \ldots \partial x_{i_{1}}}\right)=\frac{\partial^{r} f}{\partial x_{i_{r}}} \partial x_{i_{r-1}} \ldots \partial x_{i_{1}} \equiv f_{x_{1_{1}} \ldots x_{r_{r-1} x_{r_{r}}}}^{(r)}
$$

original.problem: Example 3.21. Show that the function $f(x, y)=\frac{x}{x^{2}-a y^{2}}$ satisfies the equation $\frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}}=a \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's find the necessary partial derivatives:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=\frac{x^{2}-a y^{2}-2 x^{2}}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}}=-\frac{x^{2}+a y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}} ; \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}=\frac{2 a x}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}}=-\frac{2 x\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(x^{2}+a y^{2}\right) \cdot 2 \cdot\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right) \cdot 2 x}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{2 x\left(x^{2}+3 a y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}}=\frac{2 a x\left(\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}+2 y\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right) \cdot 2 a y\right)}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{2 a x\left(x^{2}+3 a y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}-a y^{2}\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}}=a \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}}$ as required.

One of the most important applications of the differential of functions of several variables is its use in approximate calculations of the values of differentiable functions at a given point. The basis for this application is formula (3.3), which relates the total increment of the function to its total differential of the first order. According to this formula,

$$
\Delta f\left(P_{0}\right)=f(P)-f\left(P_{0}\right)=d f\left(P_{0}\right)+\varepsilon
$$

where $\varepsilon=o(\rho)$ is an infinitesimal of a higher order than $\rho\left(P, P_{0}\right), P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$.

For sufficiently small increments of the arguments $x_{k}=x_{k}-x_{k}^{0}, k=1,2, \ldots, n$, the quantity $\varepsilon$ can be neglected, then $\Delta f\left(P_{0}\right)=f(P)-f\left(P_{0}\right) \approx d f\left(P_{0}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)-f\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right) \approx \\
& \approx \frac{\partial f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\partial x_{1}} \Delta x_{1} + \frac{\partial f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\partial x_{2}} \Delta x_{2} + \ldots + \frac{\partial f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\partial x_{n}} \Delta x_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using formula (3.10), one can find an approximate value of the function $f(P)$ based on its value at point $P_{0}$ and the values of its partial derivatives $f_{x_{k}}^{\prime}\left(P_{0}\right)$ at the same point.

In general, for a function $f(P)$ that is $n+1$ times differentiable in some $\delta$-neighborhood of point $P_{0}$, the following Taylor formula holds:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\Delta f(P)=d f\left(P_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2!} d^{2} f\left(P_{0}\right)+\ldots+\frac{1}{n!} d^{n} f\left(P_{0}\right)+ \\
+\frac{1}{(n+1)!} d^{n-1} f\left(P_{1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where $P_{1}$ is some point in the specified $\delta$-neighborhood, which in general depends on the point $P$.

original.problem: Example 3.27. Find $\frac{d z}{d t}$, if $z=\arcsin \left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)$, where $x=2 t, y=4 t^{2}$.
original.solution:
Solution. The required derivative is found using formula (3.13). We find the necessary partial derivatives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=\frac{2 x}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} ; \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=\frac{2 y}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} \\
\frac{\partial z}{\partial t}=\frac{2 t}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}} ; \frac{d x}{d t}=2 ; \frac{d y}{d t}=8 t
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting into (3.13), we get:

$$
\frac{d z}{d t}=\frac{2 t+2 x \cdot 2+2 y \cdot 8 t}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{2 t\left(1+4 t+32 t^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+t^{2}\right)^{2}}}
$$

original.problem: Example 3.39. Write the equation of the tangent plane and the normal line to the surface $z=2 x^{2}+3 y^{2}$ at the point $M(1,2,14)$.
original.solution:
Solution. The required equations are found using formulas (3.32) and (3.33):

$$
f(x, y)=2 x^{2}+3 y^{2}, f_{x}^{\prime}(M)=4 x=4, f_{y}^{\prime}(M)=6 y=12
$$

The equation of the tangent plane is

$$
z-14=4(x-1)+12(y-2) \Rightarrow 4 x+12 y-z-14=0
$$

The equation of the normal line $\frac{x-1}{4}=\frac{y-2}{12}=\frac{z}{-1}$.

original.problem:
Example 3.41. Find the stationary points of the following functions:

1) $f(x, y)=(x-3)^{2}+(y-2)^{2}$
2) $f(x, y, z)=x^{2}+4 y^{2}+9 z^{2}-4 x+16 y+18 z+1$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Find the partial derivatives $f_{x}^{\prime}=2(x-3)$; $f_{y}^{\prime}=2(y-2)$. Setting the partial derivatives to zero, we get the system of equations: $x-3=0$ and $y-2=0$. From this, it follows that $x=3, y=2$. Thus, the stationary point is $(3,2)$. The partial derivatives are

$$
f_{x}^{\prime}=2 x-4, f_{y}^{\prime}=8 y-16, f_{z}^{\prime}=18 z+18
$$

Stationary points are found from the condition that the partial derivatives are equal to zero, leading to the following system of equations: $2 x-4=0, 8 y-16=0, 18 z+18=0$. From which it follows that $x=2, y=2, z=-1$. The stationary point is $(2,2,-1)$.

## Sufficient Conditions for Extremum

Let the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be defined and have continuous second-order partial derivatives in some neighborhood of the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$, which is a stationary point of the function $f$. Then, if the quadratic form (second differential)

$$
\Phi\left(d x_{1}, d x_{2}, \ldots, d x_{n}\right)=\sum_{i, j=1}^{n} f_{x_{2} x_{j}}^{\prime \prime}\left(P_{0}\right) d x_{i} d x_{j}
$$

is positive definite (negative definite) at the point $P_{0}$, then the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ has a minimum (maximum) at the point. If the quadratic form $\Phi$ takes both positive and negative values (i.e., is indefinite), then there is no extremum at the point $P_{0}$.

Remark. The quadratic form $\Phi$ is called positive (negative) definite if for any point $P\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots, z_{n}\right) \in E^{n}$, it holds that $\Phi\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)>0$ $(\Phi<0)$.

Remark. The quadratic form $\Phi$ is positive definite if and only if all the leading principal minors of the matrix of the quadratic form are positive, i.e., $\Delta_{1}>0, \Delta_{2}>0, \ldots, \Delta_{n}>0$.

Remark. If the signs of the leading principal minors alternate starting with a negative, i.e., $\Delta_{1}<0, \Delta_{2}>0, \Delta_{3}<0, \ldots$, then the quadratic form is negative definite.

For a function of two variables, the following criteria can be used to determine the nature of the stationary point:

1) minimum, if $\Delta>0, A>0$ (or $C>0$);
2) maximum, if $\Delta>0, A<0$ (or $C<0$);
3) no extremum, if $\Delta<0$;
4) the question is open, further investigation is required, if $\Delta=0$. Here $\Delta=A \cdot C-B^{2}, A=f_{x x}^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, $B=f_{x y}^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right), C=f_{y y}^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$.

The first part of the problem, where stationary points are computed through differentiation, clearly falls under straightforward derivative computations. However, the second part involves sufficient conditions for extremum that rely on the positive definiteness of a quadratic form and is more theoretical. Although it requires understanding properties related to stationary points, it doesn't involve directly verifying or proving properties in a way that would be formally verifiable via coding.

**EASY**: The initial derivative computations to find stationary points are straightforward. However, there is a portion of the problem that might make it seem more involved. But since we can derive the necessary conditions from the derivatives directly without additional theoretical groundwork in this case, it retains its classification.

original.problem: Example 4.27. Investigate the power series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(x+2)^{n}}{n^{n}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. We apply the Cauchy formula (Theorem 4.23) to determine the radius of convergence $R$:

$$
R=\frac{1}{\varlimsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt[n]{\frac{1}{n^{n}}}}=\frac{1}{\varlimsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n}}=+\infty
$$

This result means that the power series converges for all values of $x$.

The classification for this problem is:

EASY

Justification: The task is primarily to apply the Cauchy formula to compute the radius of convergence, which is a straightforward calculation involving limits.

original.problem: Example 7. Find the first few terms of the expansion in a power series of the function $f(z)=\operatorname{tg} z$ and find the radius of convergence of the series.
original.solution:
Solution. Let the desired series have the form

$$
f(z)=c_{0}+c_{1} z+c_{2} z^{2}+c_{3} z^{3}+\ldots
$$

where

$$
c_{n}=\frac{f^{(n)}(0)}{n!} \quad(n=0,1,2, \ldots), \quad f^{(0)}(0)=f(0)=0
$$

To find the values of the derivatives $f^{(n)}(z)$ at the point $z=0$, we differentiate the given function. We have

$$
\begin{gathered}
f^{\prime}(z)=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} z} \text { or } f^{\prime}(z)=1+f^{2}(z) \\
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
f^{\prime \prime}(z)=2 f(z) f^{\prime}(z) \\
f^{\prime \prime \prime}(z)=2\left[f^{\prime 2}(z)+f(z) f^{\prime \prime}(z)\right] \\
f^{\prime V}(z)=2\left[3 f^{\prime}(z) f^{\prime \prime}(z)+f(z) f^{\prime \prime \prime}(z)\right] \\
f^{\mathrm{V}}(z)=2\left[3 f^{\prime \prime 2}(z)+4 f^{\prime}(z) f^{\prime \prime \prime}(z)+f(z) f^{\prime V}(z)\right] \\
\ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots
\end{array}\right.
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting $z=0$ into (13) and (14), we find

$$
f^{\prime}(0)=1 ; \quad f^{\prime \prime}(0)=0 ; \quad f^{\prime \prime \prime}(0)=2 ; \quad f^{\prime v}(0)=0 ; \quad f^{V}(0)=16
$$

Substituting the found values of the derivatives into the series, we get

$$
\operatorname{tg} z=z+\frac{2}{3!} z^{3}+\frac{16}{5!} z^{5}+\ldots
$$

The nearest singular point to the point $z=0$ is the point $\zeta=\frac{\pi}{2}$. Therefore, the radius of convergence of the obtained series is $R=\frac{\pi}{2}$.

## Problems for Independent Solution

In the following problems, expand the given functions into Taylor series using ready-made expansions, and find the radii of convergence of the series:

210. $\sin (2 z+1)$ in powers of $z+1$.

214. $\frac{z+1}{z^{2}+4 z-5}$ in powers of $z$.

216. $\cos ^{2} \frac{i z}{2}$ in powers of $z$.
217. $\operatorname{sh}^{2} \frac{z}{2}$ in powers of $z$.
218. $\ln (2-z)$ in powers of $z$.
219. $\ln \left(2+z-z^{2}\right)$ in powers of $z$.

Find the first few terms of the expansion in a series in powers of $z$ of the following functions. Find the radii of convergence of the series:
220. $\frac{1}{1+\mathrm{e}^{2}}$.

222. $\frac{1}{e^{-x}+5}$.
223. $\ln \left(1+e^{-3}\right)$.

225. Find the function $f(z)$, analytic in the disk $|z| \leqslant 1$ and taking on the circle $|z|=1$ the value

$$
\frac{a-\cos \theta+i \sin \theta}{a^{2}-2 a \cos \theta+1}, \quad a>1, \quad \theta=\arg z
$$

228. Let the function $f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_{k} z^{k}$ be analytic in the disk $|z| \leqslant 1$. Prove that the average value of the function $\frac{f(z)}{z^{n}}$ on the circle $|z|=1$ is $a_{n}$.

Let the series be given

$$
\frac{c_{-1}}{z-z_{0}}+\frac{c_{-2}}{\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{2}}+\ldots+\frac{c_{-n}}{\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{n}}+\ldots=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{c_{-n}}{\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{n}}
$$

If $c_{-n} \neq 0$ and there exists a finite limit

$$
r=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left|c_{-n-1}\right|}{\left|c_{-n}\right|}
$$

then this series converges in the region

$$
\left|z-z_{0}\right|>r
$$

original.problem:
Example 9. Find the residue of the function

$$
f(z)=e^{1 / z^{2}} \cos z
$$

at the point $z=0$.
original.solution:

## § 11. The Residue Theorem of Cauchy. Application of Residues to the Evaluation of Definite Integrals. Summation of Some Series Using Residues

## $1^{\circ}$. The Residue Theorem of Cauchy.

Theorem. If the function $f(z)$ is analytic on the boundary $C$ of the region $D$ and everywhere inside the region, except for a finite number of singular points $z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots, z_{n}$, then

$$
\int_{C} f(z) d z=2 \pi i \sum_{k=1}^{n} \operatorname{res} f\left(z_{k}\right)
$$

original.problem: Example 6. Find $\int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $I=\int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x$; as above, after applying the integration by parts formula twice, we will form an equation to find $I$. We have:

$$
\begin{gathered}
I=\int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
e^{\alpha x}=u, & d u=\alpha e^{\alpha x} d x \\
\sin \beta x d x=d v, & v=-\frac{1}{\beta} \cos \beta x
\end{array}\right\}= \\
=-\frac{e^{\alpha x}}{\beta} \cos \beta x+\frac{\alpha}{\beta} \int e^{\alpha x} \cos \beta x d x=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
e^{\alpha x}=u, d u=\alpha e^{\alpha x} \\
\cos \beta x d x=d v, \quad v=\frac{1}{\beta} \sin \beta x
\end{array}\right\}= \\
=-\frac{e^{\alpha x}}{\beta} \cos \beta x+\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\left[\frac{1}{\beta} e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x-\frac{\alpha}{\beta} \int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x\right]= \\
=\frac{-\beta \cos \beta x+\alpha \sin \beta x}{\beta^{2}} \cdot e^{\alpha x}-\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\beta^{2}} I
\end{gathered}
$$

From the obtained equality, we find

$$
\int e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x d x=\frac{\alpha \sin \beta x-\beta \cos \beta x}{\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}} e^{\alpha x}+C
$$

Note the correct, sequential notations (in both cases $e^{\alpha x}=u$, although $e^{\alpha x} d x=d v$ could have been used) and that after the second integration, we obtained an integral similar to the one we are looking for.

Integration by parts can be used to integrate expressions containing high powers of the variable or certain irrationalities.

original.problem: Example 4. Find $\int \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}} d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let the required integral be denoted by $I$ and use the integration by parts formula to form an equation in terms of $I$. We proceed as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
I= & \int \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}} d x=\left\{\begin{aligned}
\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}=u, & d u=\frac{x}{\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}} d x \\
d x=d v, & v=x
\end{aligned}\right\}= \\
& =x \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}-\int \frac{x^{2}+a^{2}-a^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}} d x=x \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}-\int \frac{x^{2}+a^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}} d x+ \\
& +a^{2} \int \frac{d x}{\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}}=x \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}-\int \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}} d x+a^{2} \ln \left|x+\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

In the numerator of one of the fractions, we added and subtracted $a^{2}$, and in the last equality, the middle term is $I$.

Clearly, the equation in terms of the original integral, which was mentioned at the beginning of the solution, is $I=A-I$, where $A$ contains two terms. From this, we obtain the value of the original integral.

$$
\int \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}} d x=\frac{1}{2} x \sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{a^{2}}{2} \ln \left|x+\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}\right|+C
$$

Note the technique of adding and subtracting a certain quantity (here $a^{2}$) to transform the integrand.

Solution. We are dealing with case 1); $m=3$ - an odd number. Let $\sin x=u$ and bring $\cos x$ under the differential sign, since $\cos x d x=d(\sin x)$. We have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \sin ^{4} x\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right) \cos x d x=\int & u^{4}\left(1-u^{2}\right) d u= \\
& =\frac{u^{5}}{5}-\frac{u^{7}}{7}+C=\frac{1}{5} \sin ^{5} x-\frac{1}{7} \sin ^{7} x+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem: Example 8 (to $5^{\circ}$ ). Find $\int \frac{d x}{\sin ^{2} x+4 \cos ^{2} x}$.
original.solution:
Solution. It seems that the universal substitution $\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}=t$ is theoretically acceptable. Let's try to save on transformations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{d x}{\sin ^{2} x+4 \cos ^{2} x}=\int \frac{1}{\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\cos ^{2} x}+4} \cdot \frac{d x}{\cos ^{2} x}=\int \frac{d(\operatorname{tg} x)}{\operatorname{tg}^{2} x+4}=\{u=\operatorname{tg} x\}= \\
& =\int \frac{d u}{u^{2}+4}=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{arctg} \frac{u}{2}+C=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{arctg} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x}{2}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

## § 6. Integration of Hyperbolic Functions

$1^{\circ}$ Hyperbolic functions are defined by the equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{sh} x & =\frac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}-\text { hyperbolic sine, } \\
\operatorname{ch} x & =\frac{e^{x}+e^{-x}}{2}-\text { hyperbolic cosine, } \\
\operatorname{th} x & =\frac{\operatorname{sh} x}{\operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{e^{x}+e^{-x}}-\text { hyperbolic tangent, } \\
\operatorname{cth} x & =\frac{\operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{sh} x}=\frac{e^{x}+e^{-x}}{e^{x}-e^{-x}}-\text { hyperbolic cotangent }
\end{aligned}
$$

Tabular integrals containing hyperbolic functions are listed in the right column of the general table (§ 1.3).

$2^{\circ}$. The integration of expressions containing hyperbolic functions can be performed analogously to trigonometric expressions due to the following formulas:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { 1) } \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-\operatorname{sh}^{2} x=1, & \text { 2) } \operatorname{sh}^{2} x=\frac{\operatorname{ch} 2 x-1}{2} \\
\text { 3) } \operatorname{ch}^{2} x=\frac{\operatorname{ch} 2 x+1}{2}, & \text { 4) } \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x=\frac{\operatorname{sh} 2 x}{2}
\end{array}
$$

$3^{\circ}$ Integrals containing hyperbolic functions can also be considered as integrals of rational functions of the variable $u=e^{x} \cdot \int R\left(e^{x}\right) d x$

original.problem: Example 8. Find $\int \sqrt{x}(5-3 \sqrt[3]{x})^{2} d x$.
original.solution:
Solution. We have $m=\frac{1}{2}, n=\frac{1}{3}, p=2$. Let's make the first Chebyshev substitution $x=t^{6}$, or $t=\sqrt[6]{x}$. From here $\sqrt{x}=t^{3}, 5-3 \sqrt[3]{x}=$ $=5-3 t^{2}, d x=6 t^{5}$ Substituting into the desired integral, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \sqrt{x}(5-3 \sqrt[3]{x})^{2} d x=\int t^{3}\left(5-3 t^{2}\right)^{2} \cdot 6 t^{5} d t= \\
& =6 \int\left(25 t^{8}-30 t^{10}+9 t^{12}\right) d t=\frac{50}{3} t^{9}-\frac{180}{11} t^{11}+\frac{54}{13} t^{13}+C= \\
& =\frac{50}{3} \cdot x \sqrt{x}-\frac{180}{11} x \sqrt[6]{x^{5}}+\frac{54}{13} x^{2} \sqrt[6]{x}+C .
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem: Example 1. Solve the differential equation $2 x d x-\frac{d y}{\cos ^{2} y}=$ $=0$. Also find the particular solution satisfying the initial condition $y=0$ when $x=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. We have the equation with separated variables: $\frac{d y}{\cos ^{2} y}=2 x d x$. We integrate each part by its own variable: $\int \frac{d y}{\cos ^{2} y}=\int 2 x d x$, i.e., $\operatorname{tg} y=x^{2}+C$. We have obtained the general integral, or the general solution in implicit form. From this, we get the solution in explicit form: $y=\operatorname{arctg}\left(x^{2}+C\right)$ (we do not consider the periodicity of the tangent). Substituting here (or into the general integral) $x=0, y=0$ and determine the value of the constant $C: 0=\operatorname{arctg} C$ (or $0=0+C$). We get $C=0$ and substitute this value into the general solution. The desired particular solution has the form $y=\operatorname{arctg} x^{2}$.

Answer. $y=\operatorname{arctg}\left(x^{2}+C\right) ; y=\operatorname{arctg} x^{2}$.

original.problem: Example 1. Solve the equation $y^{IV}=\cos x$.
original.solution:
Solution. The equation belongs to type 1). Integrating:

$$
y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\int \cos x d x, \text { i.e. } y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\sin x+C_{1}
$$

Integrate again: $y^{\prime \prime}=-\cos x+C_{1} x+C_{2}$. Next, by analogy:

$$
y^{\prime}=-\sin x+C_{1} \frac{x^{2}}{2}+C_{2} x+C_{3}
$$

The last integration leads to the answer (find it yourself).

Answer. $y=\cos x+C_{1} \frac{x^{3}}{6}+C_{2} \frac{x^{2}}{2}+C_{3} x+C_{4}$.

Note. The products (quotients from division) of constants by numbers are also constants, so the previous answer can be written in a more convenient form: $y=\cos x+C_{1} x^{3}+C_{2} x^{2}+C_{3} x+$ $+C_{4}$.

original.problem: Example 1. Expand the function $f(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}$ into a Taylor series in powers of: a) $x-1$, b) $x$, c) $x+1$.
original.solution:
Solution. a) Expansion in a series of powers of $(x-1)$ is impossible, since $f(x)$ is not defined at the point $x=1$. In other words, a series of powers of $(x-1)$ for this function does not exist.

Cases b) and c) will be considered together. Expansion in powers of $x$ and $(x+1)$ is possible, because $f(x)$ is infinitely differentiable in the neighborhoods of the points $x=0$ and $x=-1$.

The coefficients of the expansions are given in Theorem 18. First, we compute the general derivatives of all orders.

$$
\begin{gathered}
f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{(1-x)^{2}}, f^{\prime \prime}(x)=\frac{2}{(1-x)^{3}}, f^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=\frac{2 \cdot 3}{(1-x)^{3}} \\
f^{I V}(x)=\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4}{(1-x)^{4}}, \ldots, f^{(n)}(x)=\frac{1 \cdot 2 \cdot \ldots \cdot n}{(1-x)^{n}}=\frac{n!}{(1-x)^{n}}, \ldots
\end{gathered}
$$

It remains to substitute $x=0$ or $x=-1$ and divide the results by the corresponding factorial.

b) $c_{0}=1, c_{1}=1, c_{2}=\frac{2}{2}=1, c_{3}=\frac{3!}{3!}=1, \ldots, c_{n}=\frac{n!}{n!}=1, \ldots$, and

$$
\frac{1}{1-x}=1+x+x^{2}+x^{3}+\ldots+x^{n}+\ldots \quad(|x|<1)
$$

The convergence condition $|x|<1$ is related to the fact that the radius of convergence for the obtained series is 1 (verify this!).

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { c) } c_{0}=\frac{1}{2}, c_{1}=\frac{1}{2^{2}}, c_{2}=\frac{1}{2^{3}}, \ldots, c_{n}=\frac{1}{2^{n+1}}, \ldots, \text { and } \\
& \frac{1}{1-x}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2^{2}}(x+1)+\frac{1}{2^{3}}(x+1)^{2}+\ldots+\frac{1}{2^{n+1}}(x+1)^{n}+\ldots \\
& (|x+1|<2)
\end{aligned}
$$

The radius of convergence for this series is 2 (obtain this!).

Note. Clearly, the form of the series depends not only on the function itself but also on the center of the series.

llm_response:
This problem involves expanding the function \( f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} \) into Taylor series around different centers. While the initial part assesses the ability to expand \( f(x) \) around \( x-1 \) (which cannot be done due to the function's singularity at that point), the following parts (b and c) require computation of derivatives and then using those to form the Taylor series around \( x \) and \( x+1 \). 

The main actions in the solution revolve around executing straightforward computations (derivatives and summing series), albeit the reasoning regarding the center also plays a role in understanding the convergence.

Since the problem ultimately boils down to a computation (derivatives and Taylor series) that is clearly presented, it classifies as:

**EASY**

original.problem:
Example. Compute the limit

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The numerator $n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}$ is an infinitely large sequence of order $n^{2}$, and the denominator $(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}$ is an infinitely large sequence of order $n^{2}$.

1. Factor out $n^{2}$ in the numerator, we get

$$
n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}=n^{2}\left(\frac{1}{n^{5 / 6}}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+\frac{1}{n^{10}}}\right)
$$

2. Factor out $n^{2}$ in the denominator, we get

$$
(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}=n^{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{3 / 4}}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-\frac{1}{n^{3}}}
$$

3. We have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{2}\left(1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}\right)}{n^{2}\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}
$$

4. Canceling $n^{2}$ and using theorems about limits, we finally get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}}{\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}= \\
&=\frac{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}\right)}{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

NOTE. In this case, the property of the root was used, according to which $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}=1$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}=1$.

$$
\text { Answer. } \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=2
$$

Conditions of the Problems. Calculate the limit.

1. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[3]{3 n^{2}}+\sqrt[4]{4 n^{8}+1}}{(n+\sqrt{n}) \sqrt{7-n+n^{2}}}$.
2. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n-1}-\sqrt{2 n^{2}+3}}{\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+3}+\sqrt[4]{n^{5}+2}}$.
3. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{2 n^{3}+3}-\sqrt{n+5}}{\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+2}-\sqrt{n-1}}$.
4. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[3]{n^{2}+3}+3 n^{3}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{12}+2 n+1}-n^{2}}$.
5. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{3 n+2}-\sqrt[3]{125 n^{3}+n}}{\sqrt[5]{n}+n^{2}}$.
6. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt{n}-\sqrt[3]{27 n^{6}+n^{4}}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt{4+n^{2}}}$.
7. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt{n^{2}+2}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{4}+1}-\sqrt[3]{n^{2}-1}}$.
8. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n^{5}+3}+\sqrt{n-2}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{4}+2}-\sqrt{n-2}}$.
9. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{10 n^{3}-\sqrt{n^{3}+2}}{\sqrt{4 n^{6}+3}-n}$.
10. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt[3]{8 n^{3}+3}}{\sqrt[4]{n+5}+n}$.

Answers. 1. $\sqrt{2}$. 2.0.3. $+\infty .4$. 3. 5.5. 6. -3. 7. -1 . 8. $+\infty$. 9.5. 10. -2 .

## 3.4. Calculation of $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]$

Problem Statement. Calculate the limit of the sequence

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]
$$

where $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} u(n)=1$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} v(n)=\infty$.

## Plan of Solution.

1. Transform the expression under the limit so that we can use the second remarkable limit, i.e., factor out the one:

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left((1+\alpha(n))^{1 / \alpha(n)}\right)^{\alpha(n) v(n)}
$$

where $\alpha(n)=u(n)-1$ is an infinitesimal sequence as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Since $\alpha(n) \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(1+\alpha(n))^{1 / \alpha(n)}=e
$$

2. If $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}=a\left(a_{n}>0, a>0\right)$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} b_{n}=b$, then

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}^{b_{n}}=a^{b}
$$

Therefore, if the limit

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \alpha(n) v(n)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(u(n)-1) v(n)
$$

exists, then we finally have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]=e^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(u(n)-1) v(n)}
$$

original.problem:
Example. Compute the limit

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[3]{x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)+8 \cos x}
$$
original.solution:
Solution.

1. Since the function $y=\sqrt[3]{x}$ is continuous for all $x$, by passing to the limit under the sign of a continuous function, we get

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[3]{x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)+8 \cos x}=\sqrt[3]{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left[x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)+8 \cos x\right]}
$$

2. Since $x$ is an infinitesimal function at the point $x=0$, and $2+\sin (1 / x)$ is a bounded function in the neighborhood of the point $x=0$, then $x(2+\sin (1 / x))$ is an infinitesimal function at the point $x=0$, i.e.,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)=0
$$

3. Since $\cos x$ is continuous at the point $x=0$, then

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \cos x=1
$$

and, using the properties of the limit of a function at a point, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[3]{x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)+8 \cos x}=\sqrt[3]{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x\left(2+\sin \frac{1}{x}\right)+8 \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \cos x}=2 \\
& \text { Answer. } \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[3]{x\left(2+\sin \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)\right)+8 \cos x}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

Conditions of the Problems. Calculate the limit.

1. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt{9 \cos 2 x+2 x \operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{x}}$.
2. $\lim _{x \rightarrow \pi / 2} \sqrt{4 \sin x+(2 x-\pi) \sin \frac{x^{2}}{2 x-\pi}}$.

6. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \ln \left[\left(e^{x^{3}}-\cos x\right) \cos \frac{2}{x}+\operatorname{tg}\left(x+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right]$.
7. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt{4 \sin x+\left(e^{\sin ^{2} x}-1\right) \cos \frac{1}{x}}$.

## DIFFERENTIATION

In the study of the topic DIFFERENTIATION, you will become familiar with the concepts of the derivative and differential of a function of one variable through examples, learn to compute derivatives using the rules of differentiation for sums, products, quotients, and composite functions, learn to differentiate functions given parametrically, compute higher-order derivatives, and apply derivatives and differentials in approximate calculations and in solving geometric problems.

Using the package SOLVER.CA, you can compute limits, perform numerical calculations, and compute derivatives of any order to verify the correctness of the results you obtain.

## 4.1. The Concept of a Derivative

Problem Statement. Find the derivative of the function $f(x)$ at the point $x=0$ based on the definition.

Plan of Solution.

1. By definition,

$$
f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)-f(0)}{x}
$$

(Recall that when computing the limit $x \rightarrow 0$, but $x \neq 0$.)

2. Compute the limit

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)-f(0)}{x}
$$

3. If the limit exists and equals $A$, then $f^{\prime}(0)=A$; if the limit does not exist, then $f^{\prime}(0)$ does not exist.

The given problem involves computing a limit using properties of the continuity of functions and the behavior of functions as they approach certain points. The solution involves a straightforward evaluation of this limit using standard limit properties without delving into any proving of properties or existence. 

Thus, based on the clarity of the solution being straightforward and limited to computation and not requiring any deeper properties or abstract arguments that would typically classify it as hard:

**EASY**

original.problem:
Example. Compute the limit

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x+18}{x^{3}-5 x^{2}+3 x+9}
$$
original.solution:
Solution.

1. The expression under the limit sign (a rational fraction) is the ratio of two infinitesimal functions as $x \rightarrow 3$.

Factorize the numerator and the denominator:

$$
\frac{x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x+18}{x^{3}-5 x^{2}+3 x+9}=\frac{(x-3)^{2}(x+2)}{(x-3)^{2}(x+1)}
$$

2. Since in the definition of the limit of a function as $x \rightarrow 3$, the argument cannot take the value 3, we can cancel the factor $(x-3)^{2}$. We get

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x+18}{x^{3}-5 x^{2}+3 x+9}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{x+2}{x+1}=\frac{5}{4}
$$

Answer. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x+18}{x^{3}-5 x^{2}+3 x+9}=\frac{5}{4}$.

Conditions of the Problems. Calculate the limit.

1. $\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}+3 x^{2}+7 x+5}{x^{2}-x-2}$.
2. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{2}-2 x+1}{2 x^{2}+x-3}$.
3. $\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}+4 x^{2}+5 x+2}{x^{2}+2 x+1}$.
4. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \frac{x^{3}-6 x^{2}+12 x-8}{x^{3}-2 x^{2}+2 x-4}$.
5. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{3}-1}{2 x^{2}-x-1}$.
6. $\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}+x^{2}-x-1}{x^{3}-3 x-2}$.
7. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{4}-1}{x^{4}-x^{3}+x-1}$.
8. $\lim _{x \rightarrow-3} \frac{x^{2}+2 x-3}{x^{3}+5 x^{2}+6 x}$.
9. $\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{4}+x^{3}+2 x+2}{x^{2}-1}$.
10. $\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \frac{x^{3}-x^{2}-x-2}{x^{3}-2 x^{2}+x-2}$.

Answers. 1. 0. 2. 2/3. 3. 0. 4. 2. 5. 1. 6. $-4 / 3$. 7. 0. 8. $-1 / 2$. 9. $1.10 .7 / 3$.

## 3.8. Calculation of $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}[f(x) / g(x)]$

Problem Statement. Calculate the limit

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}
$$

where $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are infinitesimal functions at the point $x=0$.

Solution Plan. The infinitesimal functions in the numerator and the denominator can be replaced by their equivalent (tabular) functions.

If $f(x), f_{1}(x), g(x), g_{1}(x)$ are infinitesimal functions at the point $x=0$ such that $f(x) \sim f_{1}(x)$ and $g(x) \sim g_{1}(x)$ at the point $x=0$, and $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} f_{1}(x) / g_{1}(x)$ exists, then $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} f(x) / g(x)$ exists, and

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f_{1}(x)}{g_{1}(x)}
$$

original.problem:
Example. Find the equations of the tangent and normal to the curve

$$
y=6 \sqrt[3]{x}-\frac{16}{3} \sqrt[4]{x}
$$

at the point with abscissa $a=1$.
original.solution:
Solution.

1. Find $f(1)=2 / 3$.
2. Find the derivative $f^{\prime}(1)=2 / 3$. Since $f^{\prime}(1) \neq 0$ and $f^{\prime}(1) \neq \infty$, we will use equations (1) and (2).
3. Substituting the found values $f(a)=2 / 3$ and $f^{\prime}(a)=2 / 3$ into (1) and (2), we get the equations of the tangent and normal:

$$
y=\frac{2}{3}+\frac{2}{3}(x-1), \quad y=\frac{2}{3}-\frac{3}{2}(x-1)
$$

Answer. Equation of the tangent: $2 x-3 y=0$. Equation of the normal: $9 x+6 y-13=0$.

Conditions of the Problem. Form the equations of the tangent and normal to the graph of the function $y=f(x)$ at the point with abscissa $a$.

1. $y=x-x^{2}, \quad a=1$.
2. $y=x^{2}+x+1, \quad a=-1$.
3. $y=x^{3}+x, \quad a=1$.
4. $y=\sqrt{x}-2, \quad a=4$.
5. $y=x^{2}+\sqrt{x^{3}}, \quad a=1$.
6. $y=\sqrt[3]{x^{2}}-9, \quad a=-27$.
7. $y=\frac{2+\sqrt{x}}{2-\sqrt{x}}, \quad a=9$.
8. $y=32 \sqrt[4]{x}-x, \quad a=16$.
9. $y=x^{2}-x-1, \quad a=1$.
10. $y=\frac{x^{2}-2 x+2}{x^{2}}, \quad a=2$.

Answers. 1. $x+y-1=0, x-y-1=0$. 2. $x+y=0, x-y-2=0$. 3. $4 x-y-2=0, \quad x+4 y-9=0$. 4. $x-4 y-4=0, \quad 4 x+y-16=0$. 5. $7 x-2 y-3=0,2 x+7 y-16=0$. 6. $2 x+9 y+54=0,9 x-2 y+243=0$. 7. $2 x-3 y-33=0, \quad 3 x+2 y-17=0$. 8. $y-48=0, \quad x-16=0$. 9. $x-y-2=0, \quad x+y=0 . \quad 10.2 y-1=0, \quad x-2=0$.

## 4.4. Approximate Calculations Using the Differential

Problem Statement. Calculate approximately using $\partial$ and $\emptyset$ differential the value of the function $y=f(x)$ at the point $x=a$.

Solution Plan. If the increment $\Delta x=x-a$ of the argument $x$ is small in absolute value, then

$$
f(x)=f(a+\Delta x) \approx f(a)+f^{\prime}(a) \Delta x
$$

1. Choose the point $a$ closest to $x$ and such that the values of $f(a)$ and $f^{\prime}(a)$ are easy to compute.
2. Calculate $\Delta x=x-a, f(a)$, and $f^{\prime}(a)$.
3. Using formula (1), calculate $f(x)$.

original.problem:
Example. Find the derivative of the function $y=x^{e^{x}} x^{9}$.

---

Translation:
Example. Find the derivative of the function $y=x^{e^{x}} x^{9}$.
original.solution:
Solution.

1. The logarithm of the given function is

$$
\ln y=\ln \left(x^{e^{x}} x^{9}\right)=e^{x} \ln x+9 \ln x
$$

2. Differentiating both sides of this equation, we get

$$
\frac{y^{\prime}}{y}=e^{x} \ln x+e^{x} \frac{1}{x}+\frac{9}{x}
$$

Therefore,

$$
y^{\prime}=y\left(e^{x} \ln x+\frac{e^{x}+9}{x}\right)
$$

3. Substituting the expression for $y$ into the last equation, we get the answer.

Answer. $y^{\prime}=x^{e^{x}} x^{9}\left(e^{x} \cdot \ln x+\frac{e^{x}+9}{x}\right)$.

Conditions of the Problems. Find the derivatives of the given functions.

1. $y=(\sin x)^{\sqrt{x}}$.
2. $y=x^{x} 3^{\sqrt{x}}$.
3. $y=x^{e^{\sqrt{x}}}$.
4. $y=(\operatorname{arctg} x)^{x}$.
5. $y=(\operatorname{tg} x)^{\ln x}$.
6. $y=x^{\sqrt{x}} 2^{\sin x}$.
7. $y=x^{2^{\cos x}}$.
8. $y=x^{\operatorname{tg} x}$.
9. $\quad y=(\sin 3 x)^{\ln \sin 3 x}$.
10. $y=x^{2^{x}} 3^{x}$.

## Answers.

1. $y^{\prime}=y\left(\frac{\ln \sin x}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{\sqrt{x} \cos x}{\sin x}\right)$.
2. $y^{\prime}=y\left(\ln x+1+\frac{\ln 3}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right)$.
3. $y^{\prime}=y e^{\sqrt{x}}\left(\frac{\ln x}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{x}\right)$.
4. $y^{\prime}=y\left[\ln \operatorname{arctg} x+\frac{x}{\left(1+x^{2}\right) \operatorname{arctg} x}\right]$.
5. $y^{\prime}=y\left(\frac{\ln \operatorname{tg} x}{x}+\frac{\ln x}{\sin x \cos x}\right)$.
6. $y^{\prime}=y\left(\frac{\ln x}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}+\cos x \ln 2\right)$.
7. $y^{\prime}=y 2^{\cos x}\left(-\sin x \ln 2+\frac{1}{x}\right)$.
8. $y^{\prime}=y\left(\frac{\ln x}{\cos ^{2} x}+\frac{\operatorname{tg} x}{x}\right)$.

## 4.6. Derivative of a function given parametrically

Problem Statement. Find the derivative of the function given parametrically.

Solution Plan. If the dependence of $y$ on $x$ is given through a parameter $t$:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=f(t) \\
y=g(t)
\end{array}\right.
$$

then the dependence of $y^{\prime}$ on $x$ is given through the parameter $t$ by the formulas

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=f(t) \\
y^{\prime}=\frac{g^{\prime}(t)}{f^{\prime}(t)}
\end{array}\right.
$$

We compute $f^{\prime}(t)$ and $g^{\prime}(t)$, substitute into formula (1), and write the answer.

llm_response:
The problem is primarily about finding the derivative of a complicated function involving exponentials and logarithmic expressions. The solution involves differentiating a product of functions and applying the logarithmic differentiation technique.

Justification: The problem statement straightforwardly asks for the derivative of a specified function, which can be computed directly by following standard differentiation rules. This falls into the category of simply computing derivatives.

Classification: EASY

Example. Find the equations of the tangent and normal to the curve

at the point \( A \), corresponding to the parameter value \( t=0 \).
original.solution:
SOLUTION.

1. We calculate the coordinates of point $A: a=2, y(a)=1$.
2. We find the derivative $y^{\prime}$ at point $A$:

$$
f^{\prime}(0)=\left.2 e^{t}\right|_{t=0}=2, \quad g^{\prime}(0)=-\left.e^{-t}\right|_{t=0}=-1 \Rightarrow y^{\prime}(0)=\frac{g^{\prime}(0)}{f^{\prime}(0)}=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

Since $f^{\prime}(0) \neq 0$ and $f^{\prime}(0) \neq \infty$, we can use equations (1) and (2).

3. We substitute the obtained values into the equation of the tangent (1):

$$
y=1-\frac{1}{2}(x-2)
$$

and the normal (2):

$$
y=1+2(x-2)
$$

Answer. The equation of the tangent: $x+2 y-4=0$. The equation of the normal: $2 x-y-3=0$.

PROBLEM STATEMENT. Form the equations of the tangent and normal $\kappa$ to the graphs of functions given parametrically.

9. $2 x+y-2=0, \quad x-2 y+4=0$.
10. $4 x-4 y-\pi \sqrt{2}=0, \quad x+y-\sqrt{2}=0$.

## 4.8. Higher Order Derivatives

PROBLEM STATEMENT. Find the $n$-th order derivative of the function $y=f(x)$.

## PLAN OF SOLUTION.

The $n$-th order derivative of the function $y=f(x)$ is the derivative of the $(n-1)$-th order derivative, i.e.,

$$
y^{(n)}(x)=y^{(n-1)}(x)^{\prime}
$$

1. We differentiate the function $y=f(x)$ several times in succession until the formula for the $n$-th order derivative becomes clear.
2. We prove this formula by mathematical induction. For this, we check that it is valid for $n=1$, i.e., it gives the correct value of $f^{\prime}$, and that differentiating the expression for $f^{(n)}$ is equivalent to replacing $n$ with $n+1$.

original.problem:
Example. Find the $n$-th order derivative of the function $y=3^{2 x+5}$.






The above text has been translated into English, preserving the original text's line breaks and format.
original.solution:
Solution.

1. Let's find sequentially

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}(x)=\left(3^{2 x+1}\right)^{\prime}=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3) 2 \\
& y^{\prime \prime}(x)=y^{\prime}(x)^{\prime}=\left(3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3) 2\right)^{\prime}=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{2} 2^{2} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=y^{\prime \prime}(x)^{\prime}=\left(3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{2} 2^{2}\right)^{\prime}=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{3} 2^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Analyzing these expressions, we hypothesize that

$$
y^{(n)}(x)=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{n} 2^{n}
$$

2. We will prove this formula by mathematical induction. First, check that it holds for $n=1$; i.e.,

$$
y^{(1)}(x)=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3) 2=y^{\prime}(x)
$$

Differentiating $f^{(n)}$ is equivalent to replacing $n$ with $n+1$, i.e.,

$$
y^{(n)}(x)^{\prime}=\left(3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{n} 2^{n}\right)^{\prime}=3^{2 x+1}(\ln 3)^{n+1} 2^{n+1}=y^{(n+1)}(x)
$$

Answer. $y^{(n)}(x)=3^{2 x+1}(2 \ln 3)^{n}$.

Conditions of the Problems. Find the $n$-th order derivatives of the given functions.

1. $y=\sin 2 x+\cos 3 x$. 2. $y=\sin (3 x+1)+\cos 2 x$. 3. $y=2^{3 x}$.
2. $y=\ln (2 x+4)$.
3. $y=\frac{x}{x+1}$.
4. $y=\frac{x+1}{2 x+3}$.
5. $y=3^{2 x+1}$.
6. $y=\ln (3 x+1)$.
7. $y=5^{2 x+4}$.
8. $y=\sqrt{x}$.

## Answers.

1. $y^{(n)}=2^{n} \sin \left(2 x+\frac{n \pi}{2}\right)+3^{n} \cos \left(3 x+\frac{n \pi}{2}\right)$.
2. $y^{(n)}=3^{n} \sin \left(3 x+1+\frac{n \pi}{2}\right)+2^{n} \cos \left(2 x+\frac{n \pi}{2}\right)$.
3. $y^{(n)}=2^{3 x}(3 \ln 2)^{n} . \quad$ 4. $y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} 2^{n}(n-1)!}{(2 x+4)^{n}}$.
4. $y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} n!}{(x+1)^{n+1}}$.
5. $y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} 2^{n-1} n!}{(2 x+3)^{n+1}}$.
6. $y^{(n)}=3^{2 x+1}(2 \ln 3)^{n}$.
7. $y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} 3^{n}(n-1)!}{(3 x+1)^{n}}$.
8. $y^{(n)}=5^{2 x+4}(2 \ln 5)^{n}$.
9. $y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1}\left(2^{n}-3\right)!!}{2^{n}(\sqrt{x})^{2 n-1}}$.

## 4.9. Leibniz's Formula

Problem Statement. Find the $n$-th order derivative of the function $y=u(x) v(x)$.

Plan of Solution. If the functions $u(x)$ and $v(x)$ have derivatives up to the $n$-th order inclusive, then the following formulas are valid:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (u v)^{\prime \prime}=u^{\prime \prime} v+2 u^{\prime} v^{\prime}+u v^{\prime \prime} \\
& (u v)^{\prime \prime \prime}=u^{\prime \prime \prime} v+3 u^{\prime \prime} v^{\prime}+3 u^{\prime} v^{\prime \prime}+u v^{\prime \prime \prime} \\
& (u v)^{(4)}=u^{(4)} v+4 u^{\prime \prime \prime} v^{\prime}+6 u^{\prime \prime} v^{\prime \prime}+4 u^{\prime} v^{\prime \prime \prime}+u v^{(4)}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
(u v)^{(n)}=u^{(n)} v+n u^{(n-1)} v^{\prime}+\frac{n(n-1)}{1 \cdot 2} & u^{(n-2)} v^{\prime \prime}+\ldots+u v^{(n)}= \\
= & \sum_{k=0}^{n} C_{n}^{k} u^{(n-k)} v^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $u^{(0)}=u, v^{(0)}=v$ and $C_{n}^{k}=\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$ are binomial coefficients.

The formula (1) for the $n$-th derivative of a product is called Leibniz's formula.

Consequently, to determine the $n$-th order derivative of a function of the form $y=u(x) v(x)$, we need to compute all derivatives (up to the $n$-th order inclusive) of each of the functions $u(x)$ and $v(x)$, the binomial coefficients $C_{n}^{k}$, and use Leibniz's formula.

original.problem:
Example. Find the derivative of the function

$$
y=\frac{3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2}{15 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution.

1. The function $y(x)$ has the form

$$
\frac{1}{15} \frac{u}{v}
$$

where $u(x)=3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2$ and $v(x)=\sqrt{1+x^{2}}$. Using the formula for the derivative of a quotient, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{15} \frac{\left(3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2\right)^{\prime} \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-\left(3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2\right)\left(\sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{\prime}}{\left(\sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

2. The function $u(x)=3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2$ is a linear combination of tabular functions. Therefore,

$$
\left(3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2\right)^{\prime}=18 x^{5}+16 x^{3}-2 x
$$

3. The function $v(x)=\sqrt{1+x^{2}}$ has the form

$$
v(x)=u_{1}\left(v_{1}(x)\right)
$$

where $u_{1}=\sqrt{v_{1}}$ and $v_{1}(x)=1+x^{2}$. Using the formula for the derivative of a composite function, we get

$$
v^{\prime}(x)=\left(\sqrt{v_{1}}\right)^{\prime}\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{v_{1}}} 2 x=\frac{2 x}{2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}}
$$

Answer. $y_{1}=$

$$
=\frac{1}{15} \frac{\left(18 x^{5}+16 x^{3}-2 x\right) \sqrt{1+x^{2}}-\left(3 x^{6}+4 x^{4}-x^{2}-2\right) \frac{2 x}{2 \sqrt{1+x^{2}}}}{1+x^{2}} .
$$

Conditions of the problems. Find the derivatives of the given functions.

1. $y=2^{\sqrt{\operatorname{tg} x}}$.
2. $y=\ln \left(x+\sqrt{1+x^{2}}\right)$.
3. $y=\ln ^{2}(1-\cos x)$.
4. $y=\ln (\arcsin \sqrt{x})$
5. $y=\frac{3^{x}(\sin x+\cos x \ln 3)}{1+\ln ^{2} 3}$.
6. $y=\frac{\operatorname{sh} 2 x}{\operatorname{ch}^{2} 2 x}$.
7. $y=\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}$.
8. $y=\operatorname{arctg} 3^{\sqrt{x}}$.
9. $y=\ln (1+\sqrt{\operatorname{th} x})$.
10. $y=\ln \sin 3-\frac{\cos ^{2} x}{\sin x}$.

Answers. 1. $2^{\sqrt{\operatorname{tg}} x} \frac{\ln 2}{2 \cos ^{2} x \sqrt{\operatorname{tg} x}} \cdot$ 2. $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^{2}}} \cdot 3 . \frac{2 \sin x \ln (1-\cos x)}{1-\cos x}$.
4. $\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x-x^{2}} \arcsin \sqrt{x}}$.
5. $3^{x} \cos x$
6. $\frac{2 \operatorname{ch}^{2} 2 x-4 \operatorname{sh}^{2} 2 x}{\operatorname{ch}^{3} 2 x}$
7. $-\frac{1}{2 x \sqrt{x-1}}$.
8. $\frac{3^{\sqrt{x}} \ln 2}{\left(1+3^{2 \sqrt{x}}\right) 2 \sqrt{x}}$.
9. $\frac{1}{2(\operatorname{th} x+\sqrt{\operatorname{th}} x) \operatorname{ch}^{2} x}$.
10. $\frac{\cos x\left(1+\sin ^{2} x\right)}{\sin ^{2} x}$.

## 4.3. Equation of the Tangent and Normal

Problem Statement. Form the equations of the tangent and normal to the curve $y=f(x)$ at the point with abscissa $a$.

Solution Plan. If the function $f(x)$ has a finite derivative at the point $a$, then the equation of the tangent is

$$
y=f(a)+f^{\prime}(a)(x-a)
$$

If $f^{\prime}(a)=\infty$, then the equation of the tangent is $x=a$.

If $f^{\prime}(a) \neq 0$, then the equation of the normal is

$$
y=f(a)-\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(a)}(x-a)
$$

If $f^{\prime}(a)=0$, then the equation of the normal is $x=a$.

1. Find the value $f(a)$.

Example. Find the fourth-order derivative of the function

$$
y=\left(x^{3}+2\right) e^{4 x+3}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution.

1. We apply Leibniz's formula (1). In this case,

$$
n=4, \quad u(x)=x^{3}+2, \quad v(x)=e^{4 x+3}
$$

We have

$$
\begin{gathered}
u^{\prime}(x)=3 x^{2}, \quad u^{\prime \prime}(x)=6 x, \quad u^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=6, \quad u^{(4)}(x)=0 \\
v^{\prime}(x)=4 e^{4 x+3}, \quad v^{\prime \prime}(x)=4^{2} e^{4 x+3}, \quad v^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=4^{3} e^{4 x+3}, \quad v^{(4)}(x)=4^{4} e^{4 x+3}
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting the obtained results into formula (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\mathrm{iv}}=\left(\left(x^{3}+2\right) e^{4 x+3}\right)^{(4)}=0 \cdot e^{4 x+3}+4 \cdot 6 \cdot 4 \cdot e^{4 x+3}+ \\
&+\frac{4 \cdot 3}{1 \cdot 2}(6 x) 4^{2} e^{4 x+3}+\frac{4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3}\left(3 x^{2}\right) 4^{3} e^{4 x+3}+\frac{4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4}\left(x^{3}+2\right) 4^{4} e^{4 x+3}= \\
&= 32 e^{4 x+3}\left(8 x^{3}+24 x^{2}+18 x+19\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer. $y^{(4)}=32 e^{4 x+3}\left(8 x^{3}+24 x^{2}+18 x+19\right)$.

8. $y^{\prime \prime \prime}=-8 \cos 2 x \ln x-\frac{6 \cos 2 x}{x^{2}}-\frac{\left(12 x^{2}-2\right) \sin 2 x}{x^{3}}$.
9. $y^{(5)}=32 e^{2 x+1}\left(x^{2}+5 x+6\right)$.
10. $y^{(4)}=3^{3 x+2} \ln 3\left[\left(9 x^{3}+18\right) \ln ^{3} 3+36 x^{2} \ln ^{2} 3+36 x \ln 3+8\right]$.

### 4.10. Second Derivative of a Function Given Parametrically

Problem Statement. Find the second-order derivative of a function given parametrically.

Solution Plan. If the function is given parametrically:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=f(t) \\
y=g(t)
\end{array}\right.
$$

then its first derivative is determined by the formulas

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=f(t) \\
y^{\prime}=\frac{g^{\prime}(t)}{f^{\prime}(t)}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Differentiating $y^{\prime}$ with respect to $x$ as a composite function of $x$ and using the formula for the derivative of the inverse function, we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=f(t) \\
y^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{g^{\prime}(t)}{f^{\prime}(t)}\right)^{\prime} \cdot \frac{1}{f^{\prime}(t)}
\end{array}\right.
$$

original.solution:
## Solution.

1. We compute

$$
\frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{1}{t}, \quad \frac{d y}{d t}=\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}
$$

and substitute these values into formula (1):

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}

\end{array}\right.
$$

Differentiating $y^{\prime}$ with respect to $x$ as a composite function of $x$ and using the formula for the derivative of the inverse function, we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\ln t \\
y^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{\prime} \cdot t=\frac{t\left(1-t^{2}\right)}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Answer. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\ln t, \\ y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{t\left(1-t^{2}\right)}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}} .\end{array}\right.$
