Solution. 1) Assuming $y=u^{3}$, where $u=1+5 x$, and applying the rule of differentiation of a composite function, we get:

$$
\frac{d y}{d u}=3 u^{2} ; \quad \frac{d u}{d \bar{x}}=5 ; \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d y}{d u} \cdot \frac{d u}{d x}=3 u^{2} \cdot 5=15(1+5 x)^{2}
$$

It is easy to verify the correctness of this result: by cubing and differentiating the resulting polynomial, we arrive at the same answer.

2) Assuming $5 x=u$ and using formulas 6 and $3 \mathrm{a}$, we find

$$
y^{\prime}=(\sin 5 x)^{\prime}=(\sin u)^{\prime}=\cos u \cdot u^{\prime}=5 \cos 5 x
$$

3) Assuming $\cos x=u$ and applying formulas 5 and 7, we get

$$
y^{\prime}=\left(\cos ^{2} x\right)^{\prime}=\left(u^{2}\right)^{\prime}=2 u \cdot u^{\prime}=2 \cos x(-\sin x)=-\sin 2 x
$$

4) For $x^{2}=u$, using formulas 6 and 5, we find

$$
\left(\sin x^{2}\right)^{\prime}=(\sin u)^{\prime}=\cos u \cdot u^{\prime}=2 x \cos x^{2}
$$

5) Assuming $2+x^{4}=u$, and using formula 5, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\sqrt[3]{2+x^{4}}\right)^{\prime}=(\sqrt[3]{u})^{\prime}=\left(u^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{3} u^{-\frac{2}{3}} u^{\prime}= \\
=\frac{1}{3}\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}} \cdot 4 x^{3}=\frac{4 x^{3}}{3 \sqrt[3]{\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{2}}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Differentiation of this composite function can also be written differently:

$\left(\sqrt[3]{2+x^{4}}\right)^{\prime}=\left[\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right]^{\prime}=\frac{1}{3}\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{4 x^{3}}{3 \sqrt[3]{\left(2+x^{4}\right)^{2}}}$.

127. Find the derivative of the given function and then calculate its particular value at the specified argument value:
1) $F(x)=\frac{(1-\sqrt{\bar{x}})^{2}}{x}, \quad x=0.01$
2) $z=\frac{\cos t}{1-\sin t}, \quad t=\frac{\pi}{6}$
3) $y=\frac{a+b}{3-2 x}+\frac{5 x^{4}-1}{a-b}, x=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) First, we expand the brackets and perform the division, then differentiate:

$$
\begin{gathered}
F(x)=\frac{1-2 V x+x}{x}=\frac{1}{x}-\frac{2}{V x}+1=x^{-1}-2 x^{-\frac{1}{2}}+1 \\
F^{\prime}(x)=-x^{-2}-2\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) x^{-\frac{3}{2}}=-\frac{1}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x^{3}}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting the value \( x=0.01 \), we get

$$
F^{\prime}(0.01)=-\frac{1}{0.01^{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.01^{3}}}=-100^{2}+10^{3}=-9000
$$

2) Using formula 4, we find

$$
\begin{gathered}
z^{\prime}=\frac{(\cos t)^{\prime}(1-\sin t)-\cos t(1-\sin t)^{\prime}}{(1-\sin t)^{2}}= \\
=\frac{-\sin t(1-\sin t)-\cos t(-\cos t)}{(1-\sin t)^{2}}=\frac{-\sin t+\sin ^{2} t+\cos ^{2} t}{(1-\sin t)^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-\sin t}
\end{gathered}
$$

Assuming \( t=\frac{\pi}{6} \), we get \( z^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=\frac{1}{1-0.5}=2 \).

3) Applying formulas 46 and 4a, we get

$$
y^{\prime}=-\frac{(a+b)(3-2 x)}{\left.1^{2}-2 x\right)^{2}}+\frac{\left(5 x^{4}-1\right)^{\prime}}{a-b}=\frac{2(a+b)}{(3-2 x)^{2}}+\frac{20 x^{3}}{a-b}
$$

At \( x=0 \), we find \( y^{\prime}(0)=\frac{2}{9}(a+b) \).

232. 

$$

x=k \sin t+\sin k t \\
y=k \cos t+\cos k t ;\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)_{t=0} ?
\end{array}\right.
$$

What is the geometric meaning of the result?
2) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\alpha^{2}+2 \alpha \\ y=\ln (\alpha+1) ; \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} ?\end{array}\right.$

original.solution:
Solution. 1) We find the derivatives of $x$ and $y$ with respect to the parameter $t$:

$$
\frac{d x}{d t}=k \cos t+k \cos k t ; \quad \frac{d y}{d t}=-k \sin t-k \sin k t
$$

The desired derivative of $y$ with respect to $x$ is found as the ratio of the derivatives of $y$ and $x$ with respect to $t$:

$\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\frac{d y}{d t}}{\frac{d x}{d t}}=-\frac{k(\sin t+\sin k t)}{k(\cos t+\cos k t)}=-\frac{2 \sin \frac{t+k t}{2} \cos \frac{t-k t}{2}}{2 \cos \frac{t+k t}{2} \cos \frac{t-k t}{2}}=-\operatorname{tg} \frac{k+1}{2} t$.

At $t=0$, we get $\frac{d y}{d x}=0$. According to the geometric meaning of the derivative (§ 1), at the point $(0 ; k+1)$, where $t=0$, the tangent to the graph of the given function is parallel to the $O x$ axis.

2) We find the derivatives of $x$ and $y$ with respect to the parameter $\alpha$:

$$
\frac{d x}{d a}=2 \alpha+2 ; \frac{d y}{d \alpha}=\frac{1}{\alpha+1}
$$

and the desired derivative of $y$ with respect to $x$:

$$
y^{\prime}=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d y}{d \alpha}: \frac{d x}{d \alpha}=\frac{1}{2(\alpha+1)^{2}}=\frac{1}{2}(\alpha+1)^{-2}
$$

Next, we find the derivative of $y^{\prime}$ with respect to $\alpha$, and then the desired second derivative of $y$ with respect to $x$ as the ratio of the derivatives of $y^{\prime}$ and $x$ with respect to $\alpha$:

$$
\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d \alpha}=-(\alpha+1)^{-3} ; \quad y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d x}=\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d \alpha}: \frac{d x}{d \alpha}=\frac{-(\alpha+1)^{-3}}{2(\alpha+1)}=-\frac{1}{2(\alpha+1)^{4}}
$$

3) Using the general formulas (A) for the derivatives of a function given parametrically, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d y}{d \varphi}: \frac{d x}{d \varphi}=\frac{a-a e^{-a \varphi}}{a e^{a \varphi}}=e^{-a \varphi}-e^{-2 \alpha \varphi} ; \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d x}=\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d \varphi}: \frac{d x}{d \varphi}=\frac{2 a e^{-2 a \varphi}-a e^{-\alpha \varphi}}{a e^{a \varphi}}=2 e^{-3 a \varphi}-e^{-2 a \varphi} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\frac{d y^{\prime \prime}}{d x}=\frac{d y^{\prime \prime}}{d \varphi}: \frac{d x}{d \varphi}=\frac{2 a e^{-2 a \varphi}-6 a e^{-3 a^{\prime} \varphi}}{a e^{a \varphi}}=2 e^{-3 a \varphi}-6 e^{-4 a \varphi} \\
& \text { 233. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=t^{2} \\
y=t^{3} ; \frac{d y}{d x}
\end{array}\right. \\
& \text { 234. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\frac{3 a t}{1+t^{3}} \\
y=\frac{3 a t^{2}}{1+t^{3}} ; \frac{d y}{d x} ?
\end{array}\right. \\
& \text { 235. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=a \cos t \\
y=a \sin t ; \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} ?
\end{array}\right. \\
& \text { 236. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p=\cos \alpha+\alpha \sin \alpha \\
q=\sin \alpha-\alpha \cos \alpha ; \frac{d^{2} q}{d p^{2}} ?
\end{array}\right. \\
& \text { 237. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=z^{2} \\
y=z^{3}+z ;\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right)_{z=1}
\end{array}\right\} \\

x=a \cos ^{3} t \\
y=a \sin ^{3} t
\end{array}\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right)_{t=\frac{\pi}{6}} ?\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

## § 11. Tangent and Normal to a Plane Curve. Angle Between Two Curves

If a plane curve is referred to a rectangular coordinate system (Fig. 33), then the equations of the tangent and normal to it at the point $M\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ are:

$$
y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right) ; \quad y-y_{0}=-\frac{1}{y_{0}^{\prime}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)
$$

where $y_{0}^{\prime}$ is the value at the point $x_{0}$ of the derivative $\frac{d y}{d x}$ from the equation of the curve.

The direction of the curve at each of its points is determined by the direction of the tangent to it at that point. The angle between two intersecting curves is defined as the angle between two lines tangent to the curves at their point of intersection (Fig. 34) by the formula

$$
\operatorname{tg} \varphi=\frac{k_{1}-k_{2}}{1+k_{1} k_{2}}
$$

where $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ are the slopes of the tangents to the curves at their point of intersection $P\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, i.e., the particular values at the point $x_{0}$ of the derivatives of $y$ with respect to $x$ from the equations of these curves:

$$
k_{1}=\operatorname{tg} \alpha_{1}=\left(\frac{d y_{1}}{d x}\right)_{x=x_{0}} ; k_{2}=\operatorname{tg} \alpha_{2}=\left(\frac{d y_{2}}{d x}\right)_{x=x_{0}}
$$

original.solution:
Solution. 1) Applying formulas 5 and 2, we find

$$
z^{\prime}=k\left(3 a x-x^{2}\right)^{k-1} \cdot\left(3 a x-x^{2}\right)^{\prime}=k(3 a-2 x)\left(3 a x-x^{2}\right)^{k-1}
$$

2) Using formulas 5 and 6:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\beta^{\prime}=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(\sin \frac{\alpha}{3}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \cdot\left(\sin \frac{\alpha}{3}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\sin \frac{\alpha}{3}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \cdot \cos \frac{\alpha}{3} \cdot\left(\frac{\alpha}{3}\right)^{\prime}= \\
=\frac{\cos \frac{\alpha}{3}}{3 \sqrt{\sin \frac{\alpha}{3}}}
\end{gathered}
$$

3) Applying formulas 5 and 4:

$$
s^{\prime}=10\left(\frac{t}{2 t+1}\right)^{8} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot(2 t+1)-2 \cdot t}{(2 t+1)^{2}}=\frac{10 t^{9}}{(2 t+1)^{11}}
$$

At $t=-1$ we get $s^{\prime}(-1)=10$.

4) First, we write the given function in the form

$$
r=(\sin 2 \varphi)^{3}-(\cos 2 \varphi)^{3}
$$

which is always useful when differentiating powers of trigonometric functions.

Using formulas $2,5,6$ and 7, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
r^{\prime}=3(\sin 2 \varphi)^{2}(\sin 2 \varphi)^{\prime}-3(\cos 2 \varphi)^{2}(\cos 2 \varphi)^{\prime}= \\
=3 \sin ^{2} 2 \varphi \cdot 2 \cos 2 \varphi-3 \cos ^{2} 2 \varphi \cdot(-2 \sin 2 \varphi)= \\
=3 \sin 4 \varphi(\sin 2 \varphi+\cos 2 \varphi)
\end{gathered}
$$

At $\varphi=\frac{\pi}{8}$ we find $r^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{8}\right)=3 \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\left(\sin \frac{\pi}{4}+\cos \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \approx 3 \sqrt{2}$.

original.solution:
Solution. 1) Substituting the given abscissa of the point of tangency \(x=1\) into the equation of the parabola, we find its ordinate \(y=-3\).

To determine the slope of the tangent \(y_{0}^{\prime}\), we find the derivative of \(y\) with respect to \(x\) from the equation of the parabola and compute its value at the point \(x=1\):

\[
y^{\prime}=2 x-4 ; y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}(1)=-2
\]

Substituting the values of \(x_{0}\), \(y_{0}\), and \(y_{0}^{\prime}\) into the general equations (I), we obtain the equation of the tangent

\[
y+3=-2(x-1) \text { or } 2 x+y+1=0
\]

and the equation of the normal

\[
y+3=\frac{1}{2}(x-1) \text { or } x-2 y-7=0 \text {. }
\]

The parabola, tangent, and normal are plotted in Fig. 35.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-080.jpg?height=272&width=244&top_left_y=1453&top_left_x=236)

Fig. 36

2) Solving the given equation of the circle and the equation of the \(O x\) axis \(y=0\) simultaneously, we find the points of their intersection: \(A(-1, 0)\), \(B(3, 0)\) (Fig. 36). Differentiating the equation of the circle with respect to \(x\), \(2 x+2 y y^{\prime}-2+4 y^{\prime}=0\), we find the derivative \(y^{\prime}=\frac{1-x}{2+y}\) and compute its values for points \(A\) and \(B: y_{A}^{\prime}=1, y_{B}^{\prime}=-1\).

Substituting into the general equations (1), we obtain the required equations of the tangents and normals:

for point \(A\), respectively, \(x-y+1=0\) and \(x+y+1=0\);

for point \(B\), \(x+y-3=0\) and \(x-y-3=0\).

3) Substituting \(t=\frac{\pi}{2}\) into the parametric equations of the cycloid, we find the coordinates of the point of tangency: \(x=\frac{\pi}{2}-1 ; y=1\).

Then we determine the derivative of \(y\) with respect to \(x\) from the parametric equations of the cycloid, as for a function given parametrically:

\[
y^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{d y}{d t}}{\frac{d x}{d t}}=\frac{\sin t}{1-\cos t}=\frac{2 \sin \frac{t}{2} \cos \frac{t}{2}}{2 \sin ^{2} \frac{t}{2}}=\operatorname{ctg} \frac{t}{2}
\]

and compute its value for the point of tangency \(\dot{y}_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=1\). Substituting \(x_{0}\), \(y_{0}\), and \(\dot{y}_{0}^{\prime}\) into the equations (1), we obtain the equation of the tangent \(2 x-2 y-\pi+4=0\) and the equation of the normal \(2 x+2 y-\pi=0\).

4)* We find the derivative \(y^{\prime}\) and then the angular point of the given curve from the condition that for this point the derivative \(y^{\prime}\) does not exist, but one-sided derivatives do exist:

\[
y^{\prime}=\left|x^{3}-1\right|^{\prime}= \pm 3 x^{2}
\]

where the plus sign corresponds to the interval \(x>1\), where \(x^{3}-1>0\), and the minus sign to the interval \(x<1\), where \(x^{3}-1<0\).

From this, we conclude that the point where \(x=1\) is an angular point; at this point, the curve has two one-sided tangents with slopes

\[
k_{1}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow-0} \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=y_{(-1}^{\prime} \quad(1)=-3 \text { and } k_{2}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow+0} \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=y_{(+)}^{\prime} \quad(1)=3
\]

Using the general equations (1), we obtain the equations of the tangents \(3 x-y-3=0\) and \(3 x+y-3=0\) and the equations of the normals \(x+3 y-1=0\) and \(x-3 y-1=0\) (Fig. 37).

original.solution:

1) $d y=y^{\prime} d x=\left(x^{3}-3^{x}\right)^{\prime} d x=\left(3 x^{2}-3^{x} \ln 3\right) d x$;
2) $d F(\varphi)=d\left(\cos \frac{\varphi}{3}+\sin \frac{3}{\varphi}\right)=\left(\cos \frac{\varphi}{3}+\sin \frac{3}{\varphi}\right)^{\prime} d \varphi=$ $=\left[-\sin \frac{\varphi}{3} \cdot\left(\frac{\varphi}{3}\right)^{\prime}+\cos \frac{3}{\varphi} \cdot\left(\frac{3}{\varphi}\right)^{\prime}\right] d \varphi=-\left(\frac{1}{3} \sin \frac{\varphi}{3}+\frac{3}{\varphi^{2}} \cos \frac{3}{\varphi}\right) d \varphi ;$
3) $d z=\left[\frac{\left(1+e^{10 x}\right)^{\prime}}{1+e^{10 x}}-\frac{\left(e^{6 x}\right)^{\prime}}{1+e^{10 x}}\right] d x=\left(\frac{10 e^{10 x}}{1+e^{10 x}}-\frac{5 e^{6 x}}{1+e^{10 x}}\right) d x=$

$$
=\frac{5 e^{5 x}\left(2 e^{5 x}-1\right)}{1+e^{10 x}} d x
$$

Assuming $x=0$ and $d x=0.1$, we get $d z=0.25$.

original.problem: 265. A point performs a straight-line oscillatory motion according to the law $x=A \sin \omega t$. original.solution:
Solution. Let's find the velocity $v$ and the acceleration of the motion at any moment of time $t$:

$$
v=\frac{d x}{d t}=A \omega \cos \omega t ; \quad \omega=\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=-A \omega^{2} \sin \omega t
$$

At $t=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}, v=A \omega, \tau=0$.

By comparing the expressions for the acceleration and the displacement $x$, we see that the former differs from the latter only by a constant factor: $w=-\omega^{2} x$.

original.problem: 287. Find the equation of the tangent to the helical line $y=a \cos t$, $y=a \sin t, z=b t$ at the point where $t=t_{0}$, and the angle it forms with the $O z$ axis.
original.solution:
Solution. Denoting the coordinates of the point of tangency ( $x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}$ ) and using the general equations (1), we obtain the following equations of the tangent:

$$
\frac{x-x_{0}}{-a \sin t_{0}}=\frac{y-y_{0}}{a \cos t_{0}}=\frac{z-z_{0}}{b}
$$

From here, the directional cosine of the angle formed by the tangent with the $O z$ axis:

$$
\cos \gamma=\frac{\dot{z}}{\sqrt{\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}}}=\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2} \sin ^{2} t_{0}+a^{2}}}=\frac{b}{\cos ^{2} t_{0}+b^{2}}=\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
$$

This result shows that all tangents to the helical line form the same angle with the $O z$ axis.[^10]

2) $\lim _{x \rightarrow a} \frac{x^{\prime n}-a^{\prime n}}{x^{n}-a^{\prime h}}=\lim \frac{m \cdot x^{m-1}}{n x^{n-1}}=-\frac{m}{n} a^{m-n}$
3) $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{2 x}-1}{\sin x}=\lim \frac{2 e^{2 x}}{\cos x}=\frac{2}{1}=2$
4) $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos a x}{1-\cos b x}=\lim \frac{a \sin a x}{b \sin b x}=\lim \frac{a^{2} \cos a x}{b^{2} \cos b . y}=\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}$.

Here L'Hôpital's rule is applied twice.
5) $\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{e^{k x}}{x^{n}}=\lim \frac{k e^{k x}}{n x^{n-1}}=\lim \frac{k^{2} e^{k x}}{n(n-1) x^{1,-x}=}=$

$$
=\ldots=\lim \frac{\ln ^{n} e^{i x}}{n!}=-\infty
$$

Here L'Hôpital's rule is applied $n$ times.
6) $\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}}{\sec x}=\lim \frac{\sec ^{-1} x}{\sec x \operatorname{tg} x}=\lim \frac{\sec x}{\lg x}=\lim \frac{\operatorname{tg} x}{\sec }=\ldots$

Here the application of L'Hôpital's rule is useless. The limit can easily be found without this rule by elementary transformations:

$$
\lim _{\pi} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x}{\sec x}=\lim \frac{\sin x \cos x}{\cos x}=1 \text{ and } \ln \sin x-1
$$

7) $\lim _{x \rightarrow a} \frac{x-\sin x}{x-\sin x}=\lim \frac{1-\cos x}{1+\cos x}$.

Here the application of L'Hôpital's rule is useless, because the ratio of derivatives $\frac{1-\cos x}{1+\cos x}=\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{x}{2}$ does not have a limit as $x \rightarrow \infty$. The desired limit can be found by elementary means:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x-\sin x}{x+\sin x}=\lim \frac{1-\frac{\sin x}{x}}{1+\frac{\sin x}{x}}=1, \text{ since }|\sin x| \leqslant 1
$$

This does not contradict L'Hôpital's theorem, which only states that if the ratio of derivatives tends to a limit, then the ratio of functions tends to the same limit, but not vice versa.

original.problem: 411. Find the curvature of the curve: 1) $x=t^{2}, y=2 t^{3}$ at the point where $t=1$; 2) $y=\cos 2 x$ at the point where $x=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) We find the derivatives $\dot{x}=2 t, \ddot{x}=2, \dot{y}=6 t^{2}$, $\ddot{y}=12 t$, and compute their values at the point where $t=1$:

$$
\dot{x}=2, \ddot{x}=2, \dot{y}=6, \ddot{y}=12
$$

and, substituting into formula (1), we get

$$
K=\frac{|\ddot{x} \ddot{y}-\ddot{y} x|}{\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}=\frac{2 \cdot 12-0.2}{\left(2^{2}+6^{2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}=\frac{3}{20 \sqrt{10}}
$$

2) From the given equation, we find the first and second derivatives of $y$ with respect to $x$:

$$
y^{\prime}=-2 \sin 2 x, y^{\prime \prime}=-4 \cos 2 x
$$

we compute their values at the given point: $y^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=0, y^{\prime \prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=4$ and, substituting into formula (1), we get $K=\frac{\left|y^{\prime \prime}\right|}{\left[1+\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]^{\frac{3}{2}}}=4$.

EASY

original.problem: 412. Determine the radii of curvature at the vertices of the ellipse $x=a \cos t, y=b \sin t$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's find the derivatives $\dot{x}=-a \sin t, \ddot{x}=-a \cos t$, $\dot{y}=b \cos t, \ddot{y}=-b \sin t$ and determine the radius of curvature of the ellipse at any of its points:

$$
R(t)=\frac{1}{K(t)}=\frac{\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{|\dddot{x} \ddot{y}-\dot{y}| \dot{x} \mid}=\frac{\left(a^{2} \sin ^{2} t+b^{2} \cos ^{2} t\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{a b}
$$

For the vertices of the ellipse lying on its axis $2 a$, the parameter $t$ is 0 or $\pi$. Therefore, the radius of curvature of the ellipse at these vertices $R(0)=R(\pi)=\frac{b^{2}}{a}$.

At the other two vertices of the ellipse, lying on the axis $2 b$, $t=\frac{\pi}{2}$ or $t=\frac{3 \pi}{2}$. At these vertices, the radius of curvature of the ellipse $R\left(\frac{\pi \pi}{2}\right)=R\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)=\frac{a^{2}}{b}$.

EASY

original.solution:
Solution.

1) $\int \frac{d x}{\sqrt[3]{5 x}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{5}} \int x^{-\frac{1}{3}} d x=\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{5}} \cdot \frac{3}{2} x^{\frac{2}{3}}+C=$ $=\frac{3}{2 \sqrt[3]{5} 5} \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}+C$, according to property III and formula 1, when $u=x, a=-\frac{1}{3}$.

3) We multiply and divide the integral by 3 and bring the factor 3 under the integral sign (according to property III), then under the differential sign:

$$
\int \cos 3 \varphi d \varphi=\frac{1}{3} \int \cos 3 \varphi d(3 \varphi)=\frac{1}{3} \sin 3 \varphi+C

by formula 5, when $u=3 \varphi$.

$$

by formula 3, when $u=-\frac{x}{2}$.

5) Multiplying and dividing by $a$ and noting that $a d x=d(a x+b)$, we get

$\int \sin (a x+b) d x=\frac{1}{a} \int \sin (a x+b) d(a x+b)=-\frac{1}{a} \cos (a x+b)+C$, by formula 4, when $u=a x+b$.

6) Multiplying and dividing by 5, we get:

$$
\int \frac{1}{5 x+4} d x=\frac{1}{5} \int \frac{5}{5 x+4} d x=\frac{1}{5} \ln |5 x+4|+C
$$

by formula 2, when $u=5 x+4 ; u^{\prime}=5$.

This integral can also be found differently:

$$
\int \frac{1}{5 x+4} d x=\frac{1}{5} \int \frac{1}{x+\frac{4}{5}} d x=\frac{1}{5} \ln \left|x+\frac{4}{5}\right|+C
$$

by formula 2, when $u=x+\frac{4}{5}, u^{\prime}=1$.

Both results obtained are correct, which can be verified by differentiating them.

2) $\int \frac{\ln x}{x^{3}} d x$

original.solution:
Solution. 1) Let $u=x, d v=\cos x d x$, then we find: $d u=d x$, $v=\int \cos x d x=\sin x$. Substituting into formula (*), we get $\int x \cos x d x=x \sin x-\int \sin x d x=x \sin x+\cos x+C$.

2) Let $u=\ln x, d v=\frac{d x}{x^{3}}$, then $d u=\frac{d x}{x}, v=\int \frac{d x}{x^{3}}=$ $=\int x^{-3} d x=-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}$. Substituting into formula (*), we find $\int \frac{\ln x}{x^{3}} d x=-\frac{\ln x}{2 x^{2}}-\int-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}} \cdot \frac{d x}{x}=-\frac{\ln x}{2 x^{2}}-\frac{1}{4 x^{2}}+C=C-\frac{1+2 \ln x}{4 x^{2}}$.
3) Let $u=\operatorname{arctg} x, d v=x d x$, then $d u=\frac{d x}{1+x^{2}}, v=\int x d x=$ $=\frac{x^{2}}{2}$. By formula (*), we get

$$
I=\int x \operatorname{arctg} x d x=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \operatorname{arctg} x-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{x^{2}}{1+x^{2}} d x
$$

We find the last integral separately:

$$
\int \frac{x^{2}}{1+x^{2}} d x=\int \frac{1+x^{2}-1}{1+x^{2}} d x=\int\left(1-\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}\right) d x=x-\operatorname{arctg} x
$$

Substituting this result into equation (1), we have $I=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \operatorname{arctg} x-\frac{x}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{arctg} x+C=C-\frac{x}{2}+\frac{x^{2}+1}{2} \operatorname{arctg} x$.

4) Let $u=\arcsin x, \quad d v=d x$, then we find: $d u=\frac{d x}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}$, $v=\int d x=x$. By formula (*) we get

$$
J=\int \arcsin x d x=x \arcsin x-\int \frac{x d x}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}
$$

We find the last integral by transforming it to formula 1:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{x d x}{\sqrt{ }} \frac{\overline{1-x^{2}}}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \int\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}(-2 x d x)= \\
= & -\frac{1}{2} \int\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} d\left(1-x^{2}\right)=-\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting into equation (2), we have

$$
J=x \operatorname{arc} \sin x+\sqrt{1-x^{2}}+C
$$

5) Let $u=x^{2}, d v=e^{3 x} d x$, then $d \iota=2 x d x, v=\int e^{3 x} d x=$ $=\frac{1}{3} \int e^{3 x} d(3 x)=\frac{1}{3} e^{3 x}$. By formula (*) we find

$$
I=\int x^{2} e^{3^{x}} d x=\frac{x}{3} e^{3 x}-\frac{2}{3} \int x e^{3 x} d x
$$

We apply the integration by parts formula again to the last integral. Let $u=x, d v=e^{3 x} d x$, then $d u=d x$, $v=\int e^{3 x} d x=\frac{1}{3} e^{3 x}$. By formula (*) we get

$$
\int x e^{3 x} d x=\frac{x}{3} e^{3 x}-\frac{1}{3} \int e^{3 x} d x=\frac{x}{3} e^{3 x}-\frac{1}{9} e^{3 x}
$$

original.problem:
718. Find the partial derivatives of the functions:
1) $z=x^{3}+5 x y^{2}-y^{3}$
2) $u=\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{z}-\frac{z}{x}$
3) $v=\sqrt[x]{e^{y}}$
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Considering $z$ as a function of only one argument $x$, using the formulas from Chapter II, we find $\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=3 x^{2}+5 y^{2}$.

Similarly, considering $z$ as a function of only $y$, we get $\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=$ $=10 x y-3 y^{2}$.

2) Considering $u$ as a function of only $x$, then only $y$, and only $z$, we obtain:

$$
\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}=\frac{1}{y}+\frac{z}{x^{2}} ; \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=-\frac{x}{y^{2}}+\frac{1}{z} ; \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial z}=-\frac{y}{z^{2}}-\frac{1}{x}
$$

3) Replacing the root with a power with a fractional exponent and then differentiating with respect to each of the two variables, we get:

$$
v=e^{\frac{y}{x}} ; \quad v_{x}^{\prime}=-\frac{y}{x^{2}} e^{\frac{y}{x}} ; \quad v_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{x} e^{\frac{y}{x}}
$$

llm_response:
The problem involves finding the partial derivatives of given functions, which is a straightforward computation for each case. The solutions provide explicit derivative calculations for each function as requested.

1) The partial derivatives for the function $z=x^{3}+5 x y^{2}-y^{3}$ are computed directly using the rules of differentiation.
2) The same straightforward application of differentiation is applied to find the partial derivatives of the function $u=\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{z}-\frac{z}{x}$.
3) The function $v=\sqrt[x]{e^{y}}$ is also differentiated using standard differentiation techniques. 

Given that all of these tasks involve direct computation of derivatives, they fit the definition of a straightforward derivative computation.

Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

EASY

original.problem: 730. Calculate the value of the total differential of the function $z=\operatorname{arcctg} \frac{x}{y}$ at $x=1, y=3, d x=0.01, d y=-0.05$.
original.solution:
Solution. We find the partial derivatives, then the partial differentials and the total differential of the given function:

$$
\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=-\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} ; \quad \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} ; \quad d z=\frac{x d y-y d x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
$$

Substituting the given values of the independent variables $x, y$, $d x$ and $d y$, which are functions of the total differential $d z$, we get

$$
d z=\frac{1 \cdot(-0.05)-3 \cdot 0.01}{1+9}=-0.008
$$

llm_response:
The problem involves calculating the total differential of a function by first finding its partial derivatives and then substituting specific values into the total differential formula. The solution relies on performing a straightforward computation using these derivatives, which is characteristic of an easy problem.

Classification: EASY

original.problem: 745. Find the derivative of the implicit function $y$, given by the equation: 1) $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x-6 y+2=0$; 2) $x^{y}=y^{x}$, and calculate its value at $x=1$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Denoting the left-hand side of the given equation by $f(x, y)$, we find the partial derivatives $f_{x}^{\prime}=2 x+2, f_{y}^{\prime}=2 y-6$ and, substituting them into formula (B), we get $y^{\prime}=\frac{x+1}{3-y}$.

Next, substituting $x=1$ into the original equation, we find two corresponding values of the function $y_{1}=1$ and $y_{2}=5$. Therefore, at $x=1$, the derivative has two values: $y_{1}^{\prime}(1)=1, y_{2}^{\prime}(1)=-1$.

2) Transforming the given equation to the form $x^{y}-y^{x}=0$, according to formula (B), we get

$$
\frac{d!y}{d x}=-\frac{\left(x^{y}-y^{x}\right)_{x}^{\prime}}{\left(x^{y}-y^{x}\right)_{!}^{\prime}}=\frac{y^{x} \ln y-y x^{y-1}}{x^{y} \ln x-x y^{x-1}}
$$

When $x=1$, from the given equation we determine $y=-1$. The sought value is $y^{\prime}(1)=1$.

EASY: It involves straightforward derivative computations through implicit differentiation techniques.

original.problem: 849. Compute the triple integral $I=\int_{-1}^{1} d x \int_{x^{2}}^{1} d y \int_{0}^{z}(4+z) d z$ and sketch its region of integration.
original.solution:
Solution. We sequentially compute three ordinary (single) definite integrals, starting with the inner one:

$$
\begin{gathered}
I_{1}=\int_{0}^{2}(4+z) d z=\left.\frac{(4+z)^{2}}{2}\right|_{0} ^{2}=\frac{36-16}{2}=10 \\
I_{2}=\int_{x^{2}}^{1} I_{1} d y=10 \int_{x^{2}}^{1} d y=\left.10 y\right|_{x^{2}} ^{1}=10\left(1-x^{2}\right) ; \\
I_{3}=I=\int_{-1}^{1} I_{2} d x=10 \int_{-1}^{1}\left(1-x^{2}\right) d x=\left.10\left(x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{-1} ^{1}=\frac{40}{3} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Here, as when computing a double integral, a more concise notation can be used:

$$
\begin{gathered}
I=\left.\int_{-1}^{1} d x \int_{x^{2}}^{1} \frac{(4+2)^{2}}{2}\right|_{0} ^{2} d y=10 \int_{-1}^{1} d x \int_{x^{2}}^{1} d y=10 \int_{-1}^{1}\left(1-x^{2}\right) d x= \\
=\left.10\left(x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{-1} ^{1}=\frac{40}{3}
\end{gathered}
$$

To construct the region of integration for this triple integral, we first write the equations of the surfaces that bound this region. By equating the variable of integration of each integral to its limits, we obtain the following equations: $x=-1, x=1, y=x^{2}, y=1, z=0, z=2$.

By plotting in the coordinate system $0 x y z$ the surfaces corresponding to these equations (Fig. 173), we see that the region bounded by them is a right cylinder, the generators of which are parallel to the $0 z$ axis.

original.problem: 884. Find the length of the cardioid $x=2 a \cos t-a \cos 2 t, y=$ $-2 a \sin t-a \sin 2 t$.
original.solution:
Solution. We apply formula (1); based on the given parametric equations of the cardioid and the formula for the differential of the arc of a plane curve (Chapter 5, §), we transform the line integral in formula (1) into an ordinary integral with the variable $t$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\dot{x}=-2 a \sin t+2 a \sin 2 t, \quad \dot{y}=2 a \cos t-2 a \cos 2 t \\
d l=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} d t=4 a \sin \frac{t}{2} d t
\end{gathered}
$$

The cardioid (Fig. 187) is obtained as $t$ varies from 0 to $2 \pi$. Therefore,

$$
L=4 a \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \sin \frac{t}{2} d t=-\left.8 a \cos \frac{t}{2}\right|_{0} ^{2 \pi}=16 a
$$

2) $C=\oint_{A B C A}(x-2) d x+(x+y) d y-2 z d z$.

The perimeter $A B C A$ of the triangle consists of three segments lying on lines with different equations. Therefore, the line integral over the contour $A B C A$ is calculated as the sum of integrals over the segments $A B, B C$, and $C A$.

Formulating the equations of the line $A B: x+y=1, z=0$ and based on these equations, we transform the line integral over the segment $A B$ into an ordinary integral with variable $x$:

$$
\int_{A B}=\int_{1}^{0}(x-3) d x=\left.\frac{(x-3)^{2}}{2}\right|_{1} ^{0}=\frac{5}{2}
$$

For the segment $B C: y+z=1, x=0 ; \int_{B C}=\int_{1}^{0}(2-y) d y=-\frac{3}{2}$.

For the segment $C A: x+z=1, y=0 ; \int_{C A}=-\int_{0}^{1} x d x=-\frac{1}{2}$.

Therefore, $C=\oint_{A B C A}=\oint_{A B}+\oint_{B C}+\int_{C A}=\frac{1}{2}$.
3) $C=\oint_{L} x z d x-y z^{2} d y+x y d z$.

To compute this integral, we transform the given equations of the curve $L$ into parametric equations: assuming $x=a \cos t$, we get $y=a \sin t, z=a^{2}(2+\cos 2 t)$.[^37]

Using these equations, we transform the line integral $C$ into an ordinary integral with variable $t$, then compute it:

$$

-\left.\frac{a^{4}}{2}\left(t-\frac{\sin 4 t}{4}\right)\right|_{0} ^{2 \pi}=-\pi a^{4} .
\end{gathered}
$$

The curl vector of the given field at any point $M(x, y, z)$ is found using formula (2):

$$

$$

At the given point $A\left(0,-a, a^{2}\right)$, rot $q=a j-2 a^{3} i$.

original.problem:
1013. Expand the functions into Taylor series:
1) $\frac{1}{x}$ at $\left.a=-2 ; 2\right) \cos x$ at $a=\frac{\pi}{4}$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) A. We calculate the values of the given function and its derivatives at $x=a:=-2$:

$$
\begin{array}{rl}
f(x)=x^{-1} & f(-2)=-\frac{1}{2} \\
f^{\prime}(x)=-1 \cdot x^{-2} & f^{\prime}(-2)=-\frac{1!}{2^{2}} \\
f^{\prime \prime}(x)=1 \cdot 2 x^{-3} & f^{\prime \prime}(-2)=-\frac{2!}{2^{3}} \\
f^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=-1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 x^{-3} & f^{\prime \prime \prime}(-2)=-\frac{3!}{2^{4}}
\end{array}
$$

$$
f^{(n)}(x)=(-1)^{n} n!x^{-n-1} \quad f^{(n)}(-2)=-\frac{n!}{2^{n+1}}
$$

Substituting these values into the Taylor series (T) for an arbitrary function, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{1}{x}=-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1!(x+2)}{2^{2}} - \frac{2!(x+2)^{2}}{2^{3} 2!}-\frac{3!(x+2)^{3}}{2^{4} 3!}-\ldots-\frac{n!(x+2)^{n}}{2^{n+1} n!}-\ldots \\
\ldots=-\frac{1}{2}\left[1+\frac{x+2}{2}+\frac{(x+2)^{2}}{2^{2}}+\frac{(x+2)^{3}}{2^{3}}+\ldots+\frac{(x+2)^{n}}{2^{n}}+\ldots\right] \\
-350-
\end{gathered}
$$

B) We investigate the convergence of the obtained series using the D'Alembert criterion: $u_{n}=\frac{(x+2)^{n}}{2^{n}} ; \quad u_{n+1}=\frac{(x+2)^{n+1}}{2^{n+1}} ;$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\rho=\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty}\left|\frac{u_{n+1}}{u_{n}}\right|=\frac{|x+2|}{2} ; \\
\rho<1, \text { if } \frac{|x+2|}{2}<1
\end{gathered}
$$

Solving this inequality, we find the interval $-4<x<0$.

We investigate the boundaries of this interval separately. Substituting $x=-4$ and then $x=0$ into the series, we get the numerical series $1-1+1-1+\ldots$ and $1+1+1+1+\ldots$, which diverge because the necessary condition for the convergence of a series $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} a_{n}=0$ is not satisfied.

Therefore, the interval of convergence of the obtained Taylor series for the given function is $(-4 ; 0)$. By investigating the remainder term $R_{n}$ of the Taylor formula for the given function, we can verify that the obtained series converges to the given function in the specified interval.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { 2) A. } y=\cos x \\
& y\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\
& y^{\prime}=-\sin x=\cos \left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \quad y^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=-\cos x=\cos \left(x+2 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \quad y^{\prime \prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\sin x=\cos \left(x+3 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \quad y^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\
& y^{(n)}=\cos \left(x+n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \quad y^{(n)}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}+n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) \\
& \cos x=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\left[1-\frac{x-\frac{\pi}{4}}{1!}-\frac{\left(x-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{2}}{2!}+\frac{\left(x-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{3}}{3!}+\ldots\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

B. We investigate the corresponding remainder term $R_{n}$ of the Taylor formula:

$$
R_{n}=\frac{\left(x-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{n+1}}{(n+1)!} \cos \left[\frac{\pi}{4}+\theta\left(x-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)+(n+1) \frac{\pi}{2}\right], \quad 0<\theta<1
$$

For any $x$, $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{\left(x-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}=0$, which was proven in the solution to problem 40, and $|\cos \alpha| \leqslant 1$. Therefore, $\lim R_{n}=0$ for any $x$, i.e., the obtained Taylor series for $\cos x$ converges to $\cos x$ for any $x$.

original.problem:
1059. Check that the given function is an integral (solution) of the given differential equation:
1) $y=\sqrt{x}, 2 y y^{\prime}=1$
2) $\ln x \ln y=c, y \ln y d x+x \ln x d y=0$.
3) $s=-t-\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 t, \frac{d^{2} s}{d t^{2}}+\operatorname{tg} t \frac{d s}{d t}=\sin 2 t$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Let's find the derivative of the given function $y'=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}$. Substituting the given equation $y=\sqrt{x}$ and $y'=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}$, we can verify that it becomes an identity: $2 \sqrt{x} \times \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}=1 ; 1=1$.

2) Differentiate the given implicit function: $\ln y \frac{dx}{x} + \ln x \frac{dy}{y}=0$ and find $dy=-\frac{y \ln y}{x \ln x} dx$. Substituting this expression for $dy$ into the given equation, we get an identity: $y \ln y dx + x \ln x \left(-\frac{y \ln y}{x \ln x} dx\right)=0 ; 0=0$.
3) Differentiating the given function twice, we find $\frac{ds}{dt}=-1-\cos 2t, \frac{d^2s}{dt^2}=2 \sin 2t$. Substituting these expressions for the first and second derivatives into the given equation: $2 \sin 2t + (-1 - \cos 2t) \tan t = \sin 2t ; \sin 2t - 2 \cos^2 t \tan t = 0 ; \sin 2t - 2 \cos t \sin t = 0 ; 0=0$, we verify that it is satisfied, i.e., it becomes an identity.

2) In the second part, verifying whether the implicit function satisfies the given differential equation also involves checking identities after substituting the derivative. 
3) The third part requires differentiation and substitution into the given second-order differential equation, also leading to an identity check.

Since all parts essentially require computing derivatives and verifying algebraic identities without needing to prove a new property or existence, they simplify to direct computations.

original.problem:
1067. Find the particular integral of the equation satisfying the given initial condition:
1) $y d x+\operatorname{ctg} x d y=0 ; \quad y\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=-1$.
2) $s=s^{\prime} \cos ^{2} t \ln s ; s(\pi)=1$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) By separating variables and integrating, we first find the general integral of the given equation:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{tg} x d x+\frac{d y}{y}=0 ; \quad-\ln |\cos x|+\ln |y|=\ln C \\
|y|=C|\cos x| ; \quad y= \pm C \cos x=C_{1} \cos x
\end{gathered}
$$

Then, using the specified initial condition $y\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=-1$, we substitute the given values of the variables $\left(x=\frac{\pi}{3}, y=-1\right)$ into the general integral and determine the corresponding value of the arbitrary constant: $-1=C_{1} \cos \frac{\pi}{3} ; C_{1}=-2$.

With this value of $C_{1}$, we obtain the desired particular integral from the general integral that satisfies the given initial condition, $y=-2 \cos x$.

2) By multiplying by $\frac{\sec ^{2} t}{s} d t$, we separate the variables $\sec ^{2} t d t=$ $=\frac{\ln s}{s} d s$ and, integrating, we find the general integral

$$
\int d(\operatorname{tg} t)=\int \ln s d \ln s+C ; \quad \operatorname{tg} t=\frac{1}{2} \ln ^{2} s+C
$$

Substituting the initial values $t=\pi, s=1$, we determine the value of $C$ :

$$
\operatorname{tg} \pi=\frac{1}{2} \ln 1+C ; \quad C=0
$$

Therefore, the desired particular integral is $\ln ^{2} s-2 \operatorname{tg} t=0$.

original.solution:
Solution. 1) Replacing the function $y$ with one and its derivatives with the corresponding powers of $r$ in the given differential equation, we write its characteristic equation: $r^{2}-5 r-6=0$.

The roots of this equation $r_{1}=6, r_{2}=-1$ are real and distinct. Therefore, according to Rule 1, the sought general integral of this equation is $y=C_{1} e^{6 x}+C_{2} e^{-x}$.

2) According to the specified rule, we form the characteristic equation: $r^{3}-6 r^{2}+13 r=0$. It has one real single root $r_{1}=0$ and a pair of complex conjugate roots $r_{2,3}=3 \pm 2 i$. According to Rules 1 and 2, the general integral of this equation is $y=C_{1}+e^{3 x}\left(C_{2} \cos 2 x+C_{3} \sin 2 x\right)$.
3) Writing the characteristic equation $r^{2}+4 r+4=0$, we find that it has equal real roots $r_{1}=r_{2}=-2$. According to Rule 3, the general integral of this equation is $S=e^{-2 t}\left(C_{1}+C_{2} t\right)$.
4) The characteristic equation $r^{4}-1=0$ of the given differential equation $y^{(4)}-y=0$ has roots $r_{1}=-1, r_{2}=1$, $r_{3,4}= \pm i$. Therefore, according to Rules 1 and 2, the sought general integral is $y=C_{1} e^{-x}+C_{2} e^{x}+C_{3} \cos x+C_{4} \sin x$.
5) The differential equation $y^{(4)}+13 y^{(2)}+36 y=0$ corresponds to the characteristic equation $r^{4}+13 r^{2}+36=0$ or $\left(r^{2}+4\right)\left(r^{2}+9\right)=0$. It has two pairs of imaginary conjugate roots $r_{1,2}= \pm 2 i, r_{\mathrm{i}, 4}= \pm 3 i$. According to Rule 2, the general integral of this equation is $y=C_{1} \cos 2 x+C_{2} \sin 2 x+C_{3} \cos 3 x+$ $+C_{4} \sin 3 x$.
6) The differential equation $y^{(7)}+2 y^{(5)}+y^{(3)}=0$ corresponds to the characteristic equation $r^{2}+2 r^{5}+r^{3}=0$ or $r^{3}\left(r^{2}+1\right)^{2}=0$. It has a triple real root, $r=0\left(r_{1}=r_{2}=r_{3}=0\right)$ and a pair of double imaginary conjugate roots $r= \pm i\left(r_{4}=r_{5}=i, r_{6}=r_{7}=-i\right)$. According to Rules 3 and 4, the general integral of this equation is $y=C_{1}+C_{2} x+C_{3} x^{2}+\left(C_{4}+C_{5} x\right) \cos x+\left(C_{8}+C_{7} x\right) \sin x$.

original.problem:
1066. Find the general integrals of the following equations:
1) $\left.(x+1)^{3} d y=(y-2)^{2} d x=0.2\right) \sec ^{2} x \sec y d x=-\operatorname{ctg} x \sin y d y$.
2) $(\sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{x}) y^{\prime}-y=0$.
3) $2^{x+y}+3^{x-2 y} y^{\prime}=0$
original.solution:
Solution. 1) We divide the variables in the given equation by dividing both parts by $(x+1)^{3}(y-2)^{2}$:

$$
\frac{d y}{(y-2)^{2}}-\frac{d x}{(x+1)^{3}}=0
$$

Integrating term by term, we obtain the desired general integral:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int(y-2)^{-2} d(y-2)-\int(x+1)^{-3} d(x+1)=C \\
-\frac{1}{y-2}+\frac{1}{2(x+1)^{2}}=C
\end{gathered}
$$

2) To separate the variables, we divide all terms of the equation by $\sec y \operatorname{ctg} x$:

$$
\sec ^{2} x \operatorname{tg} x d x+\sin y \cos y d y=0
$$

Integrating, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \operatorname{tg} x d \operatorname{tg} x+\int \sin y d \sin y=c ; \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tg}^{2} x+\frac{1}{2} \sin ^{2} y=\frac{1}{2} C \\
\operatorname{tg}^{2} x+\sin ^{2} y=C
\end{gathered}
$$

3) Express the derivative in terms of differentials of the variables: $y^{\prime}=\frac{d y}{d x}$, multiply both parts of the equation by $d x$ and factor the coefficient of $d y$:

$$
(\sqrt{y}+1) \sqrt{x} \quad d y-y d x=0
$$

Next, we separate the variables:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-389.jpg?height=99&width=408&top_left_y=326&top_left_x=442)

and, integrating, we find the general integral

$$
\int\left(y^{-\frac{1}{2}}+\frac{1}{y}\right) d y-\int x^{-\frac{1}{2}} d x=C ; 2 \sqrt{y}+\ln |y|-2 \sqrt{x}=C
$$

4) Multiply both parts of the equation by $d x$ and factor the coefficients of $d x$ and $d y$:

$$
2^{x} 2^{y} d x+3^{x} 3^{-2 y} d y=0
$$

Separate the variables by multiplying by $2^{-y} 3^{-x}$:

$$
2^{x} 3^{-x} d x+3^{-2 y} 2^{-y} d y=0
$$

and integrate:

$$
\int\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{x} d x+\int 18^{-y} d y=C ; \quad \frac{\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{x}}{\ln \frac{2}{3}}-\frac{18^{-y}}{\ln 18}=C
$$

3) The third equation similarly follows a pattern involving separation and integration to reach a solution, making it another EASY classification.

Overall classification: **EASY**

original.problem:
Example 2. Verify that the function $y=C e^{x}$ is the general solution of the equation $y^{\prime}-y=0$ and find the particular solution that satisfies the initial condition $\left.y\right|_{x=1}=-1$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_a0612bb33256580e6dcdg-008.jpg?height=468&width=391&top_left_y=308&top_left_x=125)

Fig. 5
original.solution:
Solution. We have $y=C e^{x}, y^{\prime}=C e^{x}$. Substituting the expressions for $y$ and $y^{\prime}$ into the given equation, we get $C e^{x}-C e^{x} \equiv 0$, i.e., the function $y=C e^{x}$ satisfies the given equation for any value of the constant $C$.

Let us set an arbitrary initial condition $\left.y\right|_{x=x_{0}}=y_{0}$. Substituting $x_{0}$ and $y_{0}$ for $x$ and $y$ in the function $y=C e^{x}$, we get $y_{0}=C e^{x_{0}}$, from which $C=y_{0} e^{-x_{0}}$. The function $y=y_{0} e^{x-x_{0}}$ satisfies the initial condition. Indeed, setting $x=x_{0}$, we get $y=y_{0} e^{x_{0}-x_{0}}=y_{0}$. The function $y=C e^{x}$ is the general solution of the given equation.

For $x_{0}=1$ and $y_{0}=-1$, we obtain the particular solution $y=-e^{x-1}$.

From a geometric point of view, the general solution defines a family of integral curves, which are the graphs of exponential functions; the particular solution is the integral curve passing through the point $M_{0}(1,-1)$ (Fig. 5).

A relation of the form $\Phi(x, y, C)=0$, implicitly defining the general solution, is called the general integral of a first-order differential equation.

A relation obtained from the general integral for a specific value of the constant $C$ is called a particular integral of the differential equation.

The problem of solving or integrating a differential equation consists in finding the general solution or the general integral of the given differential equation. If an initial condition is additionally given, then it is required to select a particular solution or particular integral that satisfies the given initial condition.

Since from a geometric point of view the coordinates $x$ and $y$ are equal, we will consider the equation $\frac{d x}{d y}=\frac{1}{f(x, y)}$ along with the equation $\frac{d y}{d x}=f(x, y)$.

## Problems for Independent Solution

1. Find the coinciding solutions of the two differential equations:
a) $y^{\prime}=y^{2}+2 x-x^{4}$
b) $y^{\prime}=-y^{2}-y+2 x+x^{2}+x^{4}$.

In the following problems, using some sufficient condition for uniqueness, identify the regions in which the given equations have unique solutions.
2. $y^{\prime}=x^{2}+y^{2}$.
3. $y^{\prime}=\frac{x}{y}$.
4. $y^{\prime}=y+3 \sqrt[3]{y}$.
5. $y^{\prime}=\sqrt{x-y}$.
6. $y^{\prime}=\sqrt{x^{2}-y}-x$.
7. $y^{\prime}=\sqrt{1-y^{2}}$.
8. $y^{\prime}=\frac{y+1}{x-y}$.
9. $y^{\prime}=\sin y-\cos x$.
10. $y^{\prime}=1-\operatorname{ctg} y$.
11. $y^{\prime}=\sqrt[3]{3 x-y}-1$.

12. Show that for the equation $y^{\prime}=|y|^{1 / 2}$, uniqueness of the solution is violated at each point on the $O x$ axis.
13. Find the integral curve of the equation $y^{\prime}=\sin (x y)$ passing through the point $O(0,0)$.

In the following problems, show that the given functions are solutions of the specified differential equations:

14. $y=\frac{\sin x}{x}, x y^{\prime}+y=\cos x$.
15. $y=C e^{-2 x}+\frac{1}{3} e^{x}, y^{\prime}+2 y=e^{x}$.
16. $y=2+C \sqrt{1-x^{2}},\left(1-x^{2}\right) y^{\prime}+x y=2 x$.

## § 2. Method of Isoclines

The equation

$$
y^{\prime}=f(x, y)
$$

defines in each point $(x, y)$, where the function $f(x, y)$ exists, the value of $y^{\prime}$, i.e., the slope of the tangent to the integral curve at that point.

If a value of some quantity is defined in each point of a region $D$, it is said that a field of this quantity is defined in the region $D$. Thus, the differential equation (1) defines a field of directions.

The triplet of numbers $\left(x ; y ; y^{\prime}\right)$ defines the direction of a line passing through the point $(x, y)$. The collection of segments of these lines gives a geometric picture of the field of directions.

The problem of integrating the differential equation (1) can now be interpreted as follows: find a curve such that the tangent to it at each point has a direction coinciding with the direction of the field at that point.

The problem of constructing integral curves is often solved by introducing isoclines. An isocline is the geometric locus of points where the tangents to the sought integral curves have the same direction. The family of isoclines of the differential equation (1) is defined by the equation

$$
f(x, y)=k
$$

where $k$ is a parameter. By assigning close numerical values to the parameter $k$, we obtain a sufficiently dense network of isoclines, which can be used to approximately construct the integral curves of the differential equation (1).

Remark 1. The zero isocline $f(x, y)=0$ gives the equation of the lines on which the points of maximum and minimum of the integral curves may lie.

For greater accuracy in constructing integral curves, we also find the geometric locus of points of inflection. For this, we find $y^{\prime \prime}$ using the equation (1):

$$
y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} y^{\prime}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+f(x, y) \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}
$$

and set it to zero. The line defined by the equation

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+f(x, y) \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}=0
$$

is the possible geometric locus of points of inflection.

original.problem: Example 1. Find the differential equation of the family of hyperbolas $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{1}=1$.
original.solution:
Solution. Differentiating this equation with respect to $x$, we get

$$
\frac{2 x}{a^{2}}-2 y y^{\prime}=0, \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{x}{a^{2}}=y y^{\prime}
$$

Multiplying both sides by $x$, then $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}=x y y^{\prime}$. Substituting into the equation of the family, we find $x y y^{\prime}-y^{2}=1$.

Example 2. Find the differential equation of the family of curves

$$
y=a\left(1-e^{-x / a}\right), \quad \text { where } a-\text { is a parameter. }
$$

Solution. Differentiating both sides of the equation with respect to $x$ :

$$
y^{\prime}=e^{-x / a}
$$

From the expression for $y^{\prime}$, we find $a=-\frac{x}{\ln y^{\prime}}$ and, substituting this expression for $a$ into the equation of the family of curves, we get

$$
y=-\frac{x}{\ln y^{\prime}}\left(1-y^{\prime}\right), \quad \text { or } \quad y \ln y^{\prime}+x\left(1-y^{\prime}\right)=0
$$

llm_response:

In the first example, the solution requires differentiation and algebraic manipulation to express the differential equation, and this can be straightforwardly verified by translating the given computations into a formal proof system. 

In the second example, it also involves differentiation and algebraic steps to isolate the parameter \( a \) and substitute back, which similarly lends itself to verification through clear computation.

Both examples involve direct computation and do not require proving any properties beyond simple differentiation and algebraic manipulation.

Thus, we can classify the problems as follows:

- Example 1: EASY

Both examples qualify as easy problems because they primarily involve straightforward differentiation tasks.

original.problem: Example 3. Solve the equation $y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\sqrt{1+\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. The given equation does not contain the unknown function $y$ and its derivative, so we assume $y^{\prime \prime}=p$. After this, the equation becomes

$$
\frac{d p}{d x}=\sqrt{1+p^{2}}
$$

Separating variables and integrating, we find

$$
p=\frac{e^{x+C_{1}}-e^{-\left(x+C_{1}\right)}}{2}
$$

Replacing $p$ with $y^{\prime \prime}$:

$$
y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{e^{x+C_{1}}-e^{-\left(x+C_{1}\right)}}{2}
$$

Integrating sequentially, we obtain

$$
y^{\prime}=\frac{e^{x+C_{1}}+e^{-\left(x+C_{1}\right)}}{2}+C_{2} \quad \text { and } \quad y=\frac{e^{x+C_{1}}-e^{-\left(x+C_{1}\right)}}{2}+C_{2} x+C_{3}
$$

or

$$
y=\operatorname{sh}\left(x+C_{1}\right)+C_{2} x+C_{3}
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves solving a third-order differential equation by first reducing it to a first-order equation. The process includes introducing a substitution for derivatives, separating variables, integrating, and finally expressing the solution in terms of standard functions.

**EASY**: The problem is primarily about performing a series of derivative and integration operations, which can be verified.

original.problem:
Example 8. Find the Wronskian determinant for the functions: $y_{1}(x)=\sin x$,

$$
y_{2}(x)=\sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{8}\right), y_{3}(x)=\sin \left(x-\frac{\pi}{8}\right)
$$
original.solution:
Solution. We have

$$
W\left[y_{1}, y_{2}, y_{3}\right]=\left|\begin{array}{rrr}
\sin x & \sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{8}\right) & \sin \left(x-\frac{\pi}{8}\right) \\
\cos x & \cos \left(x+\frac{\pi}{8}\right) & \cos \left(x-\frac{\pi}{8}\right) \\
-\sin x & -\sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{8}\right) & -\sin \left(x-\frac{\pi}{8}\right)
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

since the first and last rows of the determinant are proportional.

Theorem. If the system of functions $y_{1}(x), y_{2}(x), \ldots, y_{n}(x)$ is linearly dependent on the interval $[a, b]$, then its Wronskian determinant is identically zero on this interval.

For example, the system of functions $\sin x, \sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{8}\right), \sin \left(x-\frac{\pi}{8}\right)$ is linearly dependent in the interval $(-\infty,+\infty)$, and the Wronskian determinant of these functions is zero everywhere in this interval (see examples 4 and 8).

This theorem provides a necessary condition for the linear dependence of a system of functions. The converse statement is false, i.e., the Wronskian determinant can be identically zero even when the given functions form a linearly independent system on some interval.

original.problem:
Example 3. Convert the differential equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+p(t) \frac{d x}{d t}+q(t) x=0
$$

to a normal system.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $x=x_{1}, \frac{d x}{d t}=x_{2}$, then $\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=x_{2}, \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=\frac{d x_{2}}{d t}$. Substituting these expressions into the given equation, we get

$$
\frac{d x_{2}}{d t}+p(t) x_{2}+q(t) x_{1}=0
$$

The normal system will have the form

$$
\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=x_{2}, \quad \frac{d x_{2}}{d t}=-p(t) x_{2}-q(t) x_{1}
$$

A solution of the system (3) in the interval $(a, b)$ is any set of $n$ functions

$$
x_{1}=\varphi_{1}(t), \quad x_{2}=\varphi_{2}(t), \quad \ldots, \quad x_{n}=\varphi_{n}(t)
$$

defined and continuously differentiable in the interval $(a, b)$, if they turn the equations of the system (3) into identities valid for all values $t \in(a, b)$.

This problem requires reformulating a second-order differential equation into a system of first-order equations. The solution involves manipulating the expressions related to the derivatives and establishing a correspondence between the original differential equation and the transformed normal system. The solution is purely computational as it involves transforming and expressing the original equation in a different form.

Since this is primarily a straightforward conversion of the equation to a system without involving any theoretical proof or existence claim, it can be classified as:

EASY: The problem is mainly about differentiation and reformulating the given expression.

original.problem:
Example 4. Show that the system of functions $x_{1}=-\frac{1}{t^{2}}, x_{2}=-t \ln t$, defined in the interval $0<t<+\infty$, is a solution to the system of differential equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=2 t x_{1}^{2} \\
\frac{d x_{2}}{d t}=\frac{x_{2}}{t}-1
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. We have $\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=\frac{2}{t^{3}}, \frac{d x_{2}}{d t}=-1-\ln t$. Substituting into the given system of equations the expressions for $x_{1}, x_{2}, \frac{d x_{1}}{d t}$, and $\frac{d x_{2}}{d t}$ in terms of $t$, we obtain the identities

$$
\frac{2}{t^{3}} \equiv \frac{2 t}{t^{4}} \equiv \frac{2}{t^{3}}, \quad-\ln t-1 \equiv-\ln t-1, \quad 0<t<+\infty
$$

## Problems for Independent Solution

Check whether the given systems of functions are solutions to the given systems of differential equations.
767. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=-2 t x_{1}^{2}, \\ \frac{d x_{2}}{d t}=\frac{x_{2}+t}{t} ;\end{array} \quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}x_{1}=\frac{1}{t^{2}}, \\ x_{2}=t \ln t .\end{array}\right.\right.$

770. $\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{z-1}{z}, \\ \frac{d z}{d x}=y-x ;\end{array} \quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=x+e^{x}, \\ z=e^{-x} .\end{array}\right.\right.$

The Cauchy problem for the system (3) is the problem of finding a solution

$$
x_{1}=x_{1}(t), \quad x_{2}=x_{2}(t), \quad \ldots, \quad x_{n}=x_{n}(t)
$$

of this system that satisfies the initial conditions

$$
x_{1}\left(t_{0}\right)=x_{1}^{0}, \quad x_{2}\left(t_{0}\right)=x_{2}^{0}, \quad \ldots, \quad x_{n}\left(t_{0}\right)=x_{n}^{0}
$$

where $t_{0}, x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}$ are given numbers.

## Theorem of Existence and Uniqueness of the Solution to the Cauchy Problem.

Let us have a normal system of differential equations (3) and let the functions $f_{i}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), i=1,2, \ldots, n$, be defined in some $n+1$-dimensional domain $D$ of the variables $t, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$. If there exists a neighborhood $\Omega$ of the point $M_{0}\left(t_{0}, x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$, in which the functions $f_{i}$ are a) continuous, b) have bounded partial derivatives with respect to the variables $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$, then there exists an interval $t_{0}-h < t < t_{0}+h$ of variation of $t$, in which there exists a unique solution to the normal system (3) that satisfies the initial conditions (4). The system of $n$ differentiable functions

$$
x_{i}=x_{i}\left(t, C_{1}, C_{2}, \ldots, C_{n}\right), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

of the independent variable $t$ and $n$ arbitrary constants $C_{1}, C_{2}, \ldots, C_{n}$ is called the general solution of the normal system (3) if: 1) for any admissible values of $C_{1}, C_{2}, \ldots, C_{n}$, the system of functions (5) turns the equations (3) into identities, 2) in the domain where the conditions of the Cauchy theorem are satisfied, the functions (5) solve any Cauchy problem.

28.3. Prove that if the functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are differentiable at the point $x_{0}$, then:

a) $(f+g)^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)+g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$

b) $(f g)^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) g\left(x_{0}\right)+f\left(x_{0}\right) g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$, where $(f g)(x)=f(x) g(x)$;

c) $\left(\frac{f}{g}\right)^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) g\left(x_{0}\right)-f\left(x_{0}\right) g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)}{\left(g\left(x_{0}\right)\right)^{2}}$, if $g\left(x_{0}\right) \neq 0$.

- The composition of functions $f$ and $g$ is the function $g \circ f(x)=g(f(x))$.
original.solution:
28.3. a) It directly follows from the properties of the limit of the sum of two functions.

b) Let $h(x)=f(x) g(x)$. Then

$$
h(x)-h\left(x_{0}\right)=f(x)\left(g(x)-g\left(x_{0}\right)\right)+g\left(x_{0}\right)\left(f(x)-f\left(x_{0}\right)\right) .
$$

Divide both sides of this equation by $x-x_{0}$ and note that $f(x) \rightarrow f\left(x_{0}\right)$ as $x \rightarrow x_{0}$.

c) Let $h(x)=f(x) / g(x)$. Then

$$
\frac{h(x)-h\left(x_{0}\right)}{x-x_{0}}=\frac{1}{g(x) g\left(x_{0}\right)}\left(g\left(x_{0}\right) \frac{f(x)-f\left(x_{0}\right)}{x-x_{0}}-f\left(x_{0}\right) \frac{g(x)-g\left(x_{0}\right)}{x-x_{0}}\right)
$$

Taking the limit as $x$ approaches $x_{0}$, we obtain the required result.

29.14. Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial. Compute the integrals: a) $\int P(x) e^{a x} d x$; b) $\int P(x) \sin a x d x$; c) $\int P(x) \cos a x d x$.

## 29.2. Definite Integral

Let a function $f(x)$ be defined on the interval $[a, b]$. Divide this interval into parts by points $x_{0}=a<x_{1}<x_{2}<\ldots<x_{n-1}<$ $<b=x_{n}$. On each segment $\left[x_{k}, x_{k+1}\right]$, choose an arbitrary point $\xi_{k}$ and consider the so-called integral sum $\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f\left(\xi_{k}\right)\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right)$. It turns out that if the function $f(x)$ is continuous and the maximum length of the segments of the partition tends to zero, then the integral sums have a finite limit, which does not depend on the choice of the partition and the choice of points $\xi_{k}$. This limit is called the definite integral of the function $f(x)$ over the interval $[a, b]$ and is denoted by $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x$.

The function $f(x)$ is called integrable on the interval $[a, b]$ if this limit of the integral sums exists. Integrable functions can be not only continuous functions, but we will mainly be interested in continuous functions.

To prove the integrability of continuous functions, we introduce the following auxiliary concepts. Let a continuous function $f(x)$ be defined on the interval $[a, b]$ and let some partition of this interval be given. For each segment $\left[x_{k}, x_{k+1}\right]$, consider $M_{k}$ and $m_{k}$ - the maximum and minimum values of the function $f(x)$ on this segment. The sums

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} M_{k}\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} m_{k}\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right)
$$

are called the upper and lower integral sums; they depend only on the partition and do not depend on the choice of points $\xi_{k}$. Clearly, each integral sum is bounded between the upper and lower integral sums for the same partition.
original.solution:
29.14. a) Let's use the formula from problem 29.13. If $g^{(n+1)}=e^{a x}$, then $g^{(n)}=\frac{e^{a x}}{a}, g^{(n-1)}=\frac{e^{a x}}{a^{2}}, \ldots$ Therefore,

$$
\int P(x) e^{a x} d x=e^{a x}\left(\frac{P}{a}-\frac{P^{\prime}}{a^{2}}+\frac{P^{\prime \prime}}{a^{3}}-\ldots\right)+C
$$

b) If $g^{(n+1)}=\sin a x$, then $g^{(n)}=-\frac{\cos a x}{a}, g^{(n-1)}=-\frac{\sin a x}{a^{2}}, g^{(n-2)}=$ $=\frac{\cos a x}{a^{3}}, \ldots$ Therefore,

$$
\int P(x) \sin a x d x=\sin a x\left(\frac{P^{\prime}}{a^{2}}-\frac{P^{\prime \prime \prime}}{a^{4}}+\ldots\right)-\cos a x\left(\frac{P}{a}-\frac{P^{\prime \prime}}{a^{3}}+\ldots\right)+C
$$

c) Similarly to the solution of problem b), we obtain

$$
\int P(x) \cos a x d x=\sin a x\left(\frac{P}{a}-\frac{P^{\prime \prime}}{a^{3}}+\ldots\right)+\cos a x\left(\frac{P^{\prime}}{a^{2}}-\frac{P^{\prime \prime \prime}}{a^{4}}+\ldots\right)+C
$$

original.problem: 29.35. Calculate the length of the arc of the curve $y=\operatorname{ch} x$, enclosed between the points $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$.
original.solution: 29.35. It is clear that $y^{\prime}=\operatorname{sh} x$ and $\sqrt{1+\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}}=\operatorname{ch} x$. Therefore, the length of the considered arc is $\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} \operatorname{ch} x d x=\operatorname{sh} x_{2}-\operatorname{sh} x_{1}$ (it is assumed that $\left.x_{1}<x_{2}\right)$.

29.38. Calculate the length of the cycloid branch

$$
x=a(t-\sin t), \quad y=a(1-\cos t), \quad \text { where } \quad 0 \leqslant t \leqslant 2 \pi
$$

## 29.7. Surface Area

Let $f(x)$ be a continuous positive function on the interval $[a, b], x_{0}=a<x_{1}<\ldots<x_{n-1}<b=x_{n}$ - some points on the interval $[a, b]$. Suppose we rotate the curve $y=f(x)$ around the $O x$ axis. The broken line with vertices $A_{k}=\left(x_{k}, f\left(x_{k}\right)\right)$ sweeps out a certain surface, consisting of truncated cones. If the sum of the lateral surface areas of these cones has a limit as the length of the largest segment $A_{k} A_{k+1}$ approaches zero, then this limit is called the surface area of revolution swept out by the curve $y=f(x)$.
original.solution:
29.38. Answer: $8a$. It is clear that

$$
\sqrt{x'^2 + y'^2} = a \sqrt{(1 - \cos t)^2 + \sin^2 t} = 2a \sin \frac{t}{2}
$$

Therefore, the length of the branch of the cycloid is

$$
2a \int_{0}^{2\pi} \sin \frac{t}{2} dt = -\left.4a \cos \frac{t}{2}\right|_{0}^{2\pi} = 8a
$$

38.14. Calculate the curvature of the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ at each point.

## 38.4. Osculating Circle

Consider two curves on a plane given by the equations $y=f(x)$ and $y=g(x)$. These curves intersect if $f\left(x_{0}\right)=g\left(x_{0}\right)$. The curves touch (have a contact of order 1) at the point of intersection if $f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$. Curves that touch have a contact of order $n$ if $f\left(x_{0}\right)=g\left(x_{0}\right), f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right), \ldots, \ldots, f^{(n)}\left(x_{0}\right)=g^{(n)}\left(x_{0}\right)$. Curves that have a contact of order 2 are called osculating.

If the curvature of a curve at some point is non-zero, then there is a unique circle that is osculating to the curve at that point (the osculating circle). The equation of the osculating circle in the case where the curve is given by the equation $y=f(x)$ is found as follows. Let $y=g(x)$ be the function locally defining a circle of radius $R$ with center $(a, b)$, i.e., $g$ satisfies the relation

$$
(x-a)^{2}+(g(x)-b)^{2}=R^{2}
$$

Differentiating this relation, we successively obtain

$$
\begin{array}{r}
2(x-a)+2 g^{\prime}(x)(g(x)-b)=0 \\
2+2 g^{\prime \prime}(x)(g(x)-b)+2\left(g^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}=0
\end{array}
$$

If the curve $y=f(x)$ is osculating to the specified circle at the point $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(x_{0}-a\right)^{2}+\left(y_{0}-b\right)^{2} & =R^{2} \\
\left(x_{0}-a\right)+y_{0}^{\prime}\left(y_{0}-b\right) & =0 \\
1+y_{0}^{\prime \prime}\left(y_{0}-b\right)+\left(y_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{2} & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y_{0}^{\prime}=f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$ and $y_{0}^{\prime \prime}=f^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$. Moreover, if this system of equations for $a, b, R$ has a solution, then the converse is also true: the curve is osculating to the circle. It is easy to see that if $y_{0}^{\prime \prime} \neq \mathbf{0}$, then this system of equations has a unique solution. For example, if $y_{0}^{\prime}=0$ (which can always be achieved by a suitable choice of coordinate system), then $a=x_{0}, b=y_{0}+\frac{1}{y_{0}^{\prime \prime}}, R^{2}=\frac{1}{\left(y_{0}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}}$.

The center of the osculating circle is called the center of curvature of the curve. According to problem 38.13 in the considered situation, $k^{2}=\frac{\left(y_{0}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}}{\left(1+y_{0}^{\prime 2}\right)^{3}}=\left(y_{0}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}$. Thus, the center of curvature lies on the normal to the curve at the given point and is at a distance of $\pm 1 / k$ from this point.

38.14. Consider the following parameterization of an ellipse: $x(t) = a \cos t, y(t) = b \sin t$. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
x'' y' - y'' x' = -ab(\cos^2 t + \sin^2 t) = -ab, \\
x'^2 + y'^2 = a^2 \sin^2 t + b^2 \cos^2 t
\end{gathered}
$$

Therefore, according to problem 38.13,

$$
k^2 = \frac{a^2 b^2}{(a^2 \sin^2 t + b^2 \cos^2 t)^3}
$$

Remark. Another method for calculating the curvature of an ellipse is given in problem 38.16.

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:

$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{3}-(n-1)^{3}}{(n+1)^{4}-n^{4}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{3}-(n-1)^{3}}{(n+1)^{4}-n^{4}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{3}-n^{3}+3 n^{2}-3 n+1}{\left((n+1)^{2}-n^{2}\right) \cdot\left((n+1)^{2}+n^{2}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{3 n^{2}-3 n+1}{\left(n^{2}+2 n+1-n^{2}\right)\left(n^{2}+2 n+1+n^{2}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{3}}\left(3 n^{2}-3 n+1\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{3}}(2 n+1)\left(2 n^{2}+2 n+1\right)}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{3}{n}-\frac{3}{n^{2}}+\frac{1}{n^{3}}}{\left(2+\frac{1}{n}\right)\left(2+\frac{2}{n}+\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)}= \\
& =\frac{0-0+0}{(2+0) \cdot(2+0+0)}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\sqrt{\cos x}}{1-\cos \sqrt{x}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\sqrt{\cos x}}{1-\cos \sqrt{x}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(1-\sqrt{\cos x})(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}{(1-\cos \sqrt{x})(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos x}{(1-\cos \sqrt{x})(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}, \text { as } x \rightarrow 0 \\
& 1-\cos \sqrt{x} \sim \frac{(\sqrt{x})^{2}}{2}, \text { as } x \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{x^{2}}{2}}{\frac{(\sqrt{x})^{2}}{2}(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2}}{x(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{1+\sqrt{\cos x}}= \\
& =\frac{0}{1+\sqrt{\cos 0}}=\frac{0}{1+\sqrt{1}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{3 x}-e^{-2 x}}{2 \arcsin x-\sin x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(e^{3 x}-1\right)-\left(e^{-2 x}-1\right)}{2 \arcsin x-\sin x}=$

$$

& =\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{3 x}-1}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{-2 x}-1}{x}\right) /\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \arcsin x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{x}\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{3 x}-1 \sim 3 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(3 x \rightarrow 0)$

$e^{-2 x}-1 \sim-2 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(-2 x \rightarrow 0)$

$\arcsin x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

$\sin x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\frac{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 x}{x}}{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{x}}=\frac{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 3-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}-2}{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 2-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1}=\frac{3+2}{2-1}=5$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{1}{2}} \frac{(2 x-1)^{2}}{e^{\sin \pi x}-e^{-\sin 3 \pi x}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(2\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)-1\right)^{2}}{e^{\sin \pi\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)}-e^{-\sin 3 \pi\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2 y+1-1)^{2}}{e^{\sin \left(\pi y+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}-e^{-\sin \left(3 \pi y+\frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{4 y^{2}}{e^{\cos \pi y}-e^{\cos 3 \pi y}}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{4 y^{2}}{-e^{\cos \pi y}\left(e^{\cos 3 \pi y-\cos \pi y}-1\right)}=
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_b7cebc4f34037103b026g-09.jpg?height=165&width=976&top_left_y=313&top_left_x=152)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{4 y^{2}}{-e^{\cos \pi y}\left(e^{-2 \cdot \sin 2 \pi y \cdot \sin \pi y}-1\right)}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{-2 \cdot \sin 2 \pi y \cdot \sin \pi y}-1 \sim-2 \cdot \sin 2 \pi y \cdot \sin \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(-2 \cdot \sin 2 \pi y \cdot \sin \pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{4 y^{2}}{-e^{\cos \pi y}(-2 \cdot \sin 2 \pi y \cdot \sin \pi y)}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_b7cebc4f34037103b026g-09.jpg?height=70&width=800&top_left_y=1255&top_left_x=153)

$\sin \pi y \sim \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(\pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{4 y^{2}}{-e^{\cos \pi y}(-2 \cdot 2 \pi y \cdot \pi y)}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{e^{\cos \pi y}(\pi \cdot \pi)}= \\
& =\frac{1}{e^{\cos (\pi \cdot 0)}\left(\pi^{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{e^{1}\left(\pi^{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{e \cdot \pi^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:

$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{n+3}{n+5}\right)^{n+4}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{n+3}{n+5}\right)^{n+4}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{n+5}{n+3}\right)^{-n-4}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{n+3+2}{n+3}\right)^{-n-4}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+\frac{2}{n+3}\right)^{-n-4}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+\frac{1}{\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right)}\right)^{-n-4}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+\frac{1}{\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right)}\right)^{\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right)\left(\frac{2}{n+3}\right)(-n-4)}= \\
& =\left(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+\frac{1}{\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right)}\right)^{\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right)}\right)^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{2}{n+3}\right)(-n-4)}= \\
& =\{\text { Using the second remarkable limit }\}= \\
& =e^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2(-n-4)}{n+3}}=e^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n} 2(-n-4)}{\frac{1}{n}(n+3)}}= \\
& =e^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2\left(-1-\frac{4}{n}\right)}{1+\frac{3}{n}}}=e^{\frac{2(-1-0)}{1+0}}=e^{-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin (\pi(x+1))}{\ln (1+2 x)}$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln (1+2 x) \sim 2 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(2 x \rightarrow 0)$

$\sin \pi x \sim \pi x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(\pi x \rightarrow 0)$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin (\pi(x+1))}{\ln (1+2 x)}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin (\pi x+\pi)}{2 x}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \sin (\pi x)}{2 x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \pi x}{2 x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\pi}{1}=-\pi
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{\ln (2 x-5)}{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Substitution:

$x=y+3 \Rightarrow y=x-3$

$x \rightarrow 3 \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 3} \frac{\ln (2 x-5)}{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (2(y+3)-5)}{e^{\sin \pi(y+3)}-1}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (2 y+6-5)}{e^{\sin (\pi y+3 \pi)}-1}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (2 y+1)}{e^{\sin (\pi y+\pi)}-1}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (2 y+1)}{e^{-\sin \pi y}-1}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_c071f2ede8d7a98b06e8g-09.jpg?height=73&width=822&top_left_y=1809&top_left_x=150)

$e^{-\sin \pi y}-1 \sim -\sin \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(-\sin \pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 y}{-\sin \pi y}=
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\sin \pi y \sim \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(\pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 y}{-\pi y}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2}{-\pi}=-\frac{2}{\pi}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt{\operatorname{arctg} x \cdot \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)+5 \cos x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since $\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)_{\text { is bounded, and }} \operatorname{arctg} x \rightarrow 0$, as $x \rightarrow 0$, then

$$
\operatorname{arctg} x \cdot \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \rightarrow 0 \underset{\text { as } x \rightarrow 0}{ }
$$

Then:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt{\operatorname{arctg} x \cdot \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)+5 \cos x}=\sqrt{0+5 \cos 0}=\sqrt{5 \cdot 1}=\sqrt{5}$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the areas of figures bounded by lines given in polar coordinates.

$$
r=2 \sin 4 \phi
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's draw the graph of the function $r=2 \sin 4 \varphi:$

We will use

the formula

Integrals 16-26

for calculating

the area

of a region in polar

coordinates:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_17ecf51401f349d22271g-51.jpg?height=1405&width=1422&top_left_y=1134&top_left_x=520)

$$
S=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\alpha}^{\beta} r^{2}(\varphi) d \varphi
$$

Obviously, to find the area of the entire figure, it is sufficient to calculate the area for $0 \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{4}$ and multiply it by 8.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=8 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} 4 \cdot \sin ^{2} 4 \varphi d \varphi= \\
& =16 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \sin ^{2} 4 \varphi d \varphi= \\
& =16 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{1}{2}(1-\cos 8 \varphi) d \varphi= \\
& =\left.8 \cdot\left(\varphi-\frac{1}{8} \sin 8 \varphi\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 4}= \\
& =8 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{8} \sin \left(8 \cdot \frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)-8 \cdot\left(0-\frac{1}{8} \sin (8 \cdot 0)\right)= \\
& =2 \pi-\sin 2 \pi-0=2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

## Task Condition

Find the differential $d y$.

$$
y=\ln |\cos \sqrt{x}|+\sqrt{x} \tan \sqrt{x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d y=y^{\prime} \cdot d x=(\ln |\cos \sqrt{x}|+\sqrt{x} \tan \sqrt{x})^{\prime} d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\cos \sqrt{x}} \cdot(-\sin \sqrt{x}) \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} \tan \sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \sqrt{x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right) d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\left(-\tan \sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} \tan \sqrt{x}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \sqrt{x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2}\right) d x=\frac{d x}{2 \cos ^{2} \sqrt{x}}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$y=\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1}, x_{0}=1$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{2 x^{\prime}\left(x^{2}+1\right)-2 x\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{\prime}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{2 x^{2}+2-2 x \cdot 2 x}{\left(-2 x^{2}+2\right)^{2}}=\frac{2-2 x^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$
y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{2-2 \cdot 1^{2}}{\left(1^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{0}{2^{2}}=0
$$

Since the function $y^{\prime}{ }_{\text {at point }} x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right), \text { where } \\
& y_{0}^{\prime}=0 \\
& y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{2 \cdot 1}{1^{2}+1}=\frac{2}{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$y-1=0 \cdot(x-(-2))$

$y=1$

That is, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y=1$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Approximately calculate using the differential.

$y=\sqrt{x^{3}}, x=0.98$
original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{0}$ of the argument $x$ is small in absolute value, then

$f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 1$

Then:

$\Delta x = -0.02$

Calculate:

$y(1) = \sqrt{1^{3}} = 1$

$y^{\prime} = \left(\sqrt{x^{3}}\right)^{\prime} = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{3}}} \cdot 3 x^{2} = \frac{3 \sqrt{x}}{2}$

$y^{\prime}(1) = \frac{3 \sqrt{1}}{2} = \frac{3}{2}$

We get:

$y(0.98) \approx y(1) + y^{\prime}(1) \cdot (-0.02) = 1 - \frac{3}{2} \cdot 0.02 = 0.97$

$=-\frac{2}{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x} \cdot \operatorname{ch} x-(-3) \cdot \frac{1}{3 \operatorname{sh}^{4} x} \cdot \operatorname{ch} x+\frac{\operatorname{ch} x \cdot \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-\operatorname{sh} x \cdot 2 \operatorname{ch} x \cdot \operatorname{sh} x}{2 \operatorname{ch}^{4} x}+\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1+\operatorname{sh}^{2} x} \cdot \operatorname{ch} x=$

$=-\frac{2 \operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}+\frac{\operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{sh}^{4} x}+\frac{\operatorname{ch}^{2} x-2 \operatorname{sh}^{2} x}{2 \operatorname{ch}^{3} x}+\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{\operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{ch}^{2} x}=$

$=-\frac{2 \operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}+\frac{\operatorname{ch} x}{\operatorname{sh}^{4} x}+\frac{1-\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}{2 \operatorname{ch}^{3} x}+\frac{5}{2 \operatorname{ch} x}$

original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\ln \cos \frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sin ^{2} 23 x}{23 \cos 46 x}\right)^{\prime}=0+\left(\frac{\sin ^{2} 23 x}{23 \cos 46 x}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{2 \sin 23 x \cdot \cos 23 x \cdot 23 \cdot \cos 46 x-\sin ^{2} 23 x \cdot(-\sin 46 x) \cdot 46}{23 \cos ^{2} 46 x}=$

$=\frac{\sin 46 x \cdot \cos 46 x+2 \sin ^{2} 23 x \cdot \sin 46 x}{\cos ^{2} 46 x}=$

$=\frac{\sin 46 x \cdot\left(\cos 46 x+2 \sin ^{2} 23 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 46 x}=\frac{\sin 46 x \cdot\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} 23 x+2 \sin ^{2} 23 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 46 x}=$

$=\frac{\sin 46 x}{\cos ^{2} 46 x}=\frac{\operatorname{tg} 46 x}{\cos 46 x}$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$y=\arcsin \left(e^{-4 x}\right)+\ln \left(e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}\right)$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\arcsin \left(e^{-4 x}\right)+\ln \left(e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}\right)\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(e^{-4 x}\right)^{2}}} \cdot e^{-4 x} \cdot(-4)+\frac{1}{e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}} \cdot\left(e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-\frac{4}{e^{4 x} \sqrt{1-e^{-8 x}}}+\frac{1}{e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}} \cdot\left(4 e^{4 x}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}} \cdot 8 e^{8 x}\right)=$

$=-\frac{4}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}+\frac{1}{e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}} \cdot\left(\frac{4 e^{4 x} \sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}+4 e^{8 x}}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}\right)=$

$=-\frac{4}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}+\frac{1}{e^{4 x}+\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}} \cdot \frac{4 e^{4 x}\left(\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}+e^{4 x}\right)}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}=$

$=-\frac{4}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}+\frac{4 e^{4 x}}{\sqrt{e^{8 x}-1}}=\frac{4\left(e^{4 x}-1\right)}{\sqrt{\left(e^{4 x}-1\right) \cdot\left(e^{4 x}+1\right)}}=4 \sqrt{\frac{e^{4 x}-1}{e^{4 x}+1}}$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=x^{e^{\cos x}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y=x^{e^{\cos x}}$

$\ln y=e^{\cos x} \cdot \ln x$

$\frac{y^{\prime}}{y}=\left(e^{\cos x} \cdot \ln x\right)^{\prime}=\left(e^{\cos x}\right)^{\prime} \cdot \ln x+e^{\cos x} \cdot(\ln x)^{\prime}=$

$=e^{\cos x} \cdot(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \ln x+e^{\cos x} \cdot \frac{1}{x}=e^{\cos x} \cdot\left(-\sin x \cdot \ln x+\frac{1}{x}\right)$
$y^{\prime}=y \cdot e^{\cos x} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{x}-\sin x \cdot \ln x\right)=x^{e^{\cos x}} \cdot e^{\cos x} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{x}-\sin x \cdot \ln x\right)$

$=\frac{30-7(-11+30 \ln x)}{x^{8}}=\frac{107-210 \ln x}{x^{8}}$
