original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{2 \operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos x d x}{(1-\cos x)^{3}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=2 \operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{2 \operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{2}}{2}=\operatorname{tg}\left(\operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \\
& x=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{2 \operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos x d x}{(1-\cos x)^{3}}=\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1} \frac{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(1-\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{3}}=\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2} \cdot\left(\frac{1+t^{2}-1+t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{3}}= \\
= & \int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{\left(\frac{8 t^{6}}{1+t^{2}}\right)}=\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1^{2}} \frac{\left(1+t^{2}\right)\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{4 t^{6}}=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1} \frac{\left(1-t^{4}\right) d t}{t^{6}}= \\
= & \frac{1}{4} \cdot \int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{1}\left(\frac{1}{t^{6}}-\frac{1}{t^{2}}\right) d t=\left.\frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{5 t^{5}}+\frac{1}{t}\right)\right|_{\frac{1}{2}} ^{1}= \\
= & \frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(\left(-\frac{1}{5 \cdot 1^{5}}+\frac{1}{1}\right)-\left(-\frac{1}{5 \cdot\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{5}}+\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)}\right)\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{5}+1+\frac{32}{5}-2\right)=\frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(\frac{31}{5}-1\right)=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{26}{5}=\frac{13}{10}=1.3
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{\frac{\pi}{3}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos x \, dx}{1+\sin x-\cos x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=\frac{\pi}{3} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& x=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_4691033a31e4eabc857cg-24.jpg?height=212&width=1357&top_left_y=1870&top_left_x=224)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)\left(2 t^{2}+2 t\right)}=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{2(1-t)(1+t) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right) 2 t(t+1)}= \\
& =\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{(1-t) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right) t}=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right) t}-\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{t}{1+t^{2}}\right) d t-\left.\operatorname{arctg} t\right|_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}} ^{1}=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{d t}{t}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1} \frac{d\left(t^{2}+1\right)}{1+t^{2}}-\left.\operatorname{arctg} t\right|_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}} ^{1}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\ln |t|_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{1}-\left.\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+t^{2}\right)\right|_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}} ^{1}-\operatorname{arctg} 1+\operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}= \\
& =\ln |1|-\ln \left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right|-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+1^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}\right)-\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\pi}{6}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{4}{3}\right)-\frac{\pi}{12}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln 2-\frac{\pi}{12}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0} \frac{\cos x \, dx}{(1+\cos x-\sin x)^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=-\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg}\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=-1 \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{0}{2}=\operatorname{tg} 0=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0} \frac{\cos x d x}{(1+\cos x-\sin x)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(1+\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(\frac{1+t^{2}+1-t^{2}-2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{(2-2 t)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{2(1-t)(1+t) d t}{4(1-t)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(1+t) d t}{2(1-t)}=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0} \frac{t-1+2}{t-1} d t= \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0} d t-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{1}{t-1} d t=-\left.\frac{t}{2}\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\ln |t-1|_{-1}^{0}= \\
& =-\frac{0}{2}+\frac{-1}{2}-\ln |0-1|+\ln |-1-1|=0-\frac{1}{2}-0+\ln 2=-\frac{1}{2}+\ln 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}^{0} \frac{\cos x \, dx}{1+\cos x-\sin x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=-\frac{2 \pi}{3} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(-\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg}\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=-\sqrt{3} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{0}{2}=\operatorname{tg} 0=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}^{0} \frac{\cos x d x}{1+\cos x-\sin x}=\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{1+\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}}=\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\frac{1+t^{2}+1-t^{2}-2 t}{1+t^{2}}}= \\
= & \int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)(2-2 t)}=\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{2(1-t)(1+t) d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right) 2(1-t)}= \\
= & \int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{(1+t) d t}{1+t^{2}}=\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{0} \frac{d\left(t^{2}+1\right)}{1+t^{2}}= \\
= & \left.\operatorname{arctg} t\right|_{-\sqrt{3}} ^{0}+\left.\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+t^{2}\right)\right|_{-\sqrt{3}} ^{0}= \\
= & \operatorname{arctg} 0-\operatorname{arctg}(-\sqrt{3})+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+0^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(1+(-\sqrt{3})^{2}\right)= \\
= & 0-\left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)+0-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln 4=\frac{\pi}{3}-\ln 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+8-17$ »

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\sin x \, dx}{(1+\sin x)^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{0}{2}=\operatorname{tg} 0=0 \\
& x=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\sin x d x}{(1+\sin x)^{2}}=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(1+\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(\frac{1+t^{2}+2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{4 t \cdot d t}{(1+t)^{4}}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=1+t, d t=d u \\
& t=0 \Rightarrow u=1 \\
& t=1 \Rightarrow u=2
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{4(u-1) \cdot d u}{u^{4}}=4 \cdot \int_{1}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{u^{3}}-\frac{1}{u^{4}}\right) d u=\left.4 \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2 u^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 u^{3}}\right)\right|_{1} ^{2}=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2 \cdot 2^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 \cdot 2^{3}}\right)-4 \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2 \cdot 1^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 \cdot 1^{3}}\right)= \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{6}+2-\frac{4}{3}=\frac{1}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B0_8-21 »

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\frac{2 \pi}{3}} \frac{\cos ^{2} x d x}{(1+\cos x+\sin x)^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{0}{2}=\operatorname{tg} 0=0 \\
& x=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{3}=\sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\frac{2 \pi}{3}} \frac{\cos ^{2} x d x}{(1+\cos x+\sin x)^{2}}=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{\left(\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(1+\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}+\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{\left(\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(\frac{1+t^{2}+1-t^{2}+2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{2\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{2} d t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)(2+2 t)^{2}}=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{(1-t)^{2}(1+t)^{2} d t}{2\left(1+t^{2}\right)(1+t)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{(1-t)^{2} d t}{1+t^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{1-2 t+t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} d t= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} d t-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{d\left(t^{2}+1\right)}{1+t^{2}}=\left.\frac{t}{2}\right|_{0} ^{\sqrt{3}}-\left.\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(t^{2}+1\right)\right|_{0} ^{\sqrt{3}}= \\
& =\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{0}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left((\sqrt{3})^{2}+1\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(0^{2}+1\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-0-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln 4+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln 1=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\ln 2
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+2)^{3}+(n-2)^{3}}{n^{4}+2 n^{2}-1}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+2)^{3}+(n-2)^{3}}{n^{4}+2 n^{2}-1}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{3}}\left((n+2)^{3}+(n-2)^{3}\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{3}}\left(n^{4}+2 n^{2}-1\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(1+\frac{2}{n}\right)^{3}+\left(1-\frac{2}{n}\right)^{3}}{n+\frac{2}{n}-\frac{1}{n}}=\left\{\frac{2}{\infty}\right\}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+6}-\sqrt{n^{2}-5}}{\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+3}+\sqrt[4]{n^{3}+1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n}\left(\sqrt{n+6}-\sqrt{n^{2}-5}\right)}{\frac{1}{n}\left(\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+3}+\sqrt[4]{n^{3}+1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}+\frac{6}{n^{2}}}-\sqrt{1-\frac{5}{n^{2}}}}{\sqrt[3]{1+\frac{3}{n^{3}}}+\sqrt[4]{\frac{1}{n}+\frac{1}{n^{4}}}}=\frac{\sqrt{0+0}-\sqrt{1-0}}{\sqrt[3]{1+0}+\sqrt[4]{0+0}}=\frac{-1}{1}=-1
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{\cos x}-1}{\sin ^{2} 2 x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{\cos x}-1}{\sin ^{2} 2 x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-(1-\sqrt{\cos x})(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}{\sin ^{2} 2 x(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-(1-\cos x)}{\sin ^{2} 2 x(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

$\sin 2 x \sim 2 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(2 x \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}{(2 x)^{2}(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-x^{2}}{8 x^{2}(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-1}{8(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=\frac{-1}{8(1+\sqrt{\cos 0})}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\frac{-1}{8(1+1)}=-\frac{1}{16}
$$

& =\left(\tan\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-0\right)\right)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{x}-1\right) / x}=(1)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{x}-1\right) / x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{x}-1 \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=1^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{x}}=1^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1}=1^{1}=1$

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

Compose the equation of the tangent to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$$
y=\frac{x^{29}+6}{x^{4}+1}, x_{0}=1
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{x^{29}+6}{x^{4}+1}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\left(x^{29}+6\right)^{\prime}\left(x^{4}+1\right)-\left(x^{29}+6\right)\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{\prime}}{\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{29 x^{28}\left(x^{4}+1\right)-\left(x^{29}+6\right) \cdot 4 x^{3}}{\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{29 x^{32}+29 x^{28}-4 x^{32}-24 x^{3}}{\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{25 x^{32}+29 x^{28}-24 x^{3}}{\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{25 x_{0}^{32}+29 x_{0}^{28}-24 x_{0}^{3}}{\left(x_{0}^{4}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{25 \cdot 1^{32}+29 \cdot 1^{28}-24 \cdot 1^{3}}{\left(1^{4}+1\right)^{2}}=$

$=\frac{25+29-24}{(1+1)^{2}}=\frac{30}{4}=7.5$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$, where

$y_{0}^{\prime}=7.5$

$y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{x_{0}^{29}+6}{x_{0}^{4}+1}=\frac{1^{29}+6}{1^{4}+1}=\frac{1+6}{1+1}=\frac{7}{2}=3.5$

We get:

$y-3.5=7.5 \cdot(x-1)$

$y-3.5=7.5 x-7.5$

$y=7.5 x-4$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y=7.5 x-4$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$:

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
2 x^{2}+x^{2} \cos \frac{1}{9 x}, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \Delta x^{2}+\Delta x^{2} \cos \frac{1}{9 \Delta x}-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \Delta x^{2}+\Delta x^{2} \cos \frac{1}{9 \Delta x}}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(2 \Delta x+\Delta x \cos \frac{1}{9 \Delta x}\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\cos \frac{1}{9 \Delta x}$ is bounded, then

$\Delta x \cdot \cos \frac{1}{9 \Delta x} \rightarrow 0$, as $\Delta x \rightarrow 0$

Then:

$=2 \cdot 0+0=0$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=0$

original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{0}$ of the argument $x$ is small in absolute value, then

$f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 8$

Then:

$\Delta x = 0.24$

Calculate:

$y(8) = \sqrt[3]{8} = 2$

$y^{\prime} = (\sqrt[3]{x})^{\prime} = \left(x^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{\prime} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot x^{-\frac{2}{3}}$

$y^{\prime}(8) = \frac{1}{3} \cdot 8^{-\frac{2}{3}} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{12}$

## We obtain:

$y(8.24) \approx y(8) + y^{\prime}(8) \cdot 0.24 = 2 + \frac{1}{12} \cdot 0.24 = 2.02$

## Condition of the problem

Find the differential $d y$

$y=\ln \left(\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)-\frac{x}{\sin x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d y=y^{\prime} \cdot d x=\left(\ln \left(\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)-\frac{x}{\sin x}\right)^{\prime} d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)^{\prime}-\frac{x^{\prime} \cdot \sin x-x \cdot(\sin x)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sin x-x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sin x-x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\sin x}-\frac{\sin x-x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x=\left(\frac{\sin x}{\sin ^{2} x}-\frac{\sin x-x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{\sin x-\sin x+x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x=\left(\frac{x \cdot \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}\right) d x=\frac{2 \cot x}{\sin x} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=\frac{\ln (3+x)}{3+x}, y^{\prime \prime \prime}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\ln (3+x)}{3+x}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{1}{3+x} \cdot(3+x)-\ln (3+x) \cdot 1}{(3+x)^{2}}=\frac{1-\ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{2}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1-\ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-\frac{1}{3+x} \cdot(3+x)^{2}-(1-\ln (3+x)) \cdot 2(3+x)}{(3+x)^{4}}= \\
& =\frac{-1-(1-\ln (3+x)) \cdot 2}{(3+x)^{3}}=\frac{-1-2+2 \ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{3}}=\frac{-3+2 \ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{3}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{-3+2 \ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{\frac{2}{3+x} \cdot(3+x)^{3}-(-3+2 \ln (3+x)) \cdot 3(3+x)^{2}}{(3+x)^{6}}= \\
& =\frac{2-(-3+2 \ln (3+x)) \cdot 3}{(3+x)^{4}}=\frac{2+9-6 \ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{4}}=\frac{11-6 \ln (3+x)}{(3+x)^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \\

\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1 \cdot \sqrt{1-t^{2}}-t \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t)}{1-t^{2}}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1-t^{2}+t \cdot t}{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}} \\
& y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\ln \frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}{t}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{t}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t) \cdot t-\left(1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\right) \cdot 1}{t^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-t^{2}-\sqrt{1-t^{2}}-\left(1-t^{2}\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-\left(\sqrt{1-t^{2}}+1\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right) /\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=-\frac{1-t^{2}}{t}=\frac{t^{2}-1}{t}
$$

## Task Condition

$$
y=\frac{4+15 x}{5 x+1}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{4+15 x}{5 x+1}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{15 \cdot(5 x+1)-(4+15 x) \cdot 5}{(5 x+1)^{2}}=\frac{75 x+15-20-75 x}{(5 x+1)^{2}}= \\
& =-\frac{5}{(5 x+1)^{2}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{5}{(5 x+1)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{5 \cdot(-2)}{(5 x+1)^{3}} \cdot 5=\frac{2 \cdot 5^{2}}{(5 x+1)^{3}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2 \cdot 5^{2}}{(5 x+1)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{2 \cdot(-3) \cdot 5^{2}}{(5 x+1)^{4}} \cdot 5=-\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5^{3}}{(5 x+1)^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Obviously,

$y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n} \cdot n!\cdot 5^{n}}{(5 x+1)^{n+1}}$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{2 \operatorname{sh} t}{\operatorname{ch}^{3} t}\right) /(\operatorname{ch} t)=\frac{2 \operatorname{sh} t}{\operatorname{ch}^{4} t} \\

& =2 \cdot \frac{\operatorname{ch}^{2} t-4 \operatorname{sh}^{2} t}{\operatorname{ch}^{5} t}=\frac{2-6 \operatorname{sh}^{2} t}{\operatorname{ch}^{5} t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$

$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0):$

$f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}\tan\left(x^{3}+x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{x}\right)\right), x \neq 0 \\ 0, x=0\end{array}\right.$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan\left(\Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)\right)-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan\left(\Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)\right)}{\Delta x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tan\left(\Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)\right) \sim \Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right), \text { as } \\
& \Delta x \rightarrow 0\left(\Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right) \rightarrow 0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x^{3}+\Delta x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \Delta x^{2}+\Delta x \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)=$

Since $\sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right)$ is bounded, then

$$
\Delta x \cdot \sin \left(\frac{2}{\Delta x}\right) \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } \Delta x \rightarrow 0
$$

Thus:
$=0^{2}+0=0$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=0$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\frac{3 t^{2}+1}{3 t^{3}} \\
y=\sin \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{t}^{\prime} & =\left(\frac{3 t^{2}+1}{3 t^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{t}+\frac{1}{3 t^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{t^{2}}-\frac{1}{t^{4}}=-\frac{t^{2}+1}{t^{4}} \\
y_{t}^{\prime} & =\left(\sin \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right)\right)^{\prime}=\cos \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right) \cdot\left(t^{2}+1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\cos \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right) \cdot\left(t^{2}+1\right)\right) /\left(-\frac{t^{2}+1}{t^{4}}\right)=-\frac{t^{4} \cdot \cos \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right) \cdot\left(t^{2}+1\right)}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)}= \\
& =-t^{4} \cdot \cos \left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}+t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

## Task Condition

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=x \cdot e^{a x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y=x \cdot e^{a x}$

$y^{\prime}=\left(x \cdot e^{a x}\right)^{\prime}=e^{a x}+x \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a=(1+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x}$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left((1+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x}\right)^{\prime}=a \cdot e^{a x}+(1+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a=$

$=(2+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left((2+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a\right)^{\prime}=a \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a+(2+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a \cdot a=$
$=(3+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a^{2}$

Obviously,

$y^{(n)}=(n+a \cdot x) \cdot e^{a x} \cdot a^{n-1}$

$$

& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{5}} \ln \frac{2+\sqrt{5} \tanh x}{2-\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{5}} \cdot \frac{2-\sqrt{5} \tanh x}{2+\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x} \cdot\left(\frac{2+\sqrt{5} \tanh x}{2-\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{5}} \cdot \frac{2-\sqrt{5} \tanh x}{2+\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x} \cdot \frac{\frac{\sqrt{5}}{\cosh^{2} x} \cdot(2-\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x)-(2+\sqrt{5} \tanh x) \cdot\left(-\frac{\sqrt{5}}{\cosh^{2} x}\right)}{(2-\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{5}} \cdot \frac{1}{2+\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x} \cdot \frac{\frac{4 \sqrt{5}}{\cosh^{2} x}}{2-\sqrt{5} \cdot \tanh x}=\frac{1}{\left(4-5 \tanh^{2} x\right) \cosh^{2} x}= \\
& =\frac{1}{4 \cosh^{2} x-5 \sinh^{2} x}=\frac{1}{4-\sinh^{2} x}
\end{aligned}
$$

Find the derivative.

$y=(\arctan x)^{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln (\arctan x)}$

## Solution

$y=(\arctan x)^{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln (\arctan x)}$

$\ln y=\ln (\arctan x)^{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln (\arctan x)}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln (\arctan x) \cdot \ln (\arctan x)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln ^{2}(\arctan x)$

$\frac{y^{\prime}}{y}=\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln ^{2}(\arctan x)\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \ln (\arctan x) \cdot \frac{1}{\arctan x} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{\ln (\arctan x)}{\arctan x \cdot\left(1+x^{2}\right)}$

$y^{\prime}=y \cdot \frac{\ln (\arctan x)}{\arctan x \cdot\left(1+x^{2}\right)}=(\arctan x)^{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln (\arctan x)} \cdot \frac{\ln (\arctan x)}{\arctan x \cdot\left(1+x^{2}\right)}$

## Task Condition

Find the second-order derivative $y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}$ of the function given parametrically.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\cos 2 t \\
y=2 \sec ^{2} t
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=(\cos 2 t)^{\prime}=-2 \sin 2 t$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(2 \sec ^{2} t\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{\cos ^{2} t}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{4}{\cos ^{3} t} \cdot(-\sin t)=\frac{4 \sin t}{\cos ^{3} t}$

We obtain:

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{4 \sin t}{\cos ^{3} t}\right) /(-2 \sin 2 t)=-\frac{4 \sin t}{2 \cos ^{3} t \cdot \sin 2 t}=$

$=-\frac{4 \sin t}{4 \cos ^{4} t \cdot \sin t}=-\frac{1}{\cos ^{4} t}$

$\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{1}{\cos ^{4} t}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{-4}{\cos ^{5} t} \cdot(-\sin t)=-\frac{4 \sin t}{\cos ^{5} t}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(-\frac{4 \sin t}{\cos ^{5} t}\right) /(-2 \sin 2 t)=\frac{4 \sin t}{2 \cos ^{5} t \cdot \sin 2 t}= \\
& =\frac{4 \sin t}{4 \cos ^{6} t \cdot \sin t}=\frac{1}{\cos ^{6} t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Approximately calculate using the differential.

original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{0 \text{ of the argument }} x$ is small in absolute value, then

$f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 2$

Then:

$\Delta x = 0.002$

Calculate:
$y(2) = 2^{7} = 128$

$y^{\prime} = \left(x^{7}\right)^{\prime} = 7 x^{6}$

$y^{\prime}(2) = 7 \cdot 2^{6} = 448$

We get:

$y(2.002) \approx y(2) + y^{\prime}(2) \cdot 0.002 = 128 + 448 \cdot 0.002 = 128.896$

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

To derive the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$y=\frac{x}{x^{2}+1}, x_{0}=-2$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{x}{x^{2}+1}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{x^{\prime}\left(x^{2}+1\right)-x\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{\prime}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{x^{2}+1-x \cdot 2 x}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{1-x^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1-(-2)^{2}}{\left((-2)^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{-3}{5^{2}}=-\frac{3}{25}$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$, where

$y_{0}^{\prime}=-\frac{3}{25}$

$y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{-2}{(-2)^{2}+1}=-\frac{2}{5}$

We get:

$y-\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)=-\frac{3}{25} \cdot(x-(-2))$

$y=-\frac{3}{25} \cdot(x+2)-\frac{2}{5}$

$y=-\frac{3}{25} \cdot x-\frac{6}{25}-\frac{2}{5}$

$y=-\frac{3}{25} \cdot x-\frac{16}{25}$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is:

$$
y=-\frac{3}{25} \cdot x-\frac{16}{25}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$:

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
3^{x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{x}}-1+2 x, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(3^{\Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}}-1+2 x-0\right) / \Delta x= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(\left(e^{\ln 3}\right)^{\Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}}-1-2 \Delta x\right) / \Delta x= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln 3 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}}-1\right) / \Delta x-\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \Delta x}{\Delta x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
e^{\ln 3 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}}-1 \sim \Delta \ln 3 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}_{, \text {as }} \Delta x \rightarrow 0\left(\ln 3 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x} \rightarrow 0\right)
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(\ln 3 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}\right) / \Delta x-\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} 2= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \ln 3 \cdot \Delta x \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}-2=
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\sin \frac{2}{\Delta x}$ is bounded, then

$$
\Delta x \cdot \sin \frac{2}{\Delta x} \rightarrow 0, \text { as } \Delta x \rightarrow 0
$$

Thus

$=\ln 3 \cdot 0-2=-2$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=-2$

\end{aligned}

$=\frac{1}{2+2 \sin x+2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot d x=\frac{1}{2+2 \sin x+\cos x+1} \cdot d x=$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=-\frac{1}{4} \arcsin \frac{5+3 \operatorname{ch} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{1}{4} \arcsin \frac{5+3 \operatorname{ch} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{5+3 \operatorname{ch} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}\right)^{2}}} \cdot \frac{3 \operatorname{sh} x \cdot(3+5 \operatorname{ch} x)-(5+3 \operatorname{ch} x) \cdot 5 \operatorname{sh} x}{(3+5 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}{\sqrt{(3+5 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}-(5+3 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}}} \cdot \frac{9 \operatorname{sh} x+15 \cdot \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x-25 \operatorname{sh} x-15 \operatorname{ch} x \cdot \operatorname{sh} x}{(3+5 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{9+30 \operatorname{ch} x+25 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-25-30 \operatorname{ch} x-9 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{9 \operatorname{sh} x-25 \operatorname{sh} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{16 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-16}} \cdot \frac{-16 \operatorname{sh} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{\operatorname{ch}^{2} x-1}} \cdot \frac{4 \operatorname{sh} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{\operatorname{sh} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{1}{\operatorname{sh} x} \cdot \frac{\operatorname{sh} x}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{1}{3+5 \operatorname{ch} x}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{2}{3}\left(4 x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-x}+(2 x-1)^{4} \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}, 2 x-1>0
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\left(4 x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-x}+(2 x-1)^{4} \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{2}{3}\left((8 x-4) \sqrt{x^{2}-x}+\left(4 x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-x}} \cdot(2 x-1)\right)+ \\
& +\left(4(2 x-1) \cdot 2 \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}+(2 x-1)^{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{2 x-1}\right)^{2}}} \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{(2 x-1)^{2}} \cdot 2\right)\right)= \\
& =\frac{2}{3}\left(\frac{4(2 x-1) \cdot\left(x^{2}-x\right)}{\sqrt{x^{2}-x}}+\left(4 x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-x}} \cdot(2 x-1)\right)+ \\
& +8(2 x-1) \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}-(2 x-1)^{2} \cdot \frac{2 x-1}{\sqrt{(2 x-1)^{2}-1}} \cdot 2= \\
& =\frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{2 x-1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-x}} \cdot\left(8 x^{2}-8 x+4 x^{2}-4 x+3\right)+8(2 x-1) \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}-\frac{(2 x-1)^{3}}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-x}} \cdot 2= \\
& =\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{2 x-1}{\sqrt{x^{2}-x}} \cdot 3\left(4 x^{2}-4 x+1\right)+8(2 x-1) \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}-\frac{(2 x-1)^{3}}{\sqrt{x^{2}-x}}= \\
& =\frac{(2 x-1)^{2}}{\sqrt{x^{2}-x}}+8(2 x-1) \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}-\frac{(2 x-1)^{3}}{\sqrt{x^{2}-x}}=8(2 x-1) \cdot \arcsin \frac{1}{2 x-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{4^{x}(\ln 4 \cdot \sin 4 x-4 \cos 4 x)}{16+\ln ^{2} 4}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{4^{x}(\ln 4 \cdot \sin 4 x-4 \cos 4 x)}{16+\ln ^{2} 4}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{1}{16+\ln ^{2} 4} \cdot\left(4^{x} \cdot \ln 4 \cdot(\ln 4 \cdot \sin 4 x-4 \cos 4 x)+4^{x}(4 \ln 4 \cdot \cos 4 x+16 \sin 4 x)\right)=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{4^{x}}{16+\ln ^{2} 4} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 4 \cdot \sin 4 x-4 \ln 4 \cdot \cos 4 x+4 \ln 4 \cdot \cos 4 x+16 \sin 4 x\right)= \\
& =\frac{4^{x}}{16+\ln ^{2} 4} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 4 \cdot \sin 4 x+16 \sin 4 x\right)=\frac{4^{x} \cdot \sin 4 x}{16+\ln ^{2} 4} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 4+16\right)=4^{x} \cdot \sin 4 x
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=t \sqrt{t^{2}+1} \\
y=\ln \frac{1+\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(t \sqrt{t^{2}+1}\right)^{\prime}=\sqrt{t^{2}+1}+t \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t^{2}+1}} \cdot 2 t=\sqrt{t^{2}+1}+\frac{t^{2}}{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}=$

$=\frac{t^{2}+1+t^{2}}{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}=\frac{2 t^{2}+1}{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\ln \frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}{t}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{t}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t) \cdot t-\left(1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\right) \cdot 1}{t^{2}}=$

$=\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-t^{2}-\sqrt{1-t^{2}}-\left(1-t^{2}\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-\left(\sqrt{1-t^{2}}+1\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=$ $=-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}$

We obtain:

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right) /\left(\frac{2 t^{2}+1}{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}} \cdot\left(2 t^{2}+1\right)}=$

$=-\frac{1}{t\left(2 t^{2}+1\right)}$

llm_response:

The solution includes straightforward differentiation of both \( x \) and \( y \) with respect to \( t \), and then applying the quotient of these derivatives to find \( y_{x}^{\prime} \).

original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=(\sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}})^{\prime}=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1})^{3}}} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x+1}}\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1})^{3}}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}{2 \sqrt{x} \cdot \sqrt{x+1}}=\frac{\sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}}{8 \sqrt{x(x+1)}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute into equation (1):

$8 \cdot x \cdot \frac{\sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}}{8 \sqrt{x(x+1)}}-\sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}=\frac{-1}{\sqrt[4]{(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1})^{3}} \cdot \sqrt{x+1}}$

Simplify:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt[4]{(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1})^{3}} \cdot \sqrt{x+1} \cdot \sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{\sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}}{\sqrt{x+1}}- \\
& -\sqrt[4]{(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1})^{3}} \cdot \sqrt{x+1} \cdot \sqrt[4]{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}}=-1 \\
& (\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}) \cdot \sqrt{x}-(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x+1}) \cdot \sqrt{x+1}=-1 \\
& x+\sqrt{x(x+1)}-\sqrt{x(x+1)}-(x+1)=-1 \\
& x-x-1=-1 \\
& 0=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The equality holds. The function $y_{\text {satisfies equation (1). }}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the second-order derivative $y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}$ of the function given parametrically.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\cos t \\
y=\ln (\sin t)
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=(\cos t)^{\prime}=-\sin t$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=(\ln (\sin t))^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sin t} \cdot \cos t=\frac{\cos t}{\sin t}$

We obtain:

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{\cos t}{\sin t}\right) /(-\sin t)=-\frac{\cos t}{\sin ^{2} t}$

$\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{\cos t}{\sin ^{2} t}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{-\sin t \cdot \sin ^{2} t-\cos t \cdot 2 \sin t \cdot \cos t}{\sin ^{4} t}=$

$=\frac{\sin ^{2} t+2 \cos ^{2} t}{\sin ^{3} t}=\frac{1+\cos ^{2} t}{\sin ^{3} t}$

Then:

$y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{1+\cos ^{2} t}{\sin ^{3} t}\right) /(-\sin t)=-\frac{1+\cos ^{2} t}{\sin ^{4} t}$

Find the derivative.

original.solution:
## Solution

$y=(\sin \sqrt{x})^{e^{1 / x}}$

$\ln y=e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot \ln (\sin \sqrt{x})$

$\frac{y^{\prime}}{y}=\left(e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot \ln (\sin \sqrt{x})\right)^{\prime}=e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \cdot \ln (\sin \sqrt{x})+e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin \sqrt{x}} \cdot \cos \sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}=$

$=e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot\left(\frac{\ln (\sin \sqrt{x})}{x}+\frac{\tan \sqrt{x}}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right)$

$y^{\prime}=y \cdot e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot\left(\frac{\ln (\sin \sqrt{x})}{x}+\frac{\tan \sqrt{x}}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right)=(\sin \sqrt{x})^{e^{1 / x}} \cdot e^{\frac{1}{x}} \cdot\left(\frac{\ln (\sin \sqrt{x})}{x}+\frac{\tan \sqrt{x}}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right)$

## Problem Statement

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=a^{2 x+3}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y=a^{2 x+3}=a^{2 x} \cdot a^{3}=\left(e^{\ln a}\right)^{2 x} \cdot a^{3}=e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot a^{3}$

$y^{\prime}=\left(e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot a^{3}\right)^{\prime}=e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot 2 \ln a \cdot a^{3}$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot 2 \ln a \cdot a^{3}\right)^{\prime}=e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot 2^{2} \cdot \ln ^{2} a \cdot a^{3}$

$\cdots$

Obviously,
$y^{(n)}=e^{2 x \cdot \ln a} \cdot 2^{n} \cdot \ln ^{n} a \cdot a^{3}=a^{2 x} \cdot 2^{n} \cdot \ln ^{n} a \cdot a^{3}=$ $=a^{2 x+3} \cdot 2^{n} \cdot \ln ^{n} a$

Find the derivative.

$y=\operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x^{2}-1}-\frac{\ln x}{\sqrt{x^{2}-1}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x^{2}-1}-\frac{\ln x}{\sqrt{x^{2}-1}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{1+\left(\sqrt{x^{2}-1}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-1}} \cdot 2 x-\frac{\frac{1}{x} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}-1}-\ln x \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-1}} \cdot 2 x}{x^{2}-1}= \\
& =\frac{1}{1+x^{2}-1} \cdot \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}-1}}-\frac{x^{2}-1-\ln x \cdot x^{2}}{x \cdot\left(x^{2}-1\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}-1}}+\frac{\ln x \cdot x^{2}+1-x^{2}}{x \cdot\left(x^{2}-1\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}= \\
& =\frac{x^{2}-1}{x \cdot\left(x^{2}-1\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}+\frac{\ln x \cdot x^{2}+1-x^{2}}{x \cdot\left(x^{2}-1\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}= \\
& =\frac{\ln x \cdot x^{2}}{x \cdot\left(x^{2}-1\right) \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}=\frac{x \cdot \ln x}{\sqrt{\left(x^{2}-1\right)^{3}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=\frac{\ln (2 x+5)}{2 x+5}, y^{\prime \prime \prime}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\ln (2 x+5)}{2 x+5}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{1}{2 x+5} \cdot 2 \cdot(2 x+5)-\ln (2 x+5) \cdot 2}{(2 x+5)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{2-2 \ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{2}}=2 \cdot \frac{1-\ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{2}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(2 \cdot \frac{1-\ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =2 \cdot \frac{-\frac{1}{2 x+5} \cdot 2 \cdot(2 x+5)^{2}-(1-\ln (2 x+5)) \cdot 2(2 x+5) \cdot 2}{(2 x+5)^{4}}= \\
& =2 \cdot \frac{-2-4(1-\ln (2 x+5))}{(2 x+5)^{3}}=-4 \cdot \frac{1+2(1-\ln (2 x+5))}{(2 x+5)^{3}}= \\
& =-4 \cdot \frac{3-2 \ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{3}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-4 \cdot \frac{3-2 \ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =-4 \cdot \frac{\frac{-2}{2 x+5} \cdot 2 \cdot(2 x+5)^{3}-(3-2 \ln (2 x+5)) \cdot 3(2 x+5)^{2} \cdot 2}{(2 x+5)^{6}}= \\
& =-8 \cdot \frac{-2-3(3-2 \ln (2 x+5))}{(2 x+5)^{4}}=-8 \cdot \frac{-11+6 \ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{4}}= \\
& =\frac{88-48 \ln (2 x+5)}{(2 x+5)^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3^{x+1}-3}{\ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right)}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3^{x+1}-3}{\ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right)}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3\left(3^{x}-1\right)}{\ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3\left(\left(e^{\ln 3}\right)^{x}-1\right)}{\ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right)}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3\left(e^{x \ln 3}-1\right)}{\ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right)}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{x \ln 3}-1 \sim x \ln 3, \text { as } x \rightarrow 0(x \ln 3 \rightarrow 0) \\
& \ln \left(1+x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}\right) \sim x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}, \text { as } \\
& \ln \rightarrow 0\left(x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}} \rightarrow 0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 x \ln 3}{x \sqrt{1+x e^{x}}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 \ln 3}{\sqrt{1+x e^{x}}}=$

$$
=\frac{3 \ln 3}{\sqrt{1+0 \cdot e^{0}}}=\frac{3 \ln 3}{1}=3 \ln 3
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:

$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[4]{11 n}+\sqrt{25 n^{4}-81}}{(n-7 \sqrt{n}) \sqrt{n^{2}-n+1}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[4]{11 n}+\sqrt{25 n^{4}-81}}{(n-7 \sqrt{n}) \sqrt{n^{2}-n+1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(n \sqrt[4]{11 n}+\sqrt{25 n^{4}-81}\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{2}}(n-7 \sqrt{n}) \sqrt{n^{2}-n+1}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[4]{\frac{11}{n^{3}}}+\sqrt{25-\frac{81}{n^{4}}}}{\left(\frac{1}{n}(n-7 \sqrt{n})\right)\left(\frac{1}{n} \sqrt{n^{2}-n+1}\right)}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[4]{\frac{11}{n^{3}}}+\sqrt{25-\frac{81}{n^{4}}}}{\left(1-7 \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}}\right) \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{n}+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}}= \\
& =\frac{\sqrt[4]{0}+\sqrt{25-0}}{(1-7 \sqrt{0}) \sqrt{1-0+0}}=\frac{5}{1}=5
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}-\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}\right)
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}-\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}\right)= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}-\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}\right)\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}\right)}{\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)-\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}{\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{4}+n^{2}+2 n^{2}+2-n^{4}+n^{2}+2 n^{2}-2}{\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{6 n^{2}}{\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{2}} 6 n^{2}}{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{2}+1\right)\left(n^{2}+2\right)}+\sqrt{\left(n^{2}-1\right)\left(n^{2}-2\right)}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{6}{\sqrt{\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{2}{n^{2}}\right)}+\sqrt{\left(1-\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)\left(1-\frac{2}{n^{2}}\right)}}= \\
& =\frac{6}{\sqrt{(1+0)(1+0)}+\sqrt{(1-0)(1-0)}}=\frac{6}{2}=3
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
Condition of the problem

Calculate the limit of the function:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}-3 x-2}{x^{2}+2 x+1}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}-3 x-2}{x^{2}+2 x+1}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{(x+1)\left(x^{2}-x-2\right)}{(x+1)^{2}}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{2}-x-2}{x+1}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{(x+1)(x-2)}{x+1}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow-1}(x-2)=-1-2=-3
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\sqrt{\cos x}}{x \cdot \sin x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's use the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

$\sin x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\sqrt{\cos x}}{x \cdot \sin x}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(1-\sqrt{\cos x})(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}{x \cdot x(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos x}{x^{2}(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{x^{2}}{2}}{x^{2}(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2(1+\sqrt{\cos x})}=\frac{1}{2(1+\sqrt{\cos 0})}=\frac{1}{2 \cdot 2}=\frac{1}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x+h}+a^{x-h}-2 a^{x}}{h}$
original.solution:
Solution

$\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x+h}+a^{x-h}-2 a^{x}}{h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x+h}-a^{x}+a^{x-h}-a^{x}}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x+h}-a^{x}}{h}+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x-h}-a^{x}}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(a^{h}-1\right)}{h}+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(a^{-h}-1\right)}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(\left(e^{\ln a}\right)^{h}-1\right)}{h}+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(\left(e^{\ln a}\right)^{-h}-1\right)}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(e^{h \ln a}-1\right)}{h}+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x}\left(e^{-h \ln a}-1\right)}{h}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{h \ln a}-1 \sim h \ln a$, as $h \rightarrow 0(h \ln a \rightarrow 0)$

$e^{-h \ln a}-1 \sim -h \ln a$, as $h \rightarrow 0(-h \ln a \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x} \cdot h \ln a}{h}+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{a^{x} \cdot(-h) \ln a}{h}=$
$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} a^{x} \ln a+\lim _{h \rightarrow 0}-a^{x} \ln a=a^{x} \ln a-a^{x} \ln a=0$

## Condition of the problem

Find the differential $d y$.

$$
y=\cos x \cdot \ln (\operatorname{tg} x)-\ln \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}\right)
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d y=y^{\prime}(x) \cdot \Delta x=y^{\prime}(x) \cdot d x \\
& y^{\prime}=(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x+\cos x \cdot(\ln \operatorname{tg} x)^{\prime}-\left(\operatorname{lntg} \frac{x}{2}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =-\sin x \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x+\cos x \cdot \frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} x} \cdot(\operatorname{tg} x)^{\prime}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =-\sin x \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x+\frac{\cos ^{2} x}{\sin x} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} x}-\frac{\cos \frac{x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2}= \\
& =-\sin x \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x+\frac{1}{\sin x}-\frac{1}{\sin x}=-\sin x \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x \\
& d y=-\sin x \cdot \ln \operatorname{tg} x \cdot d x
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## problem statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$ :

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt[3]{1-2 x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{x}}-1+x, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$$
f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}
$$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1+\Delta x-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1}{\Delta x}+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1\right)\left(\sqrt[3]{\left(1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}\right)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}+1\right)}{\Delta x\left(\sqrt[3]{\left(1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}\right)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}+1\right)}+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} 1= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}-1}{\Delta x\left(\sqrt[3]{\left(1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}\right)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}+1\right)}+1= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}{\Delta x\left(\sqrt[3]{\left(1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}\right)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}+1\right)}+1= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \Delta x^{2} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}{\sqrt[3]{\left(1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}\right)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \Delta x^{3} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}+1}+1= \\
& \text { Since } \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x} \text { is bounded, then }
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Delta x \cdot \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x} \rightarrow 0$, as $\Delta x \rightarrow 0$

Then:

$=\frac{-2 \cdot 0}{\sqrt[3]{(1-2 \cdot 0)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{1-2 \cdot 0}+1}+1=\frac{0}{\sqrt[3]{1}+\sqrt[3]{1}+1}+1=1$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=1$

original.problem:
## problem statement

Find the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$y=3 \sqrt[4]{x}-\sqrt{x}, x_{0}=1$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}$:

$y^{\prime}=(3 \sqrt[4]{x}-\sqrt{x})^{\prime}=\left(3 x^{\frac{1}{4}}-\sqrt{x}\right)^{\prime}=3 \cdot \frac{1}{4} \cdot x^{-\frac{3}{4}}-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}=\frac{3}{4 \sqrt[4]{x^{3}}}-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}$

Then

$y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{3}{4 \sqrt[4]{1^{3}}}-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1}}=\frac{3}{4}-\frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{4}$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$, where

$y_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{4}$

$y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=3 \sqrt[4]{1}-\sqrt{1}=3-1=2$

We get:

$y-2=\frac{1}{4} \cdot(x-1)$

$y=\frac{1}{4} \cdot x-\frac{1}{4}+2$

$y=\frac{x}{4}+\frac{7}{4}$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y=\frac{x}{4}+\frac{7}{4}$

## Problem Statement

Approximately calculate using the differential.

$y=\sqrt{1+x+\sin x}, x=0.01$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y\left(x_{0}+\Delta x\right) \approx y\left(x_{0}\right)^{\prime} \cdot \Delta x+y\left(x_{0}\right)$

$\Delta x=x-x_{0}$

$x=0.01$

$x_{0}=0$

$\Delta x=0.01$

$y\left(x_{0}\right)=y(0)=1$

$y^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \cdot \sqrt{1+x+\sin x}} \cdot(1+x+\sin x)^{\prime}=\frac{1+\cos x}{2 \cdot \sqrt{1+x+\sin x}}$

$y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=y^{\prime}(0)=\frac{1+1}{2 \cdot(1+0+0)}=1$

$\sqrt{1+0.01+\sin 0.01} \approx 1 \cdot 0.01+1=1.01$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\ln \frac{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y=\ln \frac{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}}=\ln \left(\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)-\ln \left(\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)$

$y'=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)'-\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)'=$

$=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left[\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)'\right]-\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left[-\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)'\right]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{-1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}\right)=$

$=\frac{1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{5}-\tan \frac{x}{2}+\sqrt{5}+\tan \frac{x}{2}}{5-\tan ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \cdot \frac{2 \sqrt{5}}{5-\tan ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}=$

$=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{5 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}-\sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{6 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}-1}$.

## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\sqrt[7]{\tan(\cos 2)}+\frac{\sin ^{2} 27 x}{27 \cos 54 x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=(\sqrt[7]{\operatorname{tg}(\cos 2)})^{\prime}+\left(\frac{\sin ^{2} 27 x}{27 \cos 54 x}\right)^{\prime}=0+\frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{\sin ^{2} 27 x}{\cos 54 x}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{\left(\sin ^{2} 27 x\right)^{\prime} \cos 54 x-\sin ^{2} 27 x(\cos 54 x)^{\prime}}{\cos 54 x}\right)=$

$=\frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{2 \sin 27 x \cdot \cos 27 x \cdot 27 \cdot \cos 54 x-\sin ^{2} 27 x \cdot(-\sin 54 x) \cdot 54}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}\right)=$

$=\frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{\sin 54 x \cdot 27 \cdot \cos 54 x+\sin ^{2} 27 x \cdot \sin 54 x \cdot 54}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}\right)=$
$=\frac{1}{27}\left(\frac{27 \sin 54 x \cdot\left(\cos 54 x+54 \sin ^{2} 27 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}\right)=\frac{\sin 54 x \cdot\left(\cos ^{2} 27 x-\sin ^{2} 27 x+2 \sin ^{2} 27 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}=$

$=\frac{\sin 54 x \cdot\left(\cos ^{2} 27 x+\sin ^{2} 27 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}=\frac{\sin 54 x}{\cos ^{2} 54 x}=\sin 54 x \cdot \sec ^{2} 54 x=\operatorname{tg} 54 x \cdot \sec 54 x$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}\left(\sqrt[3]{x^{5}}-5 \sqrt[3]{x^{4}}+20 x-60 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}+120 \sqrt[3]{x}-120\right)
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

In the process of solving, we will introduce a substitution (to shorten the notation)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\sqrt[3]{x^{5}}-5 \sqrt[3]{x^{4}}+20 x-60 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}+120 \sqrt[3]{x}-120\right]=(\sim)} \\
& y'=\left(3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}\right)'(\sim)+3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}(\sim)'= \\
& =\frac{3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}}{3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}(\sim)+3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}} \times\left[\frac{5}{3} \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}-5 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \sqrt[3]{x}+20-60 \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{x}}+120 \cdot \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}-0\right]= \\
& =3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}\left[\frac{(\sim)}{3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}+\frac{5}{3} \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}-\frac{20}{3} \sqrt[3]{x}+20-40 \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{x}}+\frac{40}{\sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}\right]= \\
& =3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}\left[\frac{(\sim)+5\left(\sqrt[3]{x^{2}}\right)^{2}-20 \sqrt[3]{x} \cdot \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}+60 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}-120 \sqrt[3]{x}+120}{3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}\right]= \\
& =3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}\left[\frac{\sqrt[3]{x^{5}}-5 \sqrt[3]{x^{4}}+20 x-60 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}+120 \sqrt[3]{x}-120+5 \sqrt[3]{x^{4}}-20 x+60 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}-120 \sqrt[3]{x}+120}{3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}\right]=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=3 e^{\sqrt[3]{x}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt[3]{x^{5}}}{3 \sqrt[3]{x^{2}}}=e^{\sqrt[3]{x}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{x^{5}}{x^{2}}}=x \cdot e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$$
y=2 \frac{\cos x}{\sin ^{4} x}+3 \frac{\cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=2 \frac{(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \sin ^{4} x-\cos x\left(\sin ^{4} x\right)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{8} x}+3 \frac{(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \sin ^{2} x-\cos x\left(\sin ^{2} x\right)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{4} x}= \\
& =2 \frac{-\sin ^{5} x-4 \sin ^{3} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{8} x}+3 \frac{-\sin ^{3} x-2 \sin x \cdot \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{4} x}=2 \frac{-\sin ^{2} x-4 \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}+3 \frac{-\sin ^{2} x-2 \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{3} x}= \\
& =\frac{-2 \sin ^{2} x-8\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right)}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{-3 \sin ^{2} x-6\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right)}{\sin ^{3} x}= \\
& =\frac{-2 \sin ^{2} x-8+8 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{-3 \sin ^{2} x-6+6 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{3} x}=\frac{6 \sin ^{2} x-8}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{3 \sin ^{2} x-6}{\sin ^{3} x}=\frac{6 \sin ^{2} x-8+3 \sin ^{4} x-6 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}= \\
& =\frac{3}{\sin x}-\frac{8}{\sin ^{5} x}=3 \operatorname{cosec} x-8 \operatorname{cosec}^{5} x
\end{aligned}
$$

$y^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{(x \cdot \arcsin 2 x)^{\prime} \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}-x \cdot \arcsin 2 x\left(\sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}\right)^{\prime}}{1-4 x^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{8} \cdot \frac{1}{1-4 x^{2}} \cdot\left(1-4 x^{2}\right)^{\prime}=$ $=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\left(x^{\prime} \cdot \arcsin 2 x+x \cdot(\arcsin 2 x)^{\prime}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}-x \cdot \arcsin 2 x \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}} \cdot\left(1-4 x^{2}\right)^{\prime}}{1-4 x^{2}}\right)-\frac{8 x}{8\left(1-4 x^{2}\right)}=$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\left(\arcsin 2 x+\frac{2 x}{\sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}+\frac{8 x^{2}}{2 \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}} \cdot \arcsin 2 x}{1-4 x^{2}}\right)-\frac{x}{1-4 x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\sqrt{1-4 x^{2}} \cdot \arcsin 2 x+2 x+\frac{4 x^{2} \cdot \arcsin 2 x}{\sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}}{1-4 x^{2}}\right)-\frac{x}{1-4 x^{2}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\frac{\left(1-4 x^{2}\right) \cdot \arcsin 2 x+2 x \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}+4 x^{2} \cdot \arcsin 2 x}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}}{1-4 x^{2}}\right)-\frac{x}{1-4 x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\arcsin 2 x-4 x^{2} \arcsin 2 x+2 x \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}+4 x^{2} \cdot \arcsin 2 x}{\left(1-4 x^{2}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}\right)-\frac{x}{1-4 x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{\arcsin 2 x+2 x \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}{2\left(1-4 x^{2}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}-\frac{x}{1-4 x^{2}}=\frac{\arcsin 2 x+2 x \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}-2 x \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}{2\left(1-4 x^{2}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}=\frac{\arcsin 2 x}{2\left(1-4 x^{2}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1-4 x^{2}}}$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=x^{e^{\operatorname{arctan} x}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\ln y=e^{\operatorname{arctg} x} \cdot \ln x$

$(\ln y)^{\prime}=\left(e^{\operatorname{arctg} x}\right)^{\prime} \cdot \ln x+e^{\operatorname{arctg} x} \cdot(\ln x)^{\prime}=e^{\operatorname{arctg} x} \cdot(\operatorname{arctg} x)^{\prime} \cdot \ln x+e^{\operatorname{arctg} x} \cdot \frac{1}{x}=$ $=e^{\operatorname{arctg} x}\left(\frac{\ln x}{1+x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x}\right)$

$(\ln y)^{\prime}=\frac{y^{\prime}}{y} \Longrightarrow y^{\prime}=y \cdot(\ln y)^{\prime}$

$y^{\prime}=x^{e^{\operatorname{arctg} x}} \cdot e^{\operatorname{arctg} x}\left(\frac{\ln x}{1+x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x}\right)$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{\sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x^{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \ln \frac{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\frac{\left(\sqrt{x^{2}+2}\right)^{\prime} \cdot x^{2}-2 x \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x^{4}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{x}{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{x^{2}+2}} \cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}+2}} \cdot 2 x \cdot x^{2}-2 x \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x^{4}}-\frac{x}{2+\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}} \cdot\left(\frac{\left(\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{x^{2}+2}\right)^{\prime} \cdot x-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x^{2}}\right)= \\
& =\frac{2 x^{3}-4 x\left(x^{2}+2\right)}{2 x^{4} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}-\frac{x}{2+\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}} \cdot\left(\frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}+2}} \cdot 2 x \cdot x-\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{x^{2}+2}}{x^{2}}\right)= \\
& =\frac{-2 x^{3}-8 x}{2 x^{4} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}-\frac{x}{2+\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}} \cdot\left(\frac{2 x^{2}-\sqrt{2} \cdot 2 \sqrt{x^{2}+2}-2\left(x^{2}+2\right)}{2 x^{2} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}\right)= \\
& =\frac{-2 x^{3}-8 x}{2 x^{4} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}-\frac{x}{2+\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}} \cdot\left(\frac{-2 \sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}-4}{2 x^{2} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}\right)= \\
& =\frac{-2 x^{2}-8}{2 x^{3} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}+\frac{2 x\left(\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}+2\right)}{\left(2+\sqrt{2 x^{2}+4}\right)\left(2 x^{2} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}\right)}=\frac{-2 x^{2}-8+2 x^{2}}{2 x^{3} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}=-\frac{4}{x^{3} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\ln (\operatorname{tg} t) \\
y=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} t}
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y^{\prime}(t)}{x^{\prime}(t)}$

$y^{\prime}(t)=\left(1 / \sin ^{2} t\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{2 \sin t \cdot \cos t}{\sin ^{4} t}=-\frac{\sin 2 t}{\sin ^{4} t}$

$x^{\prime}(t)=(\ln \operatorname{tg} t)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} t} \cdot(\operatorname{tg} t)^{\prime}=\frac{\cos t}{\sin t} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} t}=\frac{1}{\cos t \cdot \sin t}$

$y_{x}^{\prime}=-\frac{\sin 2 t}{\sin ^{4} t} \cdot \cos t \cdot \sin t=-\frac{2 \sin t \cdot \cos t \cdot \cos t}{\sin ^{3} t}=-2 \operatorname{ctg}^{2} t$.

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=\frac{\ln (x-2)}{x-2}, y^{V}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution № 1

Let's represent the original function as a product of 2 functions:
$y=\ln (x-2) \cdot(x-2)^{-1} \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}u=\ln (x-2), \\ v=(x-2)^{-1} .\end{array}\right.$

Find the fifth derivative of both functions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ u = \operatorname { l n } ( x - 2 ) , } \\
{ v = ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 1 } ; }
\end{array} \Rightarrow \left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ u ^ { \prime } = ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 1 } , } \\
{ v ^ { \prime } = - ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 2 } ; }
\end{array} \Rightarrow \left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ u ^ { \prime \prime } = - ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 2 } , } \\
{ v ^ { \prime \prime } = 2 ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 3 } ; }
\end{array} \Rightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
u^{\prime \prime \prime}=2(x-2)^{-3}, \\
v^{\prime \prime \prime}=-6(x-2)^{-4} ;
\end{array} \Rightarrow\right.\right.\right.\right. \\
& \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ u ^ { ( 4 ) } = - 6 ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 4 } , } \\
{ v ^ { ( 4 ) } = 2 4 ( x - 2 ) ^ { - 5 } ; }
\end{array} \Rightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
u^{(5)}=24(x-2)^{-5}, \\
v^{(5)}=-120(x-2)^{-6} .
\end{array}\right.\right. \\
& (u \cdot v)^{(n)}=\sum_{i=0}^{n} C_{n}^{i} \cdot u^{(i)} \cdot v^{(n-i)}, \quad C_{n}^{i}=\frac{n!}{i!(n-i)!} \text { - binomial coefficient, }
\end{aligned}
$$

which can also be determined using Pascal's triangle, let's find these coefficients:

$C_{5}^{0}=1 ; C_{5}^{1}=5=C_{5}^{4} ; C_{5}^{2}=10=C_{5}^{3} ; C_{5}^{5}=1$.

$y^{(5)}=C_{5}^{0} \cdot u v^{(5)}+C_{5}^{1} \cdot u^{\prime} v^{(4)}+C_{5}^{2} \cdot u^{\prime \prime} v^{\prime \prime \prime}+C_{5}^{3} \cdot u^{\prime \prime \prime} v^{\prime \prime}+C_{5}^{4} \cdot u^{(4)} v^{\prime}+C_{5}^{5} \cdot u^{(5)} v=$

$=\ln (x-2) \cdot(-120)(x-2)^{-6}+5(x-2)^{-1} \cdot 24(x-2)^{-5}+10 \cdot\left(-1(x-2)^{-2}\right) \cdot\left(-6(x-2)^{-4}\right) \times$

$\times 10 \cdot 2(x-2)^{-3} \cdot 2(x-2)^{-3}+5 \cdot\left(-6(x-2)^{-4}\right) \cdot\left(-1(x-2)^{-2}\right)+24(x-2)^{-5}(x-2)^{-1}=$

$=-120 \ln (x-2) \cdot(x-2)^{-6}+120(x-2)^{-6}+60(x-2)^{-6}+40(x-2)^{-6}+30(x-2)^{-6}+24(x-2)^{-6}=$

$=(x-2)^{-6}(-120 \ln (x-2)+120+60+40+30+24)=\frac{274-120 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{6}}$.

## Solution №2

$y=\frac{\ln (x-2)}{x-2}$

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\ln (x-2)}{x-2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{1}{x-2} \cdot(x-2)-\ln (x-2) \cdot 1}{(x-2)^{2}}=\frac{1-\ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{2}}$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1-\ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-\frac{1}{x-2} \cdot(x-2)^{2}-(1-\ln (x-2)) \cdot 2(x-2)}{(x-2)^{4}}=$

$=\frac{-1-2+2 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{3}}=\frac{-3+2 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{3}}$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{-3+2 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{2}{x-2} \cdot(x-2)^{3}-(-3+2 \ln (x-2)) \cdot 3(x-2)^{2}}{(x-2)^{6}}=$

$=\frac{2+9-6 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{4}}=\frac{11-6 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{4}}$

$y^{(I V)}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{11-6 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{4}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-\frac{6}{x-2} \cdot(x-2)^{4}-(11-6 \ln (x-2)) \cdot 4(x-2)^{3}}{(x-2)^{8}}=$

$=\frac{-6-44+24 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{5}}=\frac{-50+24 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{5}}$
$y^{(V)}=\left(y^{(I V)}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{-50+24 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{5}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{24}{x-2} \cdot(x-2)^{5}-(-50+24 \ln (x-2)) \cdot 5(x-2)^{4}}{(x-2)^{10}}=$ $=\frac{24+250-120 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{6}}=\frac{274-120 \ln (x-2)}{(x-2)^{6}}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{1+\ln x}{x} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

## Method 1

$$
\int \frac{1+\ln x}{x} d x=\int(1+\ln x) d(\ln x)=\ln x+\frac{1}{2} \ln ^{2} x+C
$$

## Method 2

$$
\int \frac{1+\ln x}{x} d x=\int \frac{d x}{x}+\int \frac{\ln x d x}{x} d x=\ln |x|+\int \ln x d(\ln x)=\ln |x|+\frac{1}{2} \ln ^{2} x+C
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{2}+\ln x^{2}}{x} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{2}+\ln x^{2}}{x} d x=\int x \cdot d x+\int \frac{\ln x^{2}}{x} d x=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\int \frac{\ln x^{2}}{x} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\ln x^{2} \\
& d y=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot 2 x \cdot d x=\frac{2}{x} d x \Rightarrow \frac{1}{x} d x=\frac{d y}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\int \frac{y \cdot d y}{2}=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{y^{2}}{4}+C=
$$

After reverse substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{\left(\ln x^{2}\right)^{2}}{4}+C=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{(2 \ln x)^{2}}{4}+C= \\
& =\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{4 \ln ^{2} x}{4}+C=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\ln ^{2} x+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{d x}{x \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{d x}{x \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}=\int \frac{d x}{x \cdot|x| \cdot \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x^{2}}}}=
$$

First, consider the case $x>0$:

$$
=\int \frac{d x}{x^{2} \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{x^{2}}}}=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\frac{1}{x} \Rightarrow y^{2}=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \\
& d y=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} d x \Rightarrow \frac{1}{x^{2}} d x=-d y
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int \frac{-d y}{\sqrt{1-y^{2}}}=-\int \frac{d y}{\sqrt{1-y^{2}}}=-\arcsin y+C=
$$

Reverse substitution:

$$
y=\frac{1}{x}
$$

We get:

$$
=-\arcsin \frac{1}{x}+C
$$

In the case $x<0$, we get:

$$
=\arcsin \frac{1}{x}-C
$$

Since the function $\arcsin x$ is odd, the general solution can be written as:

$$
=-\arcsin \frac{1}{|x|}+C \text { (the sign of the integration constant does not affect the generality) }
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the second-order derivative $y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}$ of the function given parametrically.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=2(t-\sin t) \\
y=4(2+\cos t)
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y^{\prime}(t)}{x^{\prime}(t)}$

$y_{x^{2}}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}}{x^{\prime}(t)}$

$y^{\prime}(t)=4(2+\cos (t))^{\prime}=-4 \sin (t)$

$x^{\prime}(t)=2(t-\sin (t))^{\prime}=2(1-\cos (t))$

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{-4 \sin (t)}{2(1-\cos (t))}=\frac{-2 \sin (t)}{1-\cos (t)}$

$y_{x^{2}}^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{-2 \sin (t)}{1-\cos (t)}\right)^{\prime} \cdot \frac{1}{2(1-\cos (t))}=-\frac{(\sin (t))^{\prime}(1-\cos (t))-\sin (t)(1-\cos (t))^{\prime}}{(1-\cos (t))^{3}}=$

$=\frac{-\cos (t)+\cos ^{2}(t)+\sin ^{2}(t)}{(1-\cos (t))^{3}}=\frac{1}{(1-\cos (t))^{2}}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{d x}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's introduce the substitution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\frac{1}{t} \\
& d x=-\frac{1}{t^{2}} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{d x}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}}=\int \frac{-\frac{1}{t^{2}} d t}{\frac{1}{t} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{t}\right)^{2}+1}}=-\int \frac{d t}{\sqrt{t^{2}+1}}= \\
& =-\ln \left|t+\sqrt{t^{2}+1}\right|+C=-\ln \left|\frac{1+\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}{x}\right|+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{x^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d x=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{x^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d\left(x^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{x^{2}+1-1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d\left(x^{2}\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{1}{x^{2}+1} d\left(x^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d\left(x^{2}\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{1}{x^{2}+1} d\left(x^{2}+1\right)-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{1}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d\left(x^{2}+1\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right)+\frac{1}{2\left(x^{2}+1\right)}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.solution:

\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+x}{x^{4}+1} d x
$$
original.solution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{x^{3}+x}{x^{4}+1} d x=\int \frac{x^{3}}{x^{4}+1} d x+\int \frac{x}{x^{4}+1} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{4} \cdot \int \frac{1}{x^{4}+1} d\left(x^{4}+1\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{1}{x^{4}+1} d\left(x^{2}\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \left|x^{4}+1\right|+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} x^{2}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}}{x^{2}+4} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

## Solution №1

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{x^{3}}{x^{2}+4} d x=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{x^{2}}{x^{2}+4} d\left(x^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{x^{2}+4-4}{x^{2}+4} d\left(x^{2}\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int d\left(x^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{4}{x^{2}+4} d\left(x^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot x^{2}-2 \ln \left(x^{2}+4\right)+C
\end{aligned}
$$

## Solution №2

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}}{x^{2}+4} d x=
$$

Under the integral, there is an improper fraction. Let's separate the integer part:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
x^{3} & \mid x^{2}+4 \\
\frac{x^{3}+4 x}{-4} x
\end{array}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int\left(x-\frac{4 x}{x^{2}+4}\right) d x=\int x d x-4 \int \frac{x d x}{x^{2}+4}=\frac{x^{2}}{2}-2 \int \frac{d\left(x^{2}+4\right)}{x^{2}+4}= \\
& =\frac{x^{2}}{2}-2 \ln \left|x^{2}+4\right|+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x+\frac{1}{x}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{x+\frac{1}{x}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x=\int \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x+\int \frac{1}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int \frac{d\left(x^{2}+1\right)}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}+\int \frac{1}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+1}+\int \frac{1}{x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x= \\
& =\sqrt{x^{2}+1}+\int \frac{1}{x^{2} \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}} d x=\sqrt{x^{2}+1}-\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}} d\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)= \\
& =\sqrt{x^{2}+1}-\ln \left|\frac{1}{x}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{x^{2}}+1}\right|+C=\sqrt{x^{2}+1}-\ln \left|\frac{1+\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}{x}\right|+C
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{\operatorname{arctg} x + x}{1 + x^{2}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{\operatorname{arctg} x + x}{1 + x^2} \, dx = \int \frac{\operatorname{arctg} x}{1 + x^2} \, dx + \int \frac{x}{1 + x^2} \, dx = \\
& = \int \operatorname{arctg} x \, d(\operatorname{arctg} x) + \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d(1 + x^2)}{1 + x^2} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \operatorname{arctg}^2 x + \ln \left| 1 + x^2 \right| \right) + C
\end{aligned}
$$

\begin{aligned}

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{\left(x^{2}-6\right) \sqrt{\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{3}}}{120 x^{55}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\left(x^{2}-6\right) \sqrt{\left(4+x^{2}\right)^{3}}}{120 x^{5}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{\left(2 x \sqrt{\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{3}}+\left(x^{2}-6\right) \cdot \frac{5}{2} \cdot \sqrt{4+x^{2}} \cdot 2 x\right) \cdot x^{5}-\left(x^{2}-6\right) \sqrt{\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{3}} \cdot 5 x^{4}}{120 x^{10}}= \\
& =\frac{2 x^{6}\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{2}+3 x^{6}\left(x^{2}-6\right) \cdot\left(4+x^{2}\right)-5 x^{4} \cdot\left(x^{2}-6\right)\left(4+x^{2}\right)^{2}}{120 x^{10} \sqrt{4+x^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{\left(4+x^{2}\right) \cdot\left(2 x^{6}\left(4+x^{2}\right)+3 x^{6}\left(x^{2}-6\right)-5 x^{4} \cdot\left(x^{2}-6\right)\left(4+x^{-2}\right)\right)}{120 x^{10} \sqrt{4+x^{2}}}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\left(4+x^{2}\right) \cdot\left(8 x^{6}+2 x^{8}+3 x^{8}-18 x^{6}-5 x^{4} \cdot\left(4 x^{2}+x^{4}-24-6 x^{2}\right)\right)}{120 x^{10} \sqrt{4+x^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{\left(4+x^{2}\right) \cdot\left(5 x^{8}-10 x^{6}-20 x^{x^{j}}-5 x^{*}+120 x^{4}+30 x^{6}\right)}{120 x^{10} \sqrt{4+x^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{\left(4+x^{2}\right) \cdot 120 x^{4}}{120 x^{\mathbf{1 0}} \sqrt{4+x^{2}}}=\frac{\sqrt{4+x^{2}}}{x^{6}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate approximately using the differential.

$$
y=\sqrt[3]{x}, x=26.46
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{\text{argument}} x$ is small in absolute value, then $f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x^{x}$

Choose:

$x_{\bar{u}} = 2 \bar{i}$

Then:

$\Delta x = -0.54$

Calculate:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y(27) = \sqrt[3]{27} = 3 \\
& y^{\prime} = (\sqrt[3]{x})^{\prime} = \left(x^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{\prime} = \frac{1}{3} x^{-\frac{2}{3}} \\
& y^{\prime}(2 \overline{7}) = \frac{1}{3} \cdot 27^{-\frac{2}{3}} = \frac{1}{27}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$y(26.16) \approx y\left(2^{-}\right) + y^{\prime}\left(2^{-}\right) \cdot (-0.54) = 3 - \frac{1}{2^{-}} \cdot 0.54 = 2.98$

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{\cos \ln 7 \cdot \sin ^{2} 7 x}{7 \cos 14 x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\cos \ln 7 \cdot \sin ^{2} 7 x}{7 \cos 14 x}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\cos \ln 7}{7} \cdot\left(\frac{\sin ^{2} 7 x}{\cos 14 x}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{\cos \ln 7}{7} \cdot \frac{2 \sin 7 x \cdot \cos 7 x \cdot 7 \cdot \cos 14 x-\sin ^{2} 7 x \cdot(-\sin 14 x) \cdot 14}{\cos ^{2} 14 x}=$

$=\cos \ln 7 \cdot \frac{\sin 14 x \cdot \cos 14 x+2 \sin ^{2} 7 x \cdot \sin 14 x}{\cos ^{2} 14 x}=$

$=\cos \ln 7 \cdot \frac{\sin 14 x \cdot\left(\cos 14 x+2 \sin ^{2} 7 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 14 x}=$

$=\cos \ln 7 \cdot \frac{\sin 14 x \cdot\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} 7 x+2 \sin ^{2} 7 x\right)}{\sin 14 x \quad \begin{array}{c}\cos ^{2} 14 x \\ \cos \ln 7 \cdot \operatorname{tg} 14 x\end{array}}=$

$=\cos \ln 7 \cdot \frac{\sin 14 x}{\cos ^{2} 14 x}=\frac{\cos \ln 7 \cdot \operatorname{tg} 14 x}{\cos 14 x}$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=2 \arcsin \frac{2}{3 x+4}+\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}, 3 x+4>0
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(2 \arcsin \frac{2}{3 x+4}+\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =2 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{2}{3 x+4}\right)^{2}}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}} \cdot(18 x+24)= \\
& =2 \cdot \frac{3 x+4}{\sqrt{(3 x+4)^{2}-4}}+\frac{6(3 x+4)}{2 \sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}}= \\
& =\frac{6 x+8}{\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}}+\frac{3(3 x+4)}{\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}}= \\
& =\frac{6 x+8+18 x+24}{\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}}=\frac{8(3 x+4)}{\sqrt{9 x^{2}+24 x+12}}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$y=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \frac{x-1}{x+1}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} x$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \frac{x-1}{x+1}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{x+1}{x-1} \cdot\left(\frac{x-1}{x+1}\right)^{\prime}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{x+1}{x-1} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot(x+1)-(x-1) \cdot 1}{(x+1)^{2}}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^{2}}=$

$=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{x-1} \cdot \frac{2}{x+1}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x^{2}}=\frac{1}{2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}-\frac{1}{2\left(1+x^{2}\right)}=$

$=\frac{1+x^{2}}{2\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-1\right)}-\frac{x^{2}-1}{2\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-1\right)}=$

$=\frac{2}{2\left(x^{4}-1\right)}=\frac{1}{x^{4}-1}$

original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \frac{3 x-1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{3 x-1}{3 x^{2}-2 x+1}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{3 x-1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)-(3 x-1) \cdot(6 x-2)}{\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{2+(3 x-1)^{2}}+\frac{9 x^{2}-6 x+3-\left(18 x^{2}-6 x-6 x+2\right)}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{3}{2+9 x^{2}-6 x+1}+\frac{-9 x^{2}+6 x+1}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{3}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)}+\frac{-9 x^{2}+6 x+1}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}+\frac{-9 x^{2}+6 x+1}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{9 x^{2}-6 x+3-9 x^{2}+6 x+1}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{4}{3\left(3 x^{2}-2 x+1\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$
