$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{2 a \sqrt{1+a^{2}}} \ln \frac{a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}{a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 a \sqrt{1+a^{2}}} \cdot \frac{a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}{a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x} \cdot\left(\frac{a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}{a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 a \sqrt{1+a^{2}}} \cdot \frac{a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x}{a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x} \times \\
& \times \frac{\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\mathrm{ch}^{2} x} \cdot\left(a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right)-\left(a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right) \cdot\left(-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\mathrm{ch}^{2} x}\right)}{\left(a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 a \sqrt{1+a^{2}}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\mathrm{ch}^{2} x} \cdot\left(a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x+a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right)}{\left(a+\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right)\left(a-\sqrt{1+a^{2}} \operatorname{th} x\right)}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 a} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{\operatorname{ch}^{2} x} \cdot 2 a}{a^{2}+\left(1+a^{2}\right) \cdot \operatorname{th}^{2} x}=\frac{1}{\operatorname{ch}^{2} x\left(a^{2}+\left(1+a^{2}\right) \cdot \operatorname{th}^{2} x\right)}= \\
& =\frac{1}{a^{2} \cdot \operatorname{ch}^{2} x+\left(1+a^{2}\right) \cdot \operatorname{sh}^{2} x}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=\frac{7^{x}(3 \sin 3 x+\cos 3 x \cdot \ln 7)}{9+\ln ^{2} 7}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{7^{x}(3 \sin 3 x+\cos 3 x \cdot \ln 7)}{9+\ln ^{2} 7}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{9+\ln ^{2} 7} \cdot\left(7^{x}(3 \sin 3 x+\cos 3 x \cdot \ln 7)\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{9+\ln ^{2} 7} \cdot\left(7^{x} \cdot \ln 7 \cdot(3 \sin 3 x+\cos 3 x \cdot \ln 7)+7^{x}(3 \cos 3 x \cdot 3-\sin 3 x \cdot 3 \cdot \ln 7)\right)= \\
& =\frac{7^{x}}{9+\ln ^{2} 7} \cdot\left(3 \ln 7 \cdot \sin 3 x+\cos 3 x \cdot \ln ^{2} 7+9 \cos 3 x-3 \ln 7 \cdot \sin 3 x\right)= \\
& =\frac{7^{x} \cdot \cos 3 x}{9+\ln ^{2} 7} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 7+9\right)=7^{x} \cdot \cos 3 x
\end{aligned}
$$

## Condition of the problem

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\operatorname{ctg}\left(2 e^{t}\right) \\
y=\ln \left(\operatorname{tg} e^{t}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(2 e^{t}\right)\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-1}{\sin ^{2}\left(2 e^{t}\right)} \cdot 2 e^{t}=\frac{-2 e^{t}}{\sin ^{2}\left(2 e^{t}\right)} \\
& y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\ln \left(\operatorname{tg} e^{t}\right)\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} e^{t}} \cdot \frac{1}{\cos ^{2}\left(e^{t}\right)} \cdot e^{t}= \\
& =\frac{e^{t}}{\sin e^{t} \cdot \cos e^{t}}=\frac{2 e^{t}}{\sin \left(2 e^{t}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{2 e^{t}}{\sin \left(2 e^{t}\right)}\right) /\left(\frac{-2 e^{t}}{\sin ^{2}\left(2 e^{t}\right)}\right)=-\sin \left(2 e^{t}\right)$

## Task Condition

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=\frac{x}{2(3 x+2)}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\frac{x}{2(3 x+2)} \\
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{x}{2(3 x+2)}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1 \cdot(3 x+2)-x \cdot 3}{2(3 x+2)^{2}}=\frac{3 x+2-3 x}{2(3 x+2)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{2}{2(3 x+2)^{2}}=\frac{1}{(3 x+2)^{2}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{(3 x+2)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-2}{(3 x+2)^{3}} \cdot 3=-\frac{2 \cdot 3}{(3 x+2)^{3}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{2 \cdot 3}{(3 x+2)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot(-3)}{(3 x+2)^{4}} \cdot 3=\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3^{2}}{(3 x+2)^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\cdots$

Obviously,

$y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot n!\cdot 3^{n-1}}{(3 x+2)^{n+1}}$

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

To derive the equation of the normal to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$$
y=\frac{1+\sqrt{x}}{1-\sqrt{x}}, x_{\bar{u}}=4
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{x}}{1-\sqrt{x}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{(1+\sqrt{x})^{\prime}(1-\sqrt{x})-(1+\sqrt{x})(1-\sqrt{x})^{\prime}}{(1-\sqrt{x})^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} \cdot(1-\sqrt{x})-(1+\sqrt{x})\left(-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}\right)}{(1-\sqrt{x})^{2}}=\frac{1-\sqrt{x}+1+\sqrt{x}}{2 \sqrt{x}(1-\sqrt{x})^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}(1-\sqrt{x})^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$
y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{0}}\left(1-\sqrt{x_{0}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4}(1-\sqrt{4})^{2}}=\frac{1}{2(1-2)^{2}}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Since $y^{\prime}\left(x_{\bar{U}}\right) \neq 0$, the equation of the normal line is:

$$
y-y_{\overline{0}}=-\frac{1}{y_{0}^{\prime}} \cdot\left(x-x_{0}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \\
& y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1+\sqrt{x_{\bar{U}}}}{1-\sqrt{x_{0}}}=\frac{1+\sqrt{4}}{1-\sqrt{4}}=\frac{1+2}{1-2}=-3
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-(-3)=-\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)} \cdot(x-4) \\
& y=-2 \cdot(x-4)-3 \\
& y=-2 x+8-3 \\
& y=-2 x+5
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the equation of the normal line is:

$y=-2 x+5$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the second-order derivative $y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}$ of the function given parametrically.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\sqrt{t} \\
y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t}}
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{t}^{\prime}=(\sqrt{t})^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t}} \\
& y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t}}\right)^{\prime}=\left((1-t)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot(1-t)^{-\frac{3}{2}} \cdot(-1)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{(1-t)^{3}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{(1-t)^{3}}}\right) /\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t}}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{t}{(1-t)^{3}}} \\
& \left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\sqrt{\frac{t}{(1-t)^{3}}}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{(1-t)^{3}}{t}} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot(1-t)^{3}-t \cdot 3(1-t)^{2} \cdot(-1)}{(1-t)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1-t}{t}} \cdot((1-t)+3 t)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1-t}{t}} \cdot(1+2 t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1-t}{t}} \cdot(1+2 t)\right) /\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t}}\right)=(1+2 t) \sqrt{1-t}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$:

$f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}\tan\left(2^{x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 x))}-1+x\right), x \neq 0 ; \\ 0, x=0\end{array}\right.$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan\left(2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x\right)-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan\left(2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x\right)}{\Delta x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

We use the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\tan\left(2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x\right) \sim 2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x$, as

$\Delta x \rightarrow 0\left(2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x \rightarrow 0\right)$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1+\Delta x}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1}{\Delta x}+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(e^{\ln 2}\right)^{\Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1}{\Delta x}+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} 1=1+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\ln 2 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1}{\Delta x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

We use the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{\ln 2 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}-1 \sim \ln 2 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))$, as

$\Delta x \rightarrow 0\left(\ln 2 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x)) \rightarrow 0\right)$

We get:

$$
=1+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln 2 \cdot \Delta x^{2} \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))}{\Delta x}=1+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \ln 2 \cdot \Delta x \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))=
$$

Since $\cos (1 /(8 \Delta x))$ is bounded, then

$\Delta x \cos (1 /(8 \Delta x)) \rightarrow 0$, as $\Delta x \rightarrow 0$

Then:

$=1+\ln 2 \cdot 0=1$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=1$

original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{\text{argument}}$ is small in absolute value, then

$$
f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{\overline{\mathrm{U}}}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{\overline{\mathrm{U}}}\right) \cdot \Delta x
$$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 1$

Then

Calculate:

$$
\begin{aligned}

& y^{\prime}(1) = \frac{2}{3} \cdot 1^{-\frac{1}{3}} = \frac{2}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$y(1.03) \approx y(1) + y^{\prime}(1) \cdot 0.03 = 1 + \frac{2}{3} \cdot 0.03 = 1 + 0.02 = 1.02$

## Task Condition

Compose the equation of the normal to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$$
y=\frac{x^{3}+2}{x^{3}-2}, x_{0}=2
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{x^{3}+2}{x^{5}-2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\left(x^{3}+2\right)^{\prime}\left(x^{5}-2\right)-\left(x^{3}+2\right)\left(x^{5}-2\right)^{\prime}}{\left(x^{5}-2\right)^{2}}=1+\frac{3}{2} \cdot x^{\frac{1}{2}}= \\
& =\frac{3 x^{2}\left(x^{5}-2\right)-\left(x^{3}+2\right) \cdot 5 x^{4}}{\left(x^{5}-2\right)^{2}}=\frac{3 x^{2}\left(x^{5}-2-x^{5}-2\right)}{\left(x^{5}-2\right)^{2}}=\frac{-12 x^{2}}{\left(x^{5}-2\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$
y_{\overline{0}}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{-12 x_{0}^{2}}{\left(x_{0}^{5}-2\right)^{2}}=\frac{-12 \cdot 2^{2}}{\left(2^{5}-2\right)^{2}}=\frac{-48}{30}=-\frac{4}{3}
$$

Since $y^{\prime}\left(x_{\overline{0}}\right) \neq 0$, the equation of the normal line is:

$$
y-y_{\bar{\omega}}=-\frac{1}{y_{\bar{U}}^{\prime}} \cdot\left(x-x_{\bar{U}}\right), \text { where }
$$

$$
y_{0}^{\prime}=-\frac{\mathbf{1}}{3}
$$

$$
y_{\overline{0}}=y\left(x_{\overline{0}}\right)=\frac{x_{0}^{3}+2}{x_{0}^{3}-2}=\frac{2^{3}+2}{2^{3}-2}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-\frac{5}{3}=-\frac{1}{\left(-\frac{4}{3}\right)} \cdot(x-2) \\
& y=\frac{3}{4} \cdot\left(x-2\right)+\frac{5}{3} \\
& y=\frac{3}{4} \cdot x-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{5}{3} \\
& y=\frac{3}{4} \cdot x+\frac{1}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the equation of the normal line is:

$y=\frac{3}{4} \cdot x+\frac{1}{6}$

$$

& =\frac{-\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} x}+1+\operatorname{ctg}^{2} x-\frac{x^{2}}{\sin ^{2} x}}{(1-x \cdot \operatorname{ctg} x)^{2}}=\frac{-\frac{x^{2}}{\sin ^{2} x}}{(1-x \cdot \operatorname{ctg} x)^{2}}=-\frac{x^{2}}{\sin ^{2} x(1-x \cdot \operatorname{ctg} x)^{2}}= \\

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=\sin (x+1)+\cos 2 x$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=(\sin (x+1)+\cos 2 x)^{\prime}=\cos (x+1)-2 \sin 2 x$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=(\cos (x+1)-2 \sin 2 x)^{\prime}=-\sin (x+1)-4 \cos 2 x$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=(\sin (x+1)-4 \cos 2 x)^{\prime}=-\cos (x+1)+8 \sin 2 x$

$y^{(I V)}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=(-\cos (x+1)+8 \sin 2 x)^{\prime}=\sin (x+1)+2^{4} \cdot \cos 2 x$

$\cdots$

Obviously,

$y^{(4 n)}=\sin (x+1)+2^{4 n} \cdot \cos 2 x$

$y^{(4 n+1)}=\cos (x+1)-2^{4 n+1} \cdot \sin 2 x$

$y^{(4 n+2)}=-\sin (x+1)-2^{4 n+2} \cdot \cos 2 x$

$y^{(4 n+3)}=-\cos (x+1)+2^{4 n+3} \cdot \sin 2 x$

Or written in one expression:

$y^{(n)}=\sin \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2} \cdot n+x+1\right)+2^{n} \cdot \cos \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2} \cdot n+2 x\right)$

& =\left((-\ln 2 \cdot(4 x+3)+4) 2^{-x}\right)^{\prime}=(-4 \ln 2) 2^{-x}+(-\ln 2 \cdot(4 x+3)+4) 2^{-x} \cdot \ln 2 \cdot(-1)= \\
& =\left(-4 \ln 2+\ln ^{2} 2 \cdot(4 x+3)-4 \ln 2\right) 2^{-x}=\left(\ln ^{2} 2 \cdot(4 x+3)-8 \ln 2\right) 2^{-x} \\

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\sqrt{1-t^{2}} \\
y=\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t)=-\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}-t \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t)}{1-t^{2}}=$

$=\frac{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}+\frac{t^{2}}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}}{1-t^{2}}=\frac{1-t^{2}+t^{2}}{\left(1-t^{2}\right) \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=\frac{1}{\left(1-t^{2}\right) \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}$

We obtain:

$$
y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{1}{\left(1-t^{2}\right) \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}}{-\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}}=-\frac{1}{t\left(1-t^{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{t\left(t^{2}-1\right)}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Derive the equations of the tangent and normal lines to the curve at the point corresponding to the parameter value $t=t_{0}$.

\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\sin t \\
y=\cos t
\end{array}\right.
\]
$t_{0}=\frac{\pi}{6}$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since $t_{0}=\frac{\pi}{6}$, then

$x_{0}=\sin \frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{1}{2}$

$y_{0}=\cos \frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$

Let's find the derivatives:

$x_{t}^{\prime}=(\sin t)^{\prime}=\cos t$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=(\cos t)^{\prime}=-\sin t$

$y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\frac{-\sin t}{\cos t}=-\tan t$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=-\tan \frac{\pi}{6}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$

Equation of the tangent line:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$

$y-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)$

$y=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot x+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{3}}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$

$y=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot x+\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}$

Equation of the normal line:

$y-y_{0}=-\frac{1}{y_{0}^{\prime}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$

$y-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=-\frac{1}{\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)}\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)$

$y-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=-\frac{1}{\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)}\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)$
$y=\sqrt{3} \cdot x-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$

$y=\sqrt{3} \cdot x$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=2 e^{4 \varphi / 3},-\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{2}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{\phi_{1}}^{\phi_{2}} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}\right)^{2}} d \phi
$$

Let's find $\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}$:

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}=2 \cdot \frac{4}{3} e^{4 \phi / 3}=\frac{8}{3} e^{4 \phi / 3}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(2 e^{4 \phi / 3}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{8}{3} e^{4 \phi / 3}\right)^{2}} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(4+\frac{64}{9}\right)\left(e^{4 \phi / 3}\right)^{2}} d \phi= \\
& =\frac{10}{3} \int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} e^{4 \phi / 3} d \phi=\left.\frac{10}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} e^{4 \phi / 3}\right|_{-\pi / 2} ^{\pi / 2}=\frac{5}{2} \cdot\left(e^{2 \pi / 3}-e^{-2 \pi / 3}\right)=5 \cdot \operatorname{sh} \frac{2 \pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=3 e^{3 \varphi / 4},-\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{2}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{\phi_{1}}^{\phi_{2}} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}\right)^{2}} d \phi
$$

Let's find $\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}$:

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}=3 \cdot \frac{3}{4} e^{3 \phi / 4}=\frac{9}{4} e^{3 \phi / 4}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(3 e^{3 \phi / 4}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{9}{4} e^{3 \phi / 4}\right)^{2}} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(9+\frac{81}{16}\right) e^{3 \phi / 2}} d \phi= \\
& =\frac{15}{4} \int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} e^{3 \phi / 4} d \phi=\left.\frac{15}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{3} e^{3 \phi / 4}\right|_{-\pi / 2} ^{\pi / 2}=5 \cdot\left(e^{3 \pi / 8}-e^{-3 \pi / 8}\right)=10 \cdot \operatorname{sh} \frac{3 \pi}{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.solution:

$$
L=\int_{\phi_{1}}^{\phi_{2}} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}\right)^{2}} d \phi

Find $\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}$:

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=2(1-\cos \varphi),-\pi \leq \varphi \leq-\frac{\pi}{2}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$L=\int_{\varphi_{0}}^{\varphi_{1}} \sqrt{(\rho(\varphi))^{2}+\left(\rho^{\prime}(\varphi)\right)^{2}} d \varphi$

For the curve given by the equation $\rho=2(1-\cos \varphi)$, we find: $\rho^{\prime}=2 \sin \varphi$

## We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{(2(1-\cos \varphi))^{2}+(2 \sin \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{4(1-\cos \varphi)^{2}+4 \sin ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =2 \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{1-2 \cos \varphi+\cos ^{2} \varphi+\sin ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =2 \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{2-2 \cos \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =2 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{1-\cos \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =2 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sqrt{2 \sin \frac{\varphi}{2}} d \varphi= \\
& =4 \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sin \frac{\varphi}{2} d \varphi= \\
& =4 \cdot 2 \int_{-\pi}^{-\pi / 2} \sin \frac{\varphi}{2} d \frac{\varphi}{2}= \\
& =-\left.8 \cos \frac{\varphi}{2}\right|_{-\pi} ^{-\pi / 2}=-8\left(\cos \frac{-\pi}{4}-\cos \frac{-\pi}{2}\right)=-8\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-0\right)=-4 \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B0_19-12 »$ Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 19 | Integrals | Popular Problems | Problems for Checking

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=3(1+\sin \varphi),-\frac{\pi}{6} \leq \varphi \leq 0
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$L=\int_{\varphi_{0}}^{\varphi_{1}} \sqrt{(\rho(\varphi))^{2}+\left(\rho^{\prime}(\varphi)\right)^{2}} d \varphi$

For the curve given by the equation $\rho=3(1+\sin \varphi)$, we find: $\rho^{\prime}=3 \cos \varphi$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{(3(1+\sin \varphi))^{2}+(3 \cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{9(1+\sin \varphi)^{2}+9 \cos ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =3 \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{1+2 \sin \varphi+\sin ^{2} \varphi+\cos ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =3 \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{2+2 \sin \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =3 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{1-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}+\varphi\right)} d \varphi= \\
& =3 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sqrt{2 \sin { }^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)} d \varphi= \\
& =6 \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\varphi}{2}\right) d \varphi= \\
& =6 \cdot 2 \int_{-\pi / 6}^{0} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\varphi}{2}\right) d\left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)= \\
& =-\left.12 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)\right|_{-\pi / 6} ^{0}=-12\left(\cos \frac{\pi}{4}-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{12}\right)\right)=-12\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)=6(\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2})
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B0_19-13"

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=2 \sin \varphi, 0 \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{6}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
\rho & =2 \sin \varphi, 0 \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{6} \\
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\rho^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d x \\
\rho^{\prime} & =2(\sin \varphi)^{\prime}=2 \cos \varphi \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{(2 \sin \varphi)^{2}+(2 \cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{(\sin \varphi)^{2}+(\cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} d \varphi=\left.2 \varphi\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 6}=2(\pi / 6)-2 \cdot 0=\pi / 3
\end{aligned}
$$

L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\rho^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d x \\
\rho^{\prime} & =6(\sin \varphi)^{\prime}=6 \cos \varphi \\
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{(6 \sin \varphi)^{2}+(6 \cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi=6 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{(\sin \varphi)^{2}+(\cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi=6 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} d \varphi=\left.6 \varphi\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 3}=6(\pi / 3)-6 \cdot 0=2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{\left(x^{3}-2 x-1\right)(x+1)}{x^{4}+4 x^{2}-5}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{\left(x^{3}-2 x-1\right)(x+1)}{\left(x^{3}-x^{2}+5 x-5\right)(x+1)}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow-1} \frac{x^{3}-2 x-1}{x^{3}-x^{2}+5 x-5}=\frac{(-1)^{3}-2(-1)-1}{(-1)^{3}-(-1)^{2}+5(-1)-5}= \\
& =\frac{-1+2-1}{-1-1-5-5}=\frac{0}{-12}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (1+\sin x)}{\sin 4 x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's use the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

\(\sin x \sim x\), as \(x \rightarrow 0\)

\(\sin 4x \sim 4x\), as \(x \rightarrow 0\) (or \(4x \rightarrow 0\))

\(\ln (1+x) \sim x\), as \(x \rightarrow 0\)

We get:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (1+\sin x)}{\sin 4 x}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (1+x)}{4 x}=\left\{\frac{0}{0}\right\}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{4 x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{4}
\end{aligned}
\]

original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\sin 2 x}{x}\right)^{1+x}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\sin 2 x}{x}\right)\right)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1+x}=$

$=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\sin 2 x}{x}\right)\right)^{1}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin 2 x}{x}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\sin 2 x \sim 2 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(2 x \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x}{x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2}{1}=2
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Derive the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$y=\frac{x^{16}+9}{1-5 x^{2}}, x_{0}=1$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{x^{16}+9}{1-5 x^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{\left(x^{16}+9\right)^{\prime}\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)-\left(x^{16}+9\right)\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)^{\prime}}{\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{16 x^{15}\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)-\left(x^{16}+9\right)(-10 x)}{\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{16 x^{15}-80 x^{17}+10 x^{17}+90 x}{\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)^{2}}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$=\frac{16 x^{15}-70 x^{17}+90 x}{\left(1-5 x^{2}\right)^{2}}$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{16 \cdot 1^{15}-70 \cdot 1^{17}+90 \cdot 1}{\left(1-5 \cdot 1^{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{16-70+90}{(1-5)^{2}}=\frac{36}{4^{2}}=\frac{9}{4}$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$, where

$y_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{9}{4}$

$y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1^{16}+9}{1-5 \cdot 1^{2}}=\frac{1+9}{1-5}=\frac{10}{-4}=-\frac{5}{2}$

We get:

$y-\left(-\frac{5}{2}\right)=\frac{9}{4} \cdot(x-1)$

$y=\frac{9}{4} \cdot x-\frac{9}{4}-\frac{5}{2}$

$y=\frac{9}{4} \cdot x-\frac{19}{4}$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y=\frac{9}{4} \cdot x-\frac{19}{4}$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(x-e^{-x} \arcsin e^{x}-\ln \left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right)\right)^{\prime}=$

$=1+e^{-x} \arcsin e^{x}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}+\frac{e^{2 x}}{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}=$

$=e^{-x} \arcsin e^{x}+\frac{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}-\frac{1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}+\frac{e^{2 x}}{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}=$

$=e^{-x} \arcsin e^{x}+\frac{\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}+1-e^{2 x}-1-\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}+e^{2 x}}{\left(1+\sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}\right) \sqrt{1-e^{2 x}}}=e^{-x} \arcsin e^{x}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$:

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
6 x+x \sin \frac{1}{x}, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$$
f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}
$$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{6 \Delta x+\Delta x \sin \frac{1}{\Delta x}-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{6 \Delta x+\Delta x \sin \frac{1}{\Delta x}}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(6+\sin \frac{1}{\Delta x}\right)= \\
& =6+\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \sin \frac{1}{\Delta x} \text { - the limit does not exist. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $f^{\prime}(0)$ does not exist.

& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+6 \operatorname{ch} x+9 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-9-6 \operatorname{ch} x-\operatorname{ch}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{3 \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x-9 \operatorname{sh} x-3 \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-8}} \cdot \frac{-9 \operatorname{sh} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{1}{8 \sqrt{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{-9 \operatorname{sh} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}=-\frac{9 \operatorname{sh} x}{8(1+3 \operatorname{ch} x)}

$=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x}+\left(\frac{1}{x}+1\right) \cdot \frac{1}{1+(\sqrt{x})^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^{3}}}=$
$=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x}+\frac{1+x}{x} \cdot \frac{1}{1+x} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 x \sqrt{x}}=$

$=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x}+\frac{1}{2 x \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 x \sqrt{x}}=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{x}+\frac{1}{x \sqrt{x}}$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=\lg (1+x)$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\lg (1+x) \\
& y^{\prime}=(\lg (1+x))^{\prime}=\frac{1}{(1+x) \ln 10}=\frac{1}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-1} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-1}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-2} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{1}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{2}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-3} \\
& y^{(4)}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-3}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{2 \cdot 3}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-4}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\cdots$

Obviously,

$$
y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot(n-1)!}{\ln 10} \cdot(1+x)^{-n}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot(n-1)!}{\ln 10 \cdot(1+x)^{n}}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=\frac{1}{x} \cdot \sin 2 x, y^{\prime \prime \prime}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{x} \cdot \sin 2 x\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{2}{x} \cdot \cos 2 x$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{2}{x} \cdot \cos 2 x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\frac{2}{x^{3}} \cdot \sin 2 x-\frac{2}{x^{2}} \cdot \cos 2 x-\frac{2}{x^{2}} \cdot \cos 2 x-\frac{4}{x} \cdot \sin 2 x=$

$=\frac{2}{x^{3}} \cdot \sin 2 x-\frac{4}{x^{2}} \cdot \cos 2 x-\frac{4}{x} \cdot \sin 2 x$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{x^{3}} \cdot \sin 2 x-\frac{4}{x^{2}} \cdot \cos 2 x-\frac{4}{x} \cdot \sin 2 x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-\frac{6}{x^{4}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{4}{x^{3}} \cdot \cos 2 x+\frac{8}{x^{3}} \cdot \cos 2 x+\frac{8}{x^{2}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{4}{x^{2}} \cdot \sin 2 x-\frac{8}{x} \cdot \cos 2 x=$ $=-\frac{6}{x^{4}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{12}{x^{3}} \cdot \cos 2 x+\frac{12}{x^{2}} \cdot \sin 2 x-\frac{8}{x} \cdot \cos 2 x=$

$=\frac{12 x^{2}-6}{x^{4}} \cdot \sin 2 x+\frac{12-8 x^{2}}{x^{3}} \cdot \cos 2 x$

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

Find the derivative $y_{x}^{\prime}$.

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\frac{1}{\ln t} \\
y=\ln \frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\ln t}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{\ln ^{2} t} \cdot \frac{1}{t}=-\frac{1}{t \cdot \ln ^{2} t}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\ln \frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}{t}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{t}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot(-2 t) \cdot t-\left(1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\right) \cdot 1}{t^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-t^{2}-\sqrt{1-t^{2}}-\left(1-t^{2}\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1-t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{-\left(\sqrt{1-t^{2}}+1\right)}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}= \\
& =-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(-\frac{1}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\right) /\left(-\frac{1}{t \cdot \ln ^{2} t}\right)=\frac{t \cdot \ln ^{2} t}{t \sqrt{1-t^{2}}}=\frac{\ln ^{2} t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(2 x^{2}+4 x+7\right) \cos 2 x \, d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(2 x^{2}+4 x+7\right) \cos 2 x d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=2 x^{2}+4 x+7 ; d u=(4 x+4) d x \\
& d v=\cos 2 x d x ; v=\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 x
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\left(2 x^{2}+4 x+7\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \sin 2 x\right|_{0} ^{\pi}-\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{2} \sin 2 x(4 x+4) d x= \\
& =\left(2 \pi^{2}+4 \cdot \pi+7\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \sin (2 \cdot \pi)-\left(2 \cdot 0^{2}+4 \cdot 0+7\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \sin (2 \cdot 0)-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 2 x(2 x+2) d x \\
& =\left(2 \cdot \pi^{2}+4 \pi+7\right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot 0-7 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot 0-\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 2 x(2 x+2) d x= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 2 x(2 x+2) d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=2 x+2 ; d u=2 d x \\
& d v=\sin 2 x d x ; v=-\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 x
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
=-\left(\left.(2 x+2) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 x\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi}-\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(-\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 x\right) \cdot 2 d x\right)=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left((2 \cdot \pi+2) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2} \cos (2 \cdot \pi)\right)-(2 \cdot 0+2) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2} \cos (2 \cdot 0)\right)+\int_{0}^{\pi} \cos 2 x d x\right)= \\
& =-\left(-\pi-1+1+\left.\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 x\right|_{0} ^{\pi}\right)=-\left(-\pi+\frac{1}{2} \sin (2 \cdot \pi)-\frac{1}{2} \sin (2 \cdot 0)\right)= \\
& =-(-\pi+0-0)=\pi
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(8 x^{2}+16 x+17\right) \cos 4 x d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=8 x^{2}+16 x+17 ; d u=(16 x+16) d x \\
& d v=\cos 4 x d x ; v=\frac{1}{4} \sin 4 x
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\left(8 x^{2}+16 x+17\right) \cdot \frac{1}{4} \sin 4 x\right|_{0} ^{\pi}-\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{4} \sin 4 x \cdot(16 x+16) \cdot d x= \\
& =\left(8 \pi^{2}+16 \cdot \pi+17\right) \cdot \frac{1}{4} \sin (4 \cdot \pi)-\left(8 \cdot 0^{2}+16 \cdot 0+17\right) \cdot \frac{1}{4} \sin (4 \cdot 0)-\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 4 x \cdot(4 x+ \\
& =\left(8 \pi^{2}+16 \pi+11\right) \cdot \frac{1}{4} \cdot 0-17 \cdot \frac{1}{4} \cdot 0-\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 4 x \cdot(4 x+4) \cdot d x=-\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 4 x \cdot(4 x+4) \cdot d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=4 x+4 ; d u=4 d x \\
& d v=\sin 4 x d x ; v=-\frac{1}{4} \cos 4 x
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$. We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left(\left.(4 x+4) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cos 4 x\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi}-\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cos 4 x\right) \cdot 4 d x\right)= \\
& =-\left((4 \cdot \pi+4) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cos (4 \cdot \pi)\right)-(4 \cdot 0+4) \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cos (4 \cdot 0)\right)+\int_{0}^{\pi} \cos 4 x d x\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left(-\pi-1+1+\left.\frac{1}{4} \sin 4 x\right|_{0} ^{\pi}\right)=-\left(-\pi+\frac{1}{4} \sin (4 \cdot \pi)-\frac{1}{4} \sin (4 \cdot 0)\right)= \\
& =-(-\pi+0-0)=\pi
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot \ln ^{2}(x+1) d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot \ln ^{2}(x+1) d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln ^{2}(x+1) ; d u=2 \ln (x+1) \cdot \frac{1}{x+1} \cdot d x \\
& d v=(x+1)^{2} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\ln ^{2}(x+1) \cdot \frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3}\right|_{0} ^{2}-\int_{0}^{2} \frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3} \cdot 2 \ln (x+1) \cdot \frac{1}{x+1} \cdot d x= \\
& =\ln ^{2}(2+1) \cdot \frac{(2+1)^{3}}{3}-\ln ^{2}(0+1) \cdot \frac{(0+1)^{3}}{3}-\frac{2}{3} \cdot \int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot \ln (x+1) \cdot d x= \\
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-0 \cdot \frac{1^{3}}{3}-\frac{2}{3} \cdot \int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot \ln (x+1) \cdot d x=9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot \int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot \ln (x+1) \cdot d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln (x+1) ; d u=\frac{1}{x+1} d x \\
& d v=(x+1)^{2} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot\left(\left.\ln (x+1) \cdot \frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3}\right|_{0} ^{2}-\int_{0}^{2} \frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{x+1} d x\right)= \\
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot\left(\ln (2+1) \cdot \frac{(2+1)^{3}}{3}-\ln (0+1) \cdot \frac{(0+1)^{3}}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \int_{0}^{2}(x+1)^{2} \cdot d x\right)= \\
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot\left(9 \ln 3-0 \cdot \frac{1^{3}}{3}-\left.\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{(x+1)^{3}}{3}\right|_{0} ^{2}\right)=9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot\left(9 \ln 3-\frac{(2+1)^{3}}{9}+\frac{(0+1)^{3}}{9}\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-\frac{2}{3} \cdot\left(9 \ln 3-3+\frac{1}{9}\right)=9 \ln ^{2} 3-6 \ln 3+2-\frac{2}{27}= \\
& =9 \ln ^{2} 3-6 \ln 3+1 \frac{25}{27}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln ^{2}(x+2) d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln ^{2}(x+2) ; d u=2 \ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} \cdot d x \\
& d v=(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\ln ^{2}(x+2) \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4} \cdot 2 \ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} \cdot d x= \\
& =\ln ^{2}(0+2) \cdot \frac{(0+2)^{4}}{4}-\ln ^{2}(-1+2) \cdot \frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-0 \cdot \frac{1^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x=4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln (x+2) ; d u=\frac{1}{x+2} d x \\
& d v=(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\left.\ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} d x\right)= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\ln (0+2) \cdot \frac{(0+2)^{4}}{4}-\ln (-1+2) \cdot \frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{4} \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x\right)= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-0 \cdot \frac{1^{4}}{4}-\left.\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}\right)=4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-\frac{(0+2)^{4}}{16}+\frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{16}\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-1+\frac{1}{16}\right)=4 \ln ^{2} 2-2 \ln 2+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{32}= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-2 \ln 2+\frac{15}{32}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$ :

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
x^{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{11}{x}, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x^{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{11}{\Delta x}-0}{\Delta x}= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x^{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{11}{\Delta x}}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \Delta x \cdot \cos ^{2} \frac{11}{\Delta x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\cos ^{2} \frac{11}{\Delta x}$ is bounded, then

$\Delta x \cdot \cos ^{2} \frac{11}{\Delta x} \rightarrow 0$, as $\Delta x \rightarrow 0$

Thus:

$=0$

Therefore, $f^{\prime}(0)=0$

original.solution:

$$

Let's denote:

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\left(x^{2}+2\right) \cdot 2 e^{\frac{x}{2}}\right|_{-2} ^{0}-\int_{-2}^{0} 2 e^{\frac{x}{2}} \cdot 2 x \cdot d x=\left(0^{2}+2\right) \cdot 2 e^{\frac{0}{2}}-\left((-2)^{2}+2\right) \cdot 2 e^{\frac{-2}{2}}-4 \cdot \int_{-2}^{0} x \cdot e^{\frac{x}{2}} \cdot d x= \\
& =4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot \int_{-2}^{0} x \cdot e^{\frac{x}{2}} \cdot d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=x ; d u=d x \\
& d v=e^{\frac{x}{2}} \cdot d x ; v=2 e^{\frac{x}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(\left.x \cdot 2 e^{\frac{x}{2}}\right|_{-2} ^{0}-\int_{-2}^{0} 2 e^{\frac{x}{2}} d x\right)= \\
& =4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(0 \cdot 2 e^{\frac{0}{2}}-(-2) \cdot 2 e^{\frac{-2}{2}}-2 \cdot \int_{-2}^{0} e^{\frac{x}{2}} d x\right)= \\
& =4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(\frac{4}{e}-\left.2 \cdot 2 e^{\frac{x}{2}}\right|_{-2} ^{0}\right)=4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(\frac{4}{e}-4 e^{\frac{0}{2}}+4 e^{\frac{-2}{2}}\right)= \\
& =4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(\frac{4}{e}-4+\frac{4}{e}\right)=4-\frac{12}{e}-4 \cdot\left(\frac{8}{e}-4\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=4-\frac{12}{e}-\frac{32}{e}+16=20-\frac{44}{e}
$$

=\frac{-1-x^{2}}{x^{2} \sqrt{1+x^{2}}}=-\frac{\sqrt{1+x^{2}}}{x^{2}}

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

To derive the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$$
y=2 x+\frac{1}{x}, x_{\overline{0}}=1
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$$
y^{\prime}=\left(2 x+\frac{1}{x}\right)^{\prime}=2-\frac{1}{x^{2}}
$$

Then:

$$
y_{\overline{0}}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{\overline{0}}\right)=2-\frac{1}{x_{\overline{0}}^{2}}=2-\frac{1}{1^{2}}=2-1=1
$$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-y_{\overline{0}}=y_{\overline{0}}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right), \text { where } \\
& y_{\overline{0}}^{\prime}=1 \\
& y_{\overline{0}}=y\left(x_{\overline{0}}\right)=2 x_{\overline{0}}+\frac{1}{x_{\overline{0}}}=2 \cdot 1+\frac{1}{1}=2+1=3
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-3=1 \cdot(x-1) \\
& y=x-1+3 \\
& y=x+2
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is: $y=x+2$

$$
original.solution:

& d y=y^{\prime} \cdot d x=(2 x-\ln |\sin x+2 \cos x|)^{\prime} d x=\left(2+\frac{1}{\sin x+2 \cos x} \cdot(\cos x-2 \sin x)\right) d x= \\
& =\left(\frac{2 \sin x+1 \cos x+\cos x-2 \sin x}{\sin x+2 \cos x}\right) d x=\frac{5 \cos x}{\sin x+2 \cos x} \cdot d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg}_{\frac{1}{3}}\right)}{15} \cdot \frac{2 \sin 15 x \cdot \cos 15 x \cdot 15 \cdot \cos 30 x-\sin ^{2} 15 x \cdot(-\sin 30 x) \cdot 30}{\cos ^{2} 30 x}=$

$=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{1}{3}\right)}{15} \cdot \frac{15 \sin 30 x \cdot \cos 30 x+30 \sin ^{2} 15 x \cdot \sin 30 x}{\cos ^{2} 30 x}=$

$=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{1}{3}\right)}{15} \cdot \frac{15 \sin 30 x \cdot\left(\cos 30 x+2 \sin ^{2} 15 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 30 x}=$

$=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{1}{3}\right)}{15} \cdot \frac{15 \sin 30 x \cdot\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} 15 x+2 \sin ^{2} 15 x\right)}{\cos ^{2} 30 x}=$

$=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{1}{3}\right)}{15} \cdot \frac{15 \sin 30 x}{\cos ^{2} 30 x}=\frac{\cos \left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{1}{3}\right) \cdot \operatorname{tg} 30 x}{\cos 30 x}$

## Problem Statement

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1}{x^{2}}-1}-\frac{\arccos x}{2 x^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1}{x^{2}}-1}-\frac{\arccos x}{2 x^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{x^{2}-1}}{x}-\frac{\arccos x}{2 x^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x^{2}-1}} \cdot 2 x \cdot x-\sqrt{x^{2}-1} \cdot 1}{x^{2}}-\frac{\frac{-1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \cdot x^{2}-\arccos x \cdot 2 x}{2 x^{4}}= \\
& =\frac{x^{2}-\left(x^{2}-1\right)}{2 x^{2} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}+\frac{x+2 \sqrt{1-x^{2}} \cdot \arccos x}{2 x^{3} \sqrt{1-x^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{x}{2 x^{3} \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}-1}}+\frac{x+2 \sqrt{1-x^{2}} \cdot \arccos x}{2 x^{3} \sqrt{1-x^{2}}}=\frac{2 x+2 \sqrt{1-x^{2}} \cdot \arccos x}{2 x^{3} \sqrt{1-x^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{x+\sqrt{1-x^{2}} \cdot \arccos x}{x^{3} \sqrt{1-x^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{6^{x}(\sin 4 x \cdot \ln 6-4 \cos 4 x)}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{6^{x}(\sin 4 x \cdot \ln 6-4 \cos 4 x)}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{6^{x} \sin 4 x \cdot \ln 6-4 \cdot 6^{x} \cos 4 x}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}\right)^{\prime}=$

$$
=\frac{\ln 6\left(6^{x} \sin 4 x\right)^{\prime}-4\left(6^{x} \cos 4 x\right)^{\prime}}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\ln 6\left(6^{x} \ln 6 \cdot \sin 4 x+6^{x} \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot 4\right)-4\left(6^{x} \ln 6 \cdot \cos 4 x-6^{x} \cdot \sin 4 x \cdot 4\right)}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}= \\
& =\frac{6^{x} \ln ^{2} 6 \cdot \sin 4 x+6^{x} \ln 6 \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot 4-6^{x} \ln 6 \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot 4+6^{x} \cdot \sin 4 x \cdot 16}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}= \\
& =\frac{\sin 4 x \cdot 6^{x}\left(16+\ln ^{2} 6\right)}{16+\ln ^{2} 6}=6^{x} \sin 4 x
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=\lg (3 x+1)$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\lg (3 x+1) \\
& y^{\prime}=(\lg (3 x+1))^{\prime}=\frac{3}{(3 x+1) \ln 10}=\frac{3}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-1} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{3}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-1}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{3^{2}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-2} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{3^{2}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{2 \cdot 3^{3}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-3} \\
& y^{(4)}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2 \cdot 3^{3}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-3}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3^{4}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Obviously,

$$
y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot(n-1)!\cdot 3^{n}}{\ln 10} \cdot(3 x+1)^{-n}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot(n-1)!\cdot 3^{n}}{\ln 10 \cdot(3 x+1)^{n}}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=\left(2 x^{3}+1\right) \cos x, y^{V}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\left(2 x^{3}+1\right) \cos x\right)^{\prime}=6 x^{2} \cdot \cos x-\left(2 x^{3}+1\right) \sin x_{.}$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(6 x^{2} \cdot \cos x-\left(2 x^{3}+1\right) \sin x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=12 x \cdot \cos x-6 x^{2} \cdot \sin x-6 x^{2} \cdot \sin x-\left(2 x^{3}+1\right) \cos x=$

$=-12 x^{2} \cdot \sin x-\left(2 x^{3}-12 x+1\right) \cos x$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-12 x^{2} \cdot \sin x-\left(2 x^{3}-12 x+1\right) \cos x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-24 x \cdot \sin x-12 x^{2} \cdot \cos x-\left(6 x^{2}-12\right) \cos x+\left(2 x^{3}-12 x+1\right) \sin x=$

$=-\left(18 x^{2}-12\right) \cos x+\left(2 x^{3}-36 x+1\right) \sin x$
$y^{(IV)}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\left(18 x^{2}-12\right) \cos x+\left(2 x^{3}-36 x+1\right) \sin x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-36 x \cdot \cos x+\left(18 x^{2}-12\right) \sin x+\left(6 x^{2}-36\right) \sin x+\left(2 x^{3}-36 x+1\right) \cos x=$ $=\left(24 x^{2}-48\right) \sin x+\left(2 x^{3}-72 x+1\right) \cos x$

$y^{(V)}=\left(\left(24 x^{2}-48\right) \sin x+\left(2 x^{3}-72 x+1\right) \cos x\right)^{\prime}=$

$=48 x^{2} \cdot \sin x+\left(24 x^{2}-48\right) \cos x+\left(6 x^{2}-72\right) \cos x-\left(2 x^{3}-72 x+1\right) \sin x=$ $=\left(30 x^{2}-120\right) \cos x-\left(2 x^{3}-120 x+1\right) \sin x$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the second-order derivative $y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}$ of the function given parametrically.

$\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\sqrt{t-1} \\ y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}\end{array}\right.$
original.solution:
## Solution

$x_{t}^{\prime}=(\sqrt{t-1})^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t-1}}$

$y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}\right)^{\prime}=\left(t^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot t^{-\frac{3}{2}}=-\frac{1}{2 t \sqrt{t}}$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(-\frac{1}{2 t \sqrt{t}}\right) /\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t-1}}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{t-1}}{t \sqrt{t}}=-\sqrt{\frac{t-1}{t^{3}}} \\
& \left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}=\left(-\sqrt{\frac{t-1}{t^{3}}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{t^{3}}{t-1}} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot t^{3}-(t-1) \cdot 3 t^{2}}{t^{6}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{t}{t-1}} \cdot \frac{-t+3(t-1)}{t^{3}}=\frac{(2 t-3) \sqrt{t}}{2 t^{3} \sqrt{t-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$y_{x x}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\left(y_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{(2 t-3) \sqrt{t}}{2 t^{3} \sqrt{t-1}}\right) /\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t-1}}\right)=\frac{(2 t-3) \sqrt{t}}{t^{3}}$

llm_response:

The solution involves several steps of differentiation and manipulating derivatives, which can all be directly computed. The final expression for the second-order derivative is clearly derived through a systematic calculation of derivatives, making it verifiable in a formal language like Lean4.

Given that the solution is primarily about executing a series of derivative computations from a parametric form, this fits into the straightforward computation category.

Thus, the classification for this problem is: 

EASY

original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1}} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}} \cdot 2\left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right) \cdot \frac{e^{x}}{2}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1}} \cdot \frac{e^{x}}{\left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)}=\frac{e^{x}}{\left(1+e^{x}\right) \cdot \sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute into equation (1):

$\left(1+e^{x}\right) \cdot \sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1} \cdot \frac{e^{x}}{\left(1+e^{x}\right) \cdot \sqrt{\ln \left(\frac{1+e^{x}}{2}\right)^{2}+1}}=e^{x}$

Simplify:

$\left(1+e^{x}\right) \cdot \frac{e^{x}}{1+e^{x}}=e^{x}$

$e^{x}=e^{x}$

$0=0$

The equality holds. The function $y_{\text {satisfies equation (1). }}$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:
$\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin (x+h)-\sin (x-h)}{h}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin (x+h)-\sin (x-h)}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin \frac{(x+h)-(x-h)}{2} \cos \frac{(x+h)+(x-h)}{2}}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin \frac{2 h}{2} \cos \frac{2 x}{2}}{h}=$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin h \cos x}{h}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\sin h \sim h$, as $h \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 h \cos x}{h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} 2 \cos x=2 \cos x$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the graphs of the functions:

$$
y=\sqrt{4-x^{2}}, y=0, x=0, x=1
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_aa6951b1e92815ea34b6g-08.jpg?height=1133&width=1514&top_left_y=1141&top_left_x=408)

The desired area \( S \) is:

\( S=\int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{4-x^{2}} d x \)

We make a trigonometric substitution:
\( \sqrt{4-x^{2}}=2 \sin t \), hence \( x=2 \cos t, d x=2 \sin t \)

When \( x=0=2 \cos t \Rightarrow t=\frac{\pi}{2} \)

and when \( x=1=2 \cos t \Rightarrow t=\frac{\pi}{3} \)

Then we get

\[
\begin{aligned}
& S=\int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{4-x^{2}} d x= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 3}^{\pi / 2} 2 \sin t \cdot 2 \sin t d t= \\
& =4 \int_{\pi / 3}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} t d t= \\
& =2 \int_{\pi / 3}^{\pi / 2}(1-\cos 2 t) d t= \\
& =\left.(2 t-\sin 2 t)\right|_{\pi / 3} ^{\pi / 2}=\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}
\end{aligned}
\]

$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_aa6951b1e92815ea34b6g-06.jpg?height=769&width=1105&top_left_y=969&top_left_x=818)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=S_{0 x} ; 0 \leq x \leq \pi / 2 ; 0 \leq y \leq \sin x \cos ^{2} x \\
& S=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} y d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\sin x \cos ^{2} x-0\right) d x= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} x d(\cos x)= \\
& =-\left.\frac{\cos ^{3} x}{3}\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}= \\
& =-\left(\frac{\cos ^{3} \pi / 2}{3}-\frac{\cos ^{3} 0}{3}\right)=-\left(\frac{0^{3}}{3}-\frac{1^{3}}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the graphs of the functions:

$$
y=x^{2} \sqrt{4-x^{2}}, y=0, (0 \leq x \leq 2)
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Integral $14-6$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_aa6951b1e92815ea34b6g-10.jpg?height=1425&width=1430&top_left_y=1044&top_left_x=447)

$S=\int_{0}^{2} x^{2} \sqrt{4-x^{2}} d x=\left|\begin{array}{c}x=2 \sin t \\ d x=2 \cos t d t \\ x=0 ; t=0 \\ x=2 ; t=\pi / 2\end{array}\right|=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 4 \sin ^{2} t \sqrt{4-4 \sin ^{2} t} \cdot 2 \cos t d t= \\
& =4 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} t \cdot \cos t \cdot \cos t d t= \\
& =16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} t \cdot \cos ^{2} t d t= \\
& =16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(1-\cos ^{2} t\right) \cdot \cos ^{2} t d t= \\
& =16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} t d t-16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{4} t d t= \\
& =16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1+\cos 2 t}{2} d t-16 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1+2 \cos 2 t+\cos ^{2} 2 t}{4} d t= \\
& =8 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}(1+\cos 2 t) d t-4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(1+2 \cos 2 t+\cos ^{2} 2 t\right) d t= \\
& =8 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t+8 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos 2 t d t-4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t-4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 \cos 2 t d t-4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} 2 t d t= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t+8 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos 2 t d t-8 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos 2 t d t-4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1+\cos 4 t}{2} d t= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t-2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t-2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos 4 t d t= \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d t-\frac{2}{4} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos 4 t d(4 t)= \\
& =\left.2 t\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}-\left.\frac{1}{2} \sin 4 t\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}= \\
& =2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}-0-\frac{1}{2}(\sin 2 \pi-\sin 0)=\pi-\frac{1}{2}(0-0)=\pi
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the parametric equations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=e^{t}(\cos t+\sin t) \\
y=e^{t}(\cos t-\sin t)
\end{array}\right. \\
& 0 \leq t \leq \pi
\end{aligned}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{\prime}(t)=e^{t}(\cos t+\sin t)+(\cos t-\sin t) e^{t}=2 e^{t} \cos t \\
& y^{\prime}(t)=e^{t}(\cos t-\sin t)+(-\cos t-\sin t) e^{t}=-2 e^{t} \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi} \sqrt{4 e^{2 t} \cos ^{2} t+4 e^{2 t} \sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi} 2 e^{t} \sqrt{\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi} 2 e^{t} \sqrt{1} d t=2 \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{t} d t=\left.2 e^{t}\right|_{0} ^{\pi}=2\left(e^{\pi}-e^{0}\right)=2\left(e^{\pi}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

## Kuznetsov Integrals Problem 18-7

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:
The problem involves calculating the length of an arc of a parametric curve using the formula for arc length, which requires computing the derivatives of the parametric equations. The solution consists of differentiating the functions and integrating to find the length.

Since the problem essentially boils down to executing a computation involving differentiation and integration with clear steps provided, I would classify it as:

EASY: It involves straightforward derivative computations to find the arc length.

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d t
$$

From the equations of the curve, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=6 \cos ^{3} t ; x_{t}^{\prime}=6 \cdot 3 \cos ^{2} t(\cos t)^{\prime}=-18 \cos ^{2} t \sin t \\
& y=6 \sin ^{3} t ; y_{t}^{\prime}=6 \cdot 3 \sin ^{2} t(\sin t)^{\prime}=18 \sin ^{2} t \cos t
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\left(-18 \cos ^{2} t \sin t\right)^{2}+\left(18 \sin ^{2} t \cos t\right)^{2}} d t= \\
& =18 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\cos ^{4} t \sin ^{2} t+\sin ^{4} t \cos ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =18 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\cos ^{2} t \sin ^{2} t} \cdot \sqrt{\sin ^{2} t+\cos ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =18 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\cos ^{2} t \sin ^{2} t} \cdot \sqrt{1} d t=\left|\begin{array}{c}
0 \leq t \leq \pi / 3 \\
\sin (t) \geq 0 \\
\cos (t) \geq 0
\end{array}\right|= \\
& =18 \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \cos t \sin t d t=\frac{18}{4} \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sin (2 t) d(2 t)= \\
& =-\left.\frac{9}{2} \cdot \cos (2 t)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 3}=-\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(\cos \frac{2 \pi}{3}-\cos 0\right)=-\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2}-1\right)=\frac{27}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 18-13

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:
The problem involves calculating the length of an arc defined by parametric equations. The solution requires finding the derivatives of the parametric equations, substituting them into the arc length formula, and then carrying out the integration.

This involves a straightforward application of calculus to derive the length of the curve based on the provided parameters, which includes differentiating and integrating. Thus, it fits into a straightforward computation category.

Therefore, I classify this problem as **EASY**.

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\left(t^{2}-2\right) \sin t+2 t \cos t \\
& x^{\prime}(t)=2 t \sin t+\left(t^{2}-2\right) \cos t+2 \cos t-2 t \sin t=2 t \sin t+t^{2} \cos t-2 \cos t+2 \cos t-2 t \sin t=t^{2} \cos t \\
& y=\left(2-t^{2}\right) \cos t+2 t \sin t \\
& y^{\prime}(t)=-2 t \cos t-\left(2-t^{2}\right) \sin t+2 \sin t+2 t \cos t=-2 t \cos t-2 \sin t+t^{2} \sin t+2 \sin t+2 t \cos t=t^{2} \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{\left(t^{2} \cos t\right)^{2}+\left(t^{2} \sin t\right)^{2}} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{t^{4}\left(\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t\right)} d t=\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \sqrt{t^{4} \cdot 1} d t=\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} t^{2} d t=\left.\frac{1}{3} \cdot t^{3}\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 3}= \\
& =\frac{1}{3} \cdot\left(\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)^{3}-0^{3}\right)=\frac{\pi^{3}}{81}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 18-11

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:
This problem requires calculating the length of an arc for a given parametric curve, which involves computing derivatives and then performing integration. The overall problem essentially boils down to executing calculations based on well-established formulas in calculus, specifically arc length from parametric equations.

Since the solution involves straightforward derivative computations followed by a calculation of an integral which can be checked for correctness, we classify this problem as:

EASY: straightforward derivative computation and integration.

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the parametric equations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=2.5(t-\sin t) \\
y=2.5(1-\cos t)
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{\pi}{2} \leq t \leq \pi
\end{aligned}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=2.5(t-\sin t) ; x_{t}^{\prime}=2.5(1-\cos t) \\
& y=2.5(1-\cos t) ; y_{t}^{\prime}=2.5 \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} \sqrt{2.5^{2}(1-\cos t)^{2}+2.5^{2} \sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2.5 \int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} \sqrt{(1-\cos t)^{2}+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2.5 \int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} \sqrt{1-2 \cos t+\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2.5 \int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} \sqrt{2(1-\cos t)} d t=\left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}
\pi / 2 \leq t \leq \pi \\
\sin (t / 2) \geq 0
\end{array}\right. \\
& =2.5 \int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} 2 \sin (t / 2) d t=5 \int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi} \sin (t / 2) d t= \\
& =-\left.10 \cos (t / 2)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{\pi}=-10 \cdot(\cos (\pi / 2)-\cos (\pi / 4))=-10 \cdot\left(0-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)=5 \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+18-13$ ” Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 18 | Integrals

## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 18-14

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:
The problem requires calculating the length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations, which involves differentiating these functions to compute the integral for the arc length. The solution goes through a clear and detailed computation process, culminating in the evaluation of the definite integral.

Since the primary work done here consists of differentiation and integration, both of which are straightforward computations involving known formulas for arc length, I classify this problem as follows:

EASY: The problem requires applying the formula for arc length in parametric form, deriving the necessary derivatives, and performing a straightforward integration to find the length.

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{\prime}(t)=e^{t}(\cos t+\sin t)+e^{t}(\cos t-\sin t)=2 e^{t} \cos t \\
& y^{\prime}(t)=e^{t}(\cos t-\sin t)+e^{t}(-\cos t-\sin t)=-2 e^{t} \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{3 \pi / 2} \sqrt{4 e^{2 t} \cos ^{2} t+4 e^{2 t} \sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{3 \pi / 2} 2 e^{t} \sqrt{\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{3 \pi / 2} 2 e^{t} \sqrt{1} d t=2 \int_{0}^{3 \pi / 2} e^{t} d t=\left.2 e^{t}\right|_{0} ^{3 \pi / 2}=2\left(e^{3 \pi / 2}-e^{0}\right)=2\left(e^{3 \pi / 2}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_18-24»

This process primarily entails making computations based on established formulas without proving any new properties.

Given that the problem requires straightforward calculations—finding derivatives, evaluating an integral, and using basic properties of functions—the problem fits well into a simple derivative computation followed by integral evaluation.

Classification: EASY

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=2(t-\sin t) ; x_{t}^{\prime}=2(1-\cos t) \\
& y=2(1-\cos t) ; y_{t}^{\prime}=2 \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{4(1-\cos t)^{2}+4 \sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{(1-\cos t)^{2}+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{1-2 \cos t+\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{2(1-\cos t)} d t=\mid 0 \leq t \leq \pi / 2 ; 0 \leq t / 2 \leq \pi / 4 \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 \sin (t / 2) d t=4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin (t / 2) d t= \\
& =-\left.8 \cos (t / 2)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}=-8 \cdot(\cos (\pi / 4)-\cos (0))=-8 \cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-1\right)=4(2-\sqrt{2})
\end{aligned}
$$

## Material from PlusPi

llm_response:
The problem involves calculating the arc length of a curve defined by specific parametric equations. The solution requires applying the formula for arc length, calculating derivatives, and integrating to find the final expression. This involves executing a computation to obtain the result.

Since the problem focuses on computational execution rather than providing a proof of a property or existence, it fits best as a straightforward computation where we verify steps through differentiation and integration.

Therefore, I classify this problem as:

EASY: The main task is to differentiate and compute the integral to find the arc length, which involves following a straightforward procedure.

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=2(\cos t+t \sin t) ; x^{\prime}(t)=2(-\sin t+\sin t+t \cos t)=2 t \cos t \\
& y=2(\sin t-t \cos t) ; y^{\prime}(t)=2(\cos t-\cos t+t \sin t)=2 t \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{(2 t \cos t)^{2}+(2 t \sin t)^{2}} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 t \sqrt{\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} t \sqrt{1} d t=\left.t^{2}\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}=\left(\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{2}-0\right)=\frac{\pi^{2}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Based on the definition of the derivative, find $f^{\prime}(0)$:

$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
e^{x \sin \frac{5}{x}}-1, x \neq 0 \\
0, x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

By definition, the derivative at the point $x=0$:

$f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}$

Based on the definition, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+\Delta x)-f(0)}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1-0\right) / \Delta x= \\
& =\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1\right) / \Delta x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
e^{\Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}-1 \sim \Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}_{\text {, as }} \Delta x \rightarrow 0\left(\Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x} \rightarrow 0\right)
$$

We get:

$$
=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x}}{\Delta x}=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \sin \frac{5}{\Delta x} \text { - the limit does not exist. }
$$

Thus, $f^{\prime}(0)$ - does not exist.

## Task Condition

Calculate approximately using the differential.

$$
y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}, x=4,16
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{0}$ of the argument $x$ is small in absolute value, then
$f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 4$

Then:

$\Delta x = 0.16$

Calculate:

$y(4) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{4}} = \frac{1}{2}$

$y^{\prime} = \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right)^{\prime} = \left(x^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\prime} = -\frac{1}{2} \cdot x^{-\frac{3}{2}}$

$y^{\prime}(4) = -\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4^{-\frac{3}{2}} = -\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{8} = -\frac{1}{16}$

We get:

$y(4.16) \approx y(4) + y^{\prime}(4) \cdot 0.16 = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{16} \cdot 0.16 = 0.49$

$$

original.problem:
## Condition of the problem

To derive the equation of the tangent line to the given curve at the point with abscissa $x_{0}$.

$$
y=\frac{1}{3 x+2}, x_{0}=2
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find $y^{\prime}:$

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{3 x+2}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{(3 x+2)^{2}} \cdot 3=-\frac{3}{(3 x+2)^{2}}$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=y^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=-\frac{3}{(3 \cdot 2+2)^{2}}=-\frac{3}{8^{2}}=-\frac{3}{64}$

Since the function $y^{\prime}$ at the point $x_{0}$ has a finite derivative, the equation of the tangent line is:
$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$, where

$y_{0}^{\prime}=-\frac{3}{64}$

$y_{0}=y\left(x_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{3 \cdot 2+2}=\frac{1}{8}$

We get:

$y-\frac{1}{8}=-\frac{3}{64} \cdot(x-2)$

$y=-\frac{3}{64} \cdot x+\frac{3}{32}+\frac{1}{8}$

$y=-\frac{3}{64} \cdot x+\frac{7}{32}$

Thus, the equation of the tangent line is:

$y=-\frac{3}{64} \cdot x+\frac{7}{32}$

$=\frac{1}{16+\ln ^{2} 3} \cdot\left(3^{x} \cdot \ln 3 \cdot(4 \sin 4 x+\ln 3 \cdot \cos 4 x)+3^{x}(16 \cos 4 x-4 \ln 3 \cdot \sin 4 x)\right)=$ $=\frac{3^{x}}{16+\ln ^{2} 3} \cdot\left(4 \ln 3 \cdot \sin 4 x+\ln ^{2} 3 \cdot \cos 4 x+16 \cos 4 x-4 \ln 3 \cdot \sin 4 x\right)=$

$=\frac{3^{x}}{16+\ln ^{2} 3} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 3 \cdot \cos 4 x+16 \cos 4 x\right)=\frac{3^{x} \cdot \cos 4 x}{16+\ln ^{2} 3} \cdot\left(\ln ^{2} 3+16\right)=3^{x} \cdot \cos 4 x$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the $n$-th order derivative.

$y=\frac{5 x+1}{13(2 x+3)}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\frac{5 x+1}{13(2 x+3)} \\
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{5 x+1}{13(2 x+3)}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{5 \cdot(2 x+3)-(5 x+1) \cdot 2}{13(2 x+3)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{10 x+15-10 x-2}{13(2 x+3)^{2}}=\frac{13}{13(2 x+3)^{2}}=\frac{1}{(2 x+3)^{2}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{(2 x+3)^{2}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-2}{(2 x+3)^{3}} \cdot 2=-\frac{2 \cdot 2}{(2 x+3)^{3}} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-\frac{2 \cdot 2}{(2 x+3)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=-\frac{2 \cdot(-3) \cdot 2}{(2 x+3)^{4}} \cdot 2=\frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 2^{2}}{(2 x+3)^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Obviously,
$y^{(n)}=\frac{(-1)^{n-1} \cdot n!\cdot 2^{n-1}}{(2 x+3)^{n+1}}$

## Task Condition

Find the derivative of the specified order.

$$
y=(3 x-7) \cdot 3^{-x}, y^{I V}=?
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left((3 x-7) \cdot 3^{-x}\right)^{\prime}=\left((3 x-7) \cdot\left(e^{\ln 3}\right)^{-x}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=\left((3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}\right)^{\prime}=3 e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}$

$y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(3 e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-3 \ln 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln 3 \cdot 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}+\ln ^{2} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}=$

$=-6 \ln 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}+\ln ^{2} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}$

$y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(-6 \ln 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}+\ln ^{2} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=6 \ln ^{2} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}+3 \ln ^{2} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln ^{3} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}=$

$=9 \ln ^{2} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln ^{3} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}$

$y^{I V}=\left(y^{\prime \prime \prime}\right)^{\prime}=\left(9 \ln ^{2} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln ^{3} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-9 \ln ^{3} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-3 \ln ^{3} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln ^{4} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}=$

$=-12 \ln ^{3} 3 \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}-\ln ^{4} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot e^{-x \cdot \ln 3}=$

$=-12 \ln ^{3} 3 \cdot 3^{-x}-\ln ^{4} 3 \cdot(3 x-7) \cdot 3^{-x}=(7 \ln 3-12-3 \ln 3 \cdot x) \cdot \ln ^{3} 3 \cdot 3^{-x}$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the volumes of solids formed by rotating figures bounded by the graphs of functions. The axis of rotation is $O x$.

$$
y=e^{1-x}, y=0, x=0, x=1
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since the $O x$ axis is the axis of rotation, the volume is found using the formula:

$$
V=\pi \cdot \int_{a}^{b} y^{2} d x
$$

From the problem statement, we already have the limits of integration: $x_{1}=0 ; x_{2}=1$

Let's find the volume of the solid of revolution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V=\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{1-x}\right)^{2} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{1} \cdot e^{-x}\right)^{2} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{2} e^{2} \cdot e^{-2 x} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2 x} d x= \\
& =\left.\pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot\left(-2 \cdot e^{-2 x}\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}= \\
& =2 \pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot\left(1-e^{-2}\right)=2 \pi \cdot\left(e^{2}-e^{2-2}\right)=2 \pi \cdot\left(e^{2}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since the axis

$O x$ is the axis of rotation, the volume is found using the formula:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_cfec74fe4e2360126fc5g-22.jpg?height=1374&width=1448&top_left_y=1006&top_left_x=495)

Let's find the limits of integration:

$$

$$

We will find the volume of the solid as the difference in volumes of two solids of revolution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V=\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}(\sqrt{x})^{2}-\left(x^{2}\right)^{2} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}\left(x-x^{4}\right) d x= \\
& =\left.\pi \cdot\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}-\frac{x^{5}}{5}\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}= \\
& =\pi \cdot\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{5}\right)=\frac{3 \pi}{10}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Find the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{x}}}{x \sqrt[4]{x^{3}}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{x}}}{x \sqrt[4]{x^{3}}} d x=\int x^{-\frac{7}{4}}\left(1+x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} d x=
$$

Under the integral is a binomial differential $x^{m}\left(a+b x^{n}\right)^{p}$, from which

$$
m=-\frac{7}{4} ; n=\frac{1}{2} ; p=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Since $\frac{m+1}{n}+p=\frac{-\frac{7}{4}+1}{\frac{1}{2}}+\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{1}{2}=-1$ is an integer, we use the substitution:

$$
a x^{-n}+b=z^{s} \text {, where } s \text { is the denominator of the fraction } p \text {. }
$$

That is, in our case, the substitution has the form:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{-\frac{1}{2}}+1=z^{2} \\
& x=\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-2} \\
& d x=-2\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-3} \cdot 2 z d z=-4 z\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-3} d z
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int\left(\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-2}\right)^{-\frac{7}{4}}\left(1+\left(\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}(-4 z)\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-3} d z= \\
& =\int\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{\frac{7}{2}}\left(1+\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-1}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}(-4 z)\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{-3} d z= \\
& =\int\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(1+\frac{1}{z^{2}-1}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}(-4 z) d z=\int\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{z^{2}}{z^{2}-1}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}(-4 z) d z= \\
& =\int\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \cdot \frac{z}{\left(z^{2}-1\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}}(-4 z) d z=-4 \int z^{2} d z=-\frac{4 z^{3}}{3}+C=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=-\frac{4\left(x^{-\frac{1}{2}}+1\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{3}+C=-\frac{4 \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}+1\right)^{3}}}{3}+C=-\frac{4 \sqrt{(1+\sqrt{x})^{3}}}{3 \sqrt[4]{x}}+C
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+13-1$ » Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem $13 \mid$ Integrals

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}-17}{x^{2}-4 x+3} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}-17}{x^{2}-4 x+3} d x=
$$

Under the integral, we have an improper fraction. Let's separate the integer part:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{3}-17 \\
& x^{2}-4 x+3 \\
& \frac{x^{3}-4 x^{2}+3 x}{4 x^{2}-3 x}-17 \\
& \frac{4 x^{2}-16 x+12}{13 x-29}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int\left(x+4+\frac{13 x-29}{x^{2}-4 x+3}\right) d x=\int(x+4) d x+\int \frac{13 x-29}{(x-1)(x-3)} d x=
$$

Let's decompose the proper rational fraction into partial fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{13 x-29}{(x-1)(x-3)}=\frac{A}{x-1}+\frac{B}{x-3}=\frac{A(x-3)+B(x-1)}{(x-1)(x-3)}=\frac{(A+B) x-(3 A+B)}{(x-1)(x-3)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B=13 \\
-(3 A+B)=-29
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A=8 \\
B=5
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{x+1}{x(x-1)}=\frac{8}{x-1}+\frac{5}{x-3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we get:

$$
=\int(x+4) d x+\int\left(\frac{8}{x-1}+\frac{5}{x-3}\right) d x=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+4 x+8 \ln |x-1|+5 \ln |x-3|+C
$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{2 x^{3}-1}{x^{2}+x-6} d x=
$$

Under the integral, we have an improper fraction. Let's separate the integer part:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
2 x^{3}-1 & \frac{x^{2}+x-6}{2 x-2} \\
\frac{2 x^{3}+2 x^{2}-12 x}{-2 x^{2}+12 x-1}-1 & \\
\frac{-2 x^{2}-2 x+12}{14 x-13} &
\end{array}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int\left(2 x-2+\frac{14 x-13}{x^{2}+x-6}\right) d x=\int(2 x-2) d x+\int \frac{14 x-13}{(x+3)(x-2)} d x=
$$

Let's decompose the proper rational fraction into partial fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{14 x-13}{(x+3)(x-2)}=\frac{A}{x+3}+\frac{B}{x-2}=\frac{A(x-2)+B(x+3)}{(x+3)(x-2)}=\frac{(A+B) x+(-2 A+3 B)}{(x+3)(x-2)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B=14 \\
-2 A+3 B=-13
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B=3 \\
A=11
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{14 x-13}{(x+3)(x-2)}=\frac{11}{x+3}+\frac{3}{x-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we get:

$$

$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{5}-x^{3}+1}{x^{2}-x} d x=
$$

Under the integral, we have an improper fraction. Let's separate the integer part:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\frac{x^{5}-x^{3}+1}{x^{5}-x^{4}} & \frac{\mid x^{2}-x}{x^{3}+x^{2}} \\
\frac{x^{4}-x^{3}+1}{1} &
\end{array}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int\left(x^{3}+x^{2}\right) d x+\int \frac{1}{x^{2}-x} d x=
$$

We will use the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{x^{2}-x}=\frac{1}{x(x-1)}=\frac{A}{x}+\frac{B}{x-1}=\frac{A(x-1)+B x}{x(x-1)}=\frac{(A+B) x-A}{x(x-1)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B=0 \\
-A=1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B=1 \\
A=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{1}{x^{2}-x}=-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we get:

$$
=\int\left(x^{3}+x^{2}\right) d x+\int\left(-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x-1}\right) d x=\frac{x^{4}}{4}+\frac{x^{3}}{3}-\ln |x|+\ln |x-1|+C
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{5}+3 x^{3}-1}{x^{2}+x} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{5}+3 x^{3}-1}{x^{2}+x} d x=
$$

Under the integral is an improper fraction. Let's separate the integer part:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{5}+3 x^{3}-1 \\
& \frac{x^{5}+x^{4}}{-x^{4}+3 x^{3}-1} \\
& \frac{-x^{4}-x^{3}}{4 x^{3}-1} \\
& \frac{4 x^{3}+4 x^{2}}{-4 x^{2}}-1 \\
& \quad \frac{-4 x^{2}-4 x}{4 x}-1
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int\left(x^{3}-x^{2}+4 x-4\right) d x+\int \frac{4 x-1}{x^{2}+x} d x=
$$

Let's use the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{4 x-1}{x^{2}+x}=\frac{4 x-1}{x(x+1)}=\frac{A}{x}+\frac{B}{x+1}=\frac{A(x+1)+B x}{x(x+1)}=\frac{(A+B) x+A}{x(x+1)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B=4 \\
A=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B=5 \\
A=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{4 x-1}{x^{2}+x}=-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{5}{x+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int\left(x^{3}-x^{2}+4 x-4\right) d x+\int\left(-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{5}{x+1}\right) d x= \\
& =\frac{x^{4}}{4}-\frac{x^{3}}{3}+2 x^{2}-4 x-\ln |x|+5 \cdot \ln |x+1|+C
\end{aligned}
$$
